It was just a really poor way to handle the situation - extremely unprofessional.  Poor customer service.
author: Kristen M.

description: I love a cup of philz. Mostly drink my coffee rich and black-so I go for a Jacobs. If im feeling wild ill get the mocha tesora with no extra sugar- VERY GOOD. Iced ecstatic coffee is refreshing and light. Fresh mintnleaves in the mojito are bomb. I LOVE THIS COFFEE.
author: Carla R.

description:
What can I say about Philz that hasn't already been said before? You all know the coffee is delicious and each of the blends are hand roasted and blended by Phil and his son Jacob.

However, on my very first visit to Philz this morning, I found out Phil is one of the most savvy and astute businessmen in town as well. Not only is he someone who loves his trade, but he is also extremely proud of what he does, and generous as well. 

I think it's such a lost art in this day and age for real connections between the consumer and producer. At Philz, the man who makes the coffee you drink is present in each gulp you take. Sometimes, he might even shake your hand and greet you at the register. 

That's what I love about this place; I've found my new favorite cafe.
author: May T.

description: Okok ... This time, DO believe the hype. Now tell me where I can buy stock and when they'll open in TriBeCa and Portland.
author: Cydney B.

description:
We heard about this place through friends and family and decided to get this last stop in before we left SF.  So glad we did.  
We really didn't know the drill on this place, so we just got in line and followed along with the other customers.  We weren't sure what to order, so we quickly started reading the descriptions of everything on the front of the counter.  I had heard the mocha, the Turkish Coffee and the Mojito Ice Coffee.  Since it was a bit chilly, I decided to get the Mocha and Dave got the Turkish.  If you want anything in your coffee like cream or sweetener, they do all of that for you.  Each cup is individually brewed and made to your liking.  I didn't ask for any sweetener because I didn't want my mocha to be too sweet.  It came out perfectly.  Dave's Turkish was to die for.  I almost wish I ordered that.  They also have some baked goods there as well.  I had the croissant and Dave ordered a couple vegan donuts which were pretty darn good as well.  
We are wishing we had a Philz in So Cal, but since there isn't we just took a couple of bags with us home.
author: Leslie C.

description:
All you need to know about Philz:

Quality products
Great environment
Tasty drinks and snacks
Friendly staff
Book swap shelf
LOVE

My Sunday was spent here doing some quality thinking and relaxing.  I walked in with the smells already making me feel enlightened and ready to conquer my life's plan.  I got an Iced Green Tea with Honey (that's right, I don't even drink Coffee), so refreshing and energizing.  
Everyone did their own thing and shared smiles with each other between delightful sips of beverages.  Seriously such an amazing environment.  Big tables, small tables, tables facing the windows, comfy couches and  soft chairs.

If I did drink coffee, I'd go with the Turkish, my friend was here for 10 days and made me take her as often as possible, even when we were going somewhere in the opposite direction.

Thanks Philz for making people smile :)
author: Megan L.

description: i am hooked on their mint mojito or ginger snap iced coffees! one sip and i am sure you'll become a fan of philz! their ambience of the shop is cool! there is always something to look at when you're waiting for your order to come up!
author: Donald G.

description:
I love a strong, clean, smooth cup of coffee, Philz is all of that and more. 
If you are visiting for the first time, keep in mind it takes longer than your standard coffee shop. Here you select the beans of your choice and they individually brew and sweeten your coffee as you've ordered it. 

Best cup of coffee...ever. Such a treat.
author: Antonya W.

description:
The ORIGINAL Philz location! Definitely love this one better than the one in Castro, and maybe better than the one in SOMA. The feeling here is much more homey and relaxing. More seating too. Knowledgeable, friendly, and energetic staff.

Try the Silken Splendor or Anesthesia to the Upside! Or a Mint Mojito Iced Coffee on a hot day.
author: Brad Y.

description: Damn this place has good coffee, but they're a victim of their own success. If you only have time to grab a quick coffee, this place is out of the question. The lines are long and you just have to wait your turn.
author: John H.

description: I have since come fairly regularly to several PHILZ  locations convenient to me and have a better grasp of the coffee i like from them... I do believe that the overall flavor does vary from store to store but there are several variables at play.... from beans to the fact that each cup is hand poured.... I tend to stick to the darker/darkest roasts like a Jacob's or Turkish but have ventured to try some of their lighter roasts... I tend to misson the lighter roasts but they have a wide enough selection for most palates. If youre not a regular, the baristas are pretty helpful... they should be able to point you in the right direction :)
author: Denny C.

description:
I want to thank the kind man who worked at Philz the other night who was closing up, but let us order my 1 cup of decaf.

I really thank them for the service and great quality of coffee.  It's a fun destination for me when I visit SF.
author: Kristina F.

description: Hmm..love their Iced Mint Mojito with Almond milk!! This coffee always hits the spot no matter which location I'm at. Nice atmosphere and workers too! Met Phil (the owner of this place) and he is really kind too.
author: Clementine D.

description:
i wanted to love it... but can't say i did

i got the mint mojito iced coffee and boy was it creamy!
all the cream really masked the flavor of the coffee and made the drink too heavy. 
had i known they put so much cream in it, i'd have asked for less. i did like the addition of the mint, however.

i swear they put something in their coffee because although i couldn't taste the coffee too much, i was so jacked on the caffeine? that i got a massive headache and that usually never happens to me
author: Priscilla P.

description:
I'm a semi-prolific Yelper if I do say so myself. But when it comes to my alltime favorites I'm a little shy about Yelping. I mean what can you say about Philz? That's it's the best most decadent coffee ever? That Phil himself is a charmer who will simultaneously have you laughing and blushing? That the 24th Street location is the most laid-back wonderful place ever? That I never thought I'd dig a coffee place with a fake palm tree but now I simply cannot appreciate a coffee place that doesn't have one? I could go on and on but basically if you're reading this you're just wondering why you should go to Philz and I can't tell you that. Once you go you'll know, you'll just know.

Also, if you have a Green Zebra book you get a buy 2 get 1 coffee free coupon which is great if you want to introduce your really good friends to some Philz love.
author: Kelly S.

description: I usually go to the Van Ness location but this place is super cool, super chill.  Friendly staff and right across the street from La Reina bakery.  Makes me want to move to this neighborhood.
author: Nico O.

description: Probably the best coffee outside Seattle - they take care to make it exactly as you order, and it's well worth the wait.  Great place to hang out and people-watch.
author: Alan C.

description: Service is great! Had the medium sweet iced coffee with vanilla soy. I see why its voted best homemade coffee. A must try!
author: Trent O.

description:
Spot on with the taste waves of the Philharmonic blend. 
Hot with the right ratio of milk, coffee, and a bit of sweetener. 
Never knew coffee could be made so... well.
author: Anna K.

description:
This is my favorite coffee shop anywhere ever.

The coffee is incredible (my personal favorite is Tesora - I actually have dreamed about it, longed for it - I've never had coffee like it anywhere else).
The atmosphere is amazing - it feels like someone's garage, all mix matched furniture and laid back vibe.
There is free wifi, plenty of outlets, and lots of people hanging out, reading and working
The coffee is amazing. I just can't say it enough.

I love Philz from anywhere, but this particular Philz on 24th street is like my home away from home. It is the gold standard by which I judge all other coffee houses, and I can't recommend it enough.
author: Lil M.

description:
This was the first time I went to this Philz as I am usually getting my coffee fix at the one of Van Ness.  Nonetheless, the coffee was just as amazing!  I opted for the Mint Mojito Iced Coffee. WOW! Idk...I'm a bit speechless and am at a loss for words at how good it is. All I'm saying is that it is a MUST TRY!  

Service was a bit more backed up and there are definitely more people that come to this location.  Today I wanted to buy some beans but since their cash register was down they couldn't sell it to me =(  I know that stuff like that was uncontrollable but eh I was a bit disappointed!

On a side note....I had my coffee at 5pm and the caffeine is still running through my system!  I am on 2 1/2hrs of sleep right now (it is now 7 AM)! Ahhhhh!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. I've been an avid coffee drinker for years, but Starbucks was my go-to place b/c nothing ever stood out to me. Not even Bluebottle. But THIS, and Philz MINT MOJITO COFFEE takes the cake! (coffee cake?) The MINT they put in their coffee makes the flavor POP, and oh baby is that flavor DELICIOUS! I also prefer this location over the one in the Castro---the Mission location is a lot bigger, and there is plenty of seating to go around. I didn't think the Mocha Tesora was anything special--tasted like any other mocha. It's all about the mint mojito!! 

Tip #1: Bring lots of change for parking (or come after 6pm when meters are free :)
author: Diane G.

description: I always have to stop by Philz when I'm in San Francisco. The staff is so friendly. They will not let you leave until your coffee is exactly the way you want it. They truly have passion for great coffee and a real commitment to their customers. Philz is a standout.
author: Kelly P.

description: simply the best. I even had it shipped to Fort Lauderdale cause my girlfriend loved it so much while we were in the Mission.
author: Michelle B.

description:
I went here because we were in the area. My friend had heard of Philz and wanted to try it out. We didn't know what to order, so we asked the barista about the items on the menu. I ended up getting Jacob's something or other...I found the barista putting sugar and cream in for me to be odd. She did a pretty good job though and it tasted fine. I don't know if it was worth $3 for drip coffee though. Call me tacky, but I'm happy with plain coffee and vanilla creamer. 

The ambiance in there was peaceful. They had some good looking food behind the counter. I got a samosa and it was quite good. 

If I'm in the area I may come here again but wouldn't go out of my way.
author: gabby m.

description:
Philz Coffee, with so many choices of bean juice lining 24th Street what makes Philz stand out from the pack? It's the love. Great owners, great employees, make great customers.

 I'd gladly pay just to stand around for the 20 minutes a day it takes me to drink my beloved Philz brews!

OK, about the coffee and tea, it's like 31 flavors up in Philz. Possibly overwhelming at first but the great people of Philz will be more than glad to guide you through each and every time you visit.

Try Philz Coffee, a few times. 

You won't be sorry, although I might as now I have added one more body to the line-up everyday at Philz. ENJOY!
author: Steve R.

description:
One of the best Turkish coffee brews that I've had in regular coffee size....next time you are in the Mission, it's worth a trip here to try the Philz Harmonic! I like the "one cup at a time" concept and they put just the right amount of sugar & milk in your coffee. Friendly staff.  Prices are more like Starbucks, around $3.25 for a small cup.

My only issue with this place is that the descriptions of the coffee are on a board that's below eye level and right where folks stand to order...making it difficult for first-timers to read the rather extensive menu of brew options in advance, as the descriptions get blocked out by people in line ahead. I wish they moved the coffee/brew descriptions to a board behind the baristas at/above eye level. It'd speed up the ordering process.
author: Shweta V.

description: Yep, it's as good as it gets and worth $4 for a large coffee  - the Either is magic
author: Scott L.

description:
Yes, this is a five star experience. No ifs, ands, or buts. Let me get that much on the table at the outset. Philz deserves this for respecting the bean. You gotta love a place that has enough 60kilo burlap bags from coffee purchases past to basically decorate the walls of the unisexed/metrosexed/transsexed bathroom (save for the hilarious graffiti allowed to become slightly off-colored public art for your reading pleasure).

I sampled the Jamaican Blue Bottle (oops .. Freudian slip. I mean Blue MOUNTAIN, of course), perhaps the best $7 I have ever spent on a drip coffee. The Tesora that my wife had was house-blended $2.75 perfection - the greatest caffeinated deal in the city, probably. And the Silken Splendor - other than being a tempting name for a John Waters flick (go Baltimore!) - was fine. Real fine. And a little sensual, as far as beans go.

There is a nice grungy vibe here, cool social spaces to sit and sip, and the place seems to ooze with local history during times when people could still light up inside as well as out (and before the Purple Haze Smoke Shop came to town, probably). It's actually amazing to me that Philz has only been around since 2003! I would have thought it to be older than Central Perk and Cafe Nervosa, at least.*

So, let's just say that I'd probably like to sit and get buzzed on the brown stuff with Phil J. one of these days. I'd like to ask him to expand upon the web site justification concerning why he avoids mentioning the origins of his beans and foregrounds instead the masterful art of blending. Yes, blends are amazing and likely take decades of hard work to master. But even a fine blended wine in Bordeaux, which might come from 4 or 5 wine varietals, is STILL labeled according to its terroir. Personally, I like to travel vicariously through the magic of the bean to different parts of the world. Hence the reason why I ordered the Jamaican Blue Mountain (you made an exception to the rule here, Phil! You can't hide it under the specials section of the menu from me!! And Kona wouldn't be Kona w/out Hawai'i). It might be nice to mention the places of origin of at least some of the blends. But I will not second-guess the master. 

(*) Note: do not try Yelping these places. If you have to ask, you obviously missed the 1990s and the golden age of caffeinated sitcoms.
author: Bradley N.

description: Coffee is amazing. Perfect jolt for an early morning practice. Couches are comfy and there's a quiet eclectic vibe perfect for studying film.
author: Rasheed L.

description:
Iced  Ecstatic coffee...= Instant talking fast.
Amazingly the best coffee.Hands down.
author: Lia N.

description:
I'm such a sucker for coffee, on top of that, I'm fickle. I like my coffee and lattes just so. When I first heard about Philz a few weeks ago, it made it's way to the top of my must go list. 

Parking at this location was a nightmare. In the rain, we drove around and around and around and arrived soaked and cold. Prepare yourself.

We walked in and there were signs with very specific instructions at where to line up. The problem with this was that we were unable to plow through the menu without #1 a dictionary , #2 a thesaurus #3 house cheat sheet. I understand that coffee shops like this have a cultish following, but for those of us who just want a great cup of coffee, it felt incredibly isolating. The girl that helped us was knowledgeable and kind, she explained they way it works and recommended the New Manhattan and Ambrosia roasts for us. Hubs wanted a latte though and since he didn't/couldn't find them on the menu, felt pressured to accept the steaming cup of goodness that was being hand crafted just for him. His $4.00 cup of coffee went almost untouched. 

I like the idea of Philz and if I'm in the area, I wouldn't hesitate to come back in. Certainly, I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here. I hope other locations are easier to maneuver and not so suffocating with their coffee culture.  

Coffee was predictably delicious. My Apple Pecan Vegan scone...OMFG. I am not vegan, I typically don't like vegan baked goods, but this one looked way too appetizing to pass up and I am so glad I gave it a go.
author: Heidi S.

description:
What can I say? I didn't want to like Philz...I wanted to find it "over-hyped" & too expensive like one usually does with these types of places. But...I'm a convert. I loved my coffee! Went in around 8:30pm on a Sunday, needed caffeine in a BAD way, and my lovely barista was able to recommend and make a very good coffee (REALLY wish I could remember the name....not Sooo Good or the Heaven one but the other caffeine-heavy coffee). The mint leaves in it were divine & I'm doing that w/ my coffee from now on. 

A little expensive? Well, yeah...I think $2.75 for a regular cup of coffee is a bit much...but...I'm going to pay it again and again if the coffee is that good. End of my story. 

Oh - and them supporting Nabolom Bakery (a Berkeley bakery that's yummy) is all-that much better!
author: Marissa H.

description:
I usually go to the one in Palo Alto, but Angelica N showed me this venue the other day. It's waaaaaaaay (with eight a's) more hipster than its Silicon Valley sister. What I like about it is that there's plenty of space to sit down and people watch. Also, Phil was there and thanked me for coming in. I'm sure he doesn't do that with just *anyone*.

I'm not a coffee snob, but I will tell you I like the Anesthesia, probably because it takes like a coffee milkshake to me. I also recommend getting the Philz iPhone app so you can keep track of which blends you like/or just think are okay.
author: Huey K.

description: Cozy and eclectic atmosphere. An absolute original and truly worth a visit for a cup of coffee.
author: Jack L.

description:
Excellent coffee in the Mission District of San Francisco. Solidly strong, not too bitter with a long list of specialty drinks.

The decor needs a major overhaul, though.
author: Alex C.

description:
How to spend a perfect Sunday: 
1.  FIRST, go to Dianda's on Mission for cookies and an almond torte.
2.  NEXT, off to Philz on 24th and Folsom for a Turkish grind with mint (but choose your barista wisely).
3.  THEN, savor every sip and delight in every crumb
4.  FINALLY, look forward to repeating Steps 1, 2, & 3 next Sunday.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
Best coffee I've had in the bay area, so far. Philz is a very well known place in this city, as within the first week I moved here I had several people recommend I try it immediately. After the first visit I knew why!

The "Tantalizing Turkish" dark roast with cardamom and fresh mint leaves is just such a treat. Once I can afford it I would love to buy a bunch of this and make it at home, all the time. The "Jacobs Wonderbar" is another one of my dark roast favorites, with a clean, robust coffee flavor and bold chocolate and nutty finish.

I rarely get anything lighter, but when I do It's the Philharmonic or the Tesora. The staff, and obviously Phil, have great knowledge of the different blends, so if you aren't sure what you want they will help you based on what you like. And I'd be surprised if you dont enjoy what they have recommended.

Eventually I'd like to try all of them, I have yet to dislike anything I've had from Philz, and I have a feeling I never will!
author: Chris G.

description:
Probably the best coffee I have ever had. Just to make sure, I went several times and tried different blends. The first time, I found the Turkish blend to be amazingly smooth, with a sweet and nutty flavor. The cardamom was very subtle and enhanced the overall flavor of the coffee without overpowering it. This location (24th Street) gets pretty crowded, but I managed to find seating and an outlet so I could work on my laptop. All in all, a great experience. 

I returned and Phil was behind the bar - he made me a cup of Arabic coffee which was delicious - again, the same nuttiness and sweetness from whatever roasting process he uses. Although the cafe was crowded this time, I still managed to find a place to sit and work on my laptop. 

Finally, I tried the Philharmonic and the Tesora. Both were delicious - not quite as strong as the previous two blends I tried. There is absolutely no bitterness in his coffees and I believe even a non-coffee drinker would be hooked by these coffees, they are that good. Thanks Phil!
author: Robert C.

description:
Some people have called me a bitch. 
Some people were right. 

Those people are also stupid because you never talk to me before I've had at least three cups of coffee. Seriously.

Enter Philz Coffee.

Just walking into the cafe made me instantly warm and fuzzy inside. The delicious aroma of roasted beans and freshly drip-brewed coffee was amazing. In a flash they took my order. A sprig of mint and out the door to enjoy happiness in a cup. 

I'm telling you...I'm a darling and your bestie once I've experienced a cup o' joe.
author: Jay H.

description: Great coffee and a cool place to hang out.  I had high expectations, as friends from all over the country had extolled Philz's virtues.  I was not disappointed!!!!  I cannot wait to go back, and wish I had a similar place in New Jersey to get coffee and hang out.
author: Matthew K.

description: I love Philz!!!  Blue bottle, Boyds and Philz is about the only coffee I drink nowadays.  The Ambrosia, iced with crushed mint is to die for . . . . . and Dynamo donuts is right down the street from this store so how can you lose???  Ambrosia + bacon maple donut please =)
author: Erin B.

description: I dedicate my 200 review to a cup of coffee! This was my very first visit to a Philz and I am hooked.  However, it did not really help energize me but whatever it tasted good.  The price is decent and portion is not bad.  I must say they do need a better ordering system.  It is kinda confusing standing in line... order, get your drink then pay.  Anyways, I will pay Philz a visit very soon.  Until, our lips meet again!
author: Ann L.

description:
We were in the Mission for the street food festival. After gorging on some lovely food, we were on our way back to the bus-stop when we came across Philz. 
The line was fairly big, but I'd heard good things about this place, and decided to check it out. 
I ordered the philharmonic. The coffee was sublime. It had an amazing slight bitter taste to it, and they add a sprig of mint to every cup. They prepare it right in front of you, right from the beans. So each cuppa joe is as fresh as it can get. 
The service is incredible too. They actually ask you to taste it before you walk off to make sure you like what you got! 

Coffee with a smile.... thats Philz...
author: Gurpreet S.

description:
I kind of agree with Teddy B's comment ...it's a good place for some overpriced filter drip coffee with a bit of show."  Although I don't really think it is that over priced.  The coffee is good but I don't think it is that much better than Peets. Maybe I just don't have that discriminating of a pallet but I couldn't really tell the difference. 

What I really enjoyed about Philz was how friendly and helpfully the staff was. After speaking with them for a bit it was evident that I knew very little about different type of blends and roasts. They were able to help me pick out a coulpld of pounds of diffent coffee that I was buying for girts and for myself. 

If am ever in the Mission in the morning I will be hitting up Philiz for a cup.
author: Jeff P.

description:
If you ever feel like you need to get a cup of coffee, please please PLEASE...do yourself a favor and come here. Philz Coffee is the best coffee place I can think of in San Francisco.

There are several brews to choose from. Personally, I went for the "Soooooooo Good" (number 18, I believe). I didn't know what to expect. I thought to myself, "It's a cup of coffee, how different can it really be?" Let me tell you right now, the first sip punched me in the taste buds with a delicious, glorious uppercut!

This experience alone has convinced me to try EVERY SINGLE brew they've got (and believe me, they've got quite a few). The lady who made my cup was extremely friendly. So was the guy who rang up my order. So the service gets an "A+" from me.

Point is, go here for your coffee fix. You will not be disappointed!
author: Daniel M.

description:
I thought I'd write this review, because I was waxing nostalgic about the summer I spent in San Francisco in 2005. Back then, this was the only Philz, and Phil himself was the barristo. I found both his "one cup at a time" shtick and chatty manner charming. And the coffee was great! I remember that he put actual mint leaves in it, which I'd never seen before. The closest thing was mint tea in the Middle East. I've tried this myself numerous times, and it always turns out terribly, so I need to go back and find out how Phil does it.

I lived in the Mission, and I stopped at Philz almost every day. A few times, I got to listen in to the owner's family drama. I can tell you this for sure: Phil ran a tight ship and was an ambitious businessman. Whenever his son was working the counter, he couldn't get away with anything (like talking to his girlfriend on the phone when he was supposed to be serving customers). I loved it.

Sometimes, Phil would excitedly tell me about his plans for expansion. And I thought, yeah, whatever, the coffee is really good, but the cafe itself wasn't anything that special. People are always talking expansion, and I've heard more than one hard sell from a Middle Eastern guy in my life. Well, I guess I have to swallow my skepticism, because I check back five years later, and suddenly Philz is a veritable franchise, with locations all over the city and merchandise to boot. I am stunned by his success, but I can only congratulate him for it while reserving to myself some small sentiment for the good old days, when Phil himself made the coffee. I wonder if he still does...
author: Steven S.

description: Philz Coffee is worth the wait!  Whether the line is short or long, don't go in a hurry.  Savor the service, selection, and true mainstay of the Mission.  Where firefighters mix with artists, locals, dot com imports, and the gainfully unemployed nurse their laptops.  Philz in the Mission, like its roasts, has a vibrant energy and whimsy that is unmatched by other craft coffee houses in the area.
author: Heather G.

description:
BEST COFFEE EVER!!

I took both my family and my friends who were out of town to this delightful place and they also agreed that it is one of the best cup of coffee they've had. 

The dancing water and the red eye are both great! Love this place.
author: Sophie S.

description:
YUM- this is the best coffee ever- you have to try the "philharmonic"

The coffee is like methamphetamine, and you will be awake for work after one cup definitely....but coming down will not be as hard....: )

They also have the best lemon poppyseed muffins I have ever tasted- I do not think Phil makes them, however.
author: Lisa M.

description:
I'm not big on coffee, so my rating should be discounted. I'll just give it the same rating that way it doesn't affect the overall rating. However I will comment on the atmosphere. It has a very laid back hipster feel atmosphere. Very chill place to be your unique self. The coffee place doesn't really fit the neighborhood, but it's a nice place to go. The coffee was really strong, and way too bitter for me. I guess it has a complex layers of taste to it. I hear it's good. Even with the cream and sugar, it was too much for me.

This was place #2 of our SF visit progressive food run.
author: Arnold W.

description: I'll keep this short and sweet.  I drive 700 miles round trip to satisfy my Philz craving.  It is THAT good.
author: Nile N.

description:
Philz Coffee shop's new slogan should be ''If you're a douchebag and carry your mac wherever you go come on in for a coffee". 

We walked in here for a meeting and honestly got stared down by everyone. And I mean everyone. This place obviously caters to what the neighborhood is becoming - douchey hipsterville. I'm glad that the area is cleaning up but about 4 years ago everything used to be genuine, mellow, and unpretentious. New places were opening up and really fostering what the area was about. Philz coffee is a great example of what this area is going to become and I don't like it. 

I like independent coffee shops as much as the next guy - I will avoid Starbucks as much as possible and will even go a few blocks out of the way to support an independent coffee house. However, this location of Philz sucks and it disgusts me that a group of us can't even walk in without being judged and starred at b.c. we're showered and don't wear plaid shirts. And honestly, the selection of drink/food at this Philz sucked. 

What happened to just getting a coffee without judgement?
author: Sasha B.

description: By far the BEST COFFEE I have ever had. I'm from LA and I wish we had a Philz Coffee shop in Southern California. Coffee Bean and Starbucks ain't got nothing on Philz. I would fly to the Bay Area for some Philz because that's how good their coffee is. BOMB COFFEE!!!
author: Mary M.

description: I went here on Election Day last year on my break from working at the Elections at Alvarado Elementary. . I spotted Philz on the way to the voting place and decided to go back during my first break. My first impression, it's for hipsters. But, the coffee there is the best. They have all these different blends there and being a caffeine freak, I went for the 3 Way Alarm(?) blend. The blend had a smokey, chocolatey aroma to it and it tasted amazing! For once, coffee that tastes as the price says! I strongly recommend this place to anyone, if not EVERY ONE!
author: Richard L.

description: Loved the mint monitor, creamy and sweet. Really refreshing. Enjoyed that it was the original location. It's got lots of seating and couches and tables, free wifi for people to do work. Quite a lot of people though - went on a Friday morning at 11am and most chairs were filled.
author: Deanna L.

description: I guess I just don't get it.  It's really expensive.  You're supposed to be happy that every cup is made one at a time but I don't really care about that.  If it's good, that's enough, but I've had two cups that were hard to swallow.  Also why can't I sugar it myself?  For such an expensive place I thought the baked goods would be nicer too but they were the typical crap - seemed to me, anyways.  Blegh.  Maybe I'm just cranky right now but I just don't get it.
author: M C.

description: The Philtered Sould reigns supreme for those with a sweet tooth for coffee!
author: Candy R.

description: Really Nice cup of Coffe! had the Basil Infused coffe. Other thought it was really strong but It was perfect for me. I loved how they put basil in the coffee. Gave it a perfect floral and earthyness to the coffee. try out the Thai basil coffee here! really tasty.
author: Joseph G.

description:
Full disclosure: I am not a scenester or hipster, do not own tight pants, and generally find it difficult to be concerned with what fads other people in my sub-35 age group are doing with themselves.  That being said, read on for a review focused on the coffee.  

I have a ton of enthusiasm to convey in support of this fine coffee purveyor! I have been a coffee enthusiast for over half of my life, and have worked for many places big and small (Dunkins', Peets, Starbucks) and have never had a cup this good.  

The 'cup at a time' aspect of the service is where it's at, with your choice going from bean to cup in less than 5 minutes.  Plus, I've found that the staff can read your cream and sugar preferences very well.  I have been to the San Jose, Palo Alto, and SF locations, and have experienced great customer service in all the locations.  Philz puts other coffee houses and brands to shame. (Starbucks is really quite lost.) You must try it!

The vegan donuts are good too.

Some good coffees I have had from Philz:

1. New Manhattan
2. Tasura
3. Silkin' Splendor
4. Julie's


Enjoy!
author: TJ D.

description:
Crack-in-a-cup would probably describe this place fairly accurately. I'm not big on coffee, and considering how ridiculously strong their coffees are (including the "light" roasts), you can imagine my jitteriness throughout the rest of the day. 

If I'm ever in need of a huge jolt of waking-up, this will be my go-to place. Seriously great coffee, and though I've never done crack, I imagine the effects would be somewhat similar to the effects after drinking a cup-o-philz.
author: Sami A.

description: I love this place, fresh brew and nice coffee beans. If you are Coffee aficionado you will love this place.
author: Tyler Y.

description:
This shop has the most interesting interior and 
offer "Special" blend coffee such as Code 33 that
I believe the other shops do not have.
author: Yoshiko M.

description: I love this place even though it is expensive - the coffe is delicious and it's a unique experience. This isn't a cup of joe you can make at home - the beans are blended w/ other beans to make their own special brews. So it's diff than going to blue bottle or four barrels and getting a great cup from there. I go w/out the mint leaf but many people like it.
author: Rew C.

description:
I've been coming here almost every day for the last 4 years. My boyfriend and I shared our second date here, and it's become our daily ritiual together. 

The staff are friendly and awesome, I never run out of different coffee options since you can mix any of the blends to create a new coffee sensation (my new favorite is the "red julie"), and I love the homey decore that totally appeals to the clutter bug inside me. 

I really don't have much to much else to say, except it's my home away from home and it's THE BEST coffee in san francisco, and I'll be coming here for years to come. 

Love you guys!
author: Cake S.

description: Ecstatic iced coffee will rock your world. I honestly feel like the coffee makers connected with me on a spiritual level about my coffee THATS HOW GOOD IT IS. I will never look at coffee the same way again. If you don't like philz you probably didn't deserve to be there in the first place. Thank you Philz for making the world a better place. Philz doesn't just make awesome coffee, the make better days (and probably better lives)
author: Jackie J.

description:
If coffee is your religion, your congregation meets at Philz Coffee.

I do audio engineering for a living, and as all audio engineers know; coffee is the fuel of our trade.

Every Sunday however, I arrive at Philz to celebrate the Great Mystery of Philz Bean.

Did Phil sell his soul at the crossroads in exchange for the secret to delivering texture with taste?
Does Phil "do something" to the water he infuses into that magical hand-crafted cup (quite "analog" I might add)?
Has Phil commissioned his own line of filters to sustain the purity of the bean as the water passes through the grounds, through the filter, and into my cup?
Will Phil ever create a POS system that solves ordering and payment in one easy step?

While these and other mysteries remain in the ether of my mind, I dream of Sunday.  My perfect (always perfect!) cup of Philz in my hand.

I am not a religious person, but that cup of Philz sure makes me feel like one.

Drink the word that Phil preaches, and you too will understand.
author: Mike W.

description:
Total nube at Philz today. Wasn't sure how to maneuver myself through the ordering/paying/waiting process but got through it just fine without embarrassing myself too badly.  

We didn't know what to order so we used the coffee names to help us!  I ordered a "Sooo Good" and my friend had "Itz The Best".  Both were pretty pretty good.  

Two blocks later, I was still talking about how good it was.  Officially converting from Ritual to Philz.
author: Helen V.

description:
I think this is the best coffee in San Francisco. It perks me up without making me jittery. (By way of example, Blue Bottle is really delicious but I feel I need to be scraped off the ceiling.)
My favorite things to order at Philz, depending on mood: 
Tesora, Philz way (coffee -yes. Cream - yes. Sugar - yes) 
Iced mint mojito (so good I try to refrain from chugging it.)
There are several Philz Coffee locations but my favorite is at the Mission. It's the perfect place to people watch and savor your coffee on a weekend morning.
author: D Z.

description:
If you are just starting to go to Philz or haven't been, start with coffee #1 and go down the list with every visit.  This was my approach, and found the Turkish and Ambrosia were personal favorites.  The place can get crowded - especially on the weekends.  But probably worth the wait.

5 stars on the coffee, 3 stars for the hipster crowded-ness and Apple-laptop takeovers.
author: Nick H.

description: Friendly staff, great coffee and very reasonably priced. Best place for coffee in Bay Area.
author: Ben L.

description:
Come here for the ambience (love the couches!), not necessarily to have a mind-blowing cup of coffee.

Coffee is somewhat bitter (needs a lot of sugar), and the iced teas aren't prepared quite right (pouring hot, fresh brew over ice doesn't make it taste better - it melts the ice and waters down my drink).

But the atmosphere in here is always very welcoming, despite the grubbiness.  I love the couches, and there always seems to be at least one group of people (or a couple) that is playing a game.

The baristas are really friendly, but if you're not a Mission hipster type or a regular, you may feel that you have to earn their trust/smiles, which is a really weird feeling for a paying customer to have.
author: Dmytro A.

description:
Good single made cups of coffee, but sub-par wifi.

I have had experiences with other coffee shops in this area that have better wifi and I expected more from Philz.

I go to coffee shops like this so that I can use the wifi. The coffee is important, but is second to the internet connection. Don't expect to be able to download a podcast in a reasonable amount of time. A 26.6mb This American Life podcast  is going to take another 41 min to download if I stay here that long. The internet comes from ZR Internet Access and gives you a message that goes something like "Use our secure internet (not free) or you can use the free internet, but someone will hack your computer." It is a cheesy up-sell.

Since I have more interneting to do, I am heading to different place for faster internet.
author: Lane L.

description:
Flower Power! This place seemed more hippy groovy than hipster groovy.  .  . a definite throwback to the 60's.   This was my first Philz experience.    The coffee maestros were kind enough to not toss my * out the front door when I ordered a medium coffee.   They did, however, giggle and point to the overhead menu.   A nap on one of the huge, comfy, shabby-chicish couches would have been nice....but they looked kind of hippy dirty.     I love the whirled fresh cream that is spooned on top of the coffee.    

 Very friendly folks!!! 

 Peace, baby!
author: kimberlyn u.

description: This place has an interesting setup. You walk in and to the back of the shop and get in line to wait for your personal barista. The guy I had was really friendly and enthusiastic about their coffee. When my cup was poured he did some crazy trickery with the pour to create some foam and impress me, and it worked, I was impressed -- by him. It's a total dive inside, which seems in SF to somehow translate to posh because a large, black cup of coffee here will run you $5 (it's $4 but when it takes 12 minutes to brew my individual cup and the guy spends 45 seconds pouring I feel like a tip is obligatory). This place really reminds me of another dive cafe establishment I like in Stockholm, except that place is dive because it's trying to attract students, not adults, and it is actually cheap (for that city) matching it's appearance. I have a sample size of 1 but when I went it was not a good spot to sit, chill and work for an hour with your coffee. The tables are meant for parties, the place was packed, and the couches were taken. I can see why locals would come here and hang out for a bit with their coffee but I would not return, despite thinking it's not at all a bad place. The whole experience was...just not worth it.
author: James C.

description:
Places like Philz make me think that I just don't understand humanity.

I've stopped here a handful of times, although not in the past couple of years.  In fact, my most recent visit to a Philz was last year in Palo Alto (mostly because I was so shocked to see it there).

My first couple of visits were entertaining enough, mostly for the crazy "soup nazi" like vibe and wondering what they were going to serve me.  The (mostly female) coffee makers seemed to vaguely worship Phil, who had a guru / eccentric Arab guy shtick working -- how's that for mixing metaphors?

The "handmade" coffee with lots of creme, sugar and a mint leaf was kind of appealing (in a Vietnamese coffee kind of way).  But, it just feels so odd.  The different coffee drinks are all the same, just made with different blends of beans.  They don't roast their own, do they?

The place itself is pretty dirty (I remember noticing a pet bird visiting the place); I was a bit concerned to eat the pastries.  Well, I tried one once.  It wasn't particularly good.

The coffee itself is OK, but the normal drink is mixed with so much cream and it's not really coffee.  I also have to confess, that I usually prefer espresso; hey, that's always made per person.  In terms of coffee quality, you won't confuse Philz with Blue Bottle, Ritual or Barefoot.

Phil seems to have a good mind for business.  Wow, it's surprising that he was able to expand around the bay area.  Are the other locations owned by Phil or are they franchises?  Most of the others do seem cleaner, which is a plus.  And, perhaps serve better coffee as well.

Anyway, Philz is interesting as something different.  If you are in the area (it's a long walk from my home), then it's OK for stopping in.  But, I won't go out of my way.

In the end, I'm a bit surprised that it's become trendy  in the past couple of years (after kicking around for a while).  It seems like the kind of place that Kramer, the hipster doofus, would have raved about.

I don't begrudge Phil for creating his unique place, but I don't understand the popularity.

It's a quiet place; the noise level is low.

p.s.  Are Philz and Blue Bottle polar opposites?  Been noticing that people's opinion of the two chains tend to be positive for one or the other, but not the same for both.  Now, I'm trying to predict people's preferences.  Usually right, but have been wrong at least one.
author: Jice E.

description:
It's hit or miss with this place. Depending on your barista you could real good coffee, or the flavor of a MUNI bumper in your mouth. 

Today I ordered my usual Philharmonic and they put ground up mint in it. At least that's what I think the chunks of material were. 

Be warned, your experience may vary. Walk the extra ten minutes and go to Rituals if you want consistency.
author: D M.

description:
It's a good place for some overpriced filter drip coffee with a bit of show - even if its mechanics are essentially identical to the offerings of any café with a Melita bar these days.

Phil Jabar himself is also a bit of flash, taking the back office labor of Rodger Bories (now running Rodger's Coffee & Tea in the Mission) and slapping on his showmanship as the front of the house. It mostly works, and the coffee is good, albeit not great.

The coffee is mostly fresh-roasted. The challenge comes to all the variants they keep in inventory, so sometimes lots grow older than a couple of weeks and it starts to show in the cup. We've bought some beans for home use and have found the freshness varying from what seems like a week to well over a month.

They are also heavy on darker roasts. And the blends are a bit of wannabe alchemy. In this era of knowing where your food comes from, Philz takes the weird approach of obscuring it with names that seem lifted from Disneyland rides. 

But beware: never order anything besides the filter drip coffee here, or you'll be sorry. We once had an espresso (a real espresso, from an espresso machine, and not the fake espresso "blend" of Philz'), and it was outright dreadful - tasting like the watery, ashy flow out of a dormant volcano.
author: Teddy B.

description: If you like coffee, go to Philz. The one cup at a time strategy can cause long lines, but it's worth it if you're not in a hurry. It's really good. I also really like this location because it's cool, has a great space and plays good music, but doesn't make you feel unwelcome there for being uncool, which I am. The baristas (or whatever they're called here - coffee artists or whatever) are generally very friendly. I generally prefer the medium blends, but everything is great. Just do it, ok?
author: Tom M.

description:
Dear Phil,

I will be straight forward with: I love you. This isn't quite a love letter (sorry to disappoint you), but just my heartwarming feelings towards you.

Your coffee is beyond excellent: brewed to perfection and delicious! 

Although I admit, I was overwhelmed by all the drink selections on the menu, but one day I will conquer them all! The turkish coffee I ordered was strong & full of flavor, just the way I like my coffee! 

Your prices are reasonable for quality coffee, and the service is excellent. I love how each cup of coffee is brewed individually.

This location is a bit small, and can get crowded, but I always think it's worth the wait. Love isn't something you rush right? 

Now if only we didn't have a semi-long distance relationship. If only you were closer to me or on my daily walk to work. But I guess the few times I do get to visit you, it makes it even more special. 

Thanks for keeping my love for coffee alive. 

Love & Coffee Beans,
Cat
author: Catherine O.

description:
Philz on 24th is where good coffee gets poured and where comfort is the name of the game.  This place manages to maintain cred while not being at all pretentious, and that includes the staff.  

Seriously though, I love Blue Bottle, but everything about their decor is sort of warehouse chic and not much like the coffee shops sitcoms informed me throughly about.

Also the coffee is outstanding. Like, even for a jaded coffee person like me.
author: Robert K.

description: Ive been hearing alot about this Mint mojito iced coffee and had to try it myself. Went out of my way to order this to go, def refreshing but not worth the $4 iced coffee.  If you haven't tried this, you must at least order it once! Will be back, only if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Chanel L.

description: i didn't know what i walked into, but my friend is a regular here. but i didn't expect the menu to be something so cute.. but at the same time i had no idea what i was ordering.. i asked the guy what were the difference between two of the drinks and he explained ita ll to me.  if there wasn't a line behind him, i would ask him about everything on the menu. so i ended up ordering the 2nd to the last item on the menu. it turned out to be ok.  the perfect amount of sugar and coffee blend. i wished they had a little menu that would explain all the different coffee blends/flavors they have.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Yes I am aware that this is the same review (almost) that I wrote for the SOMA store but i liked it so much I put it up for you Mission people to enjoy too.  Besides, Philz deserves like 10 stars anyway!

From my heart and for you reading enjoyment, an ode to Philz:
--------------------------------------------------
How I miss Philz,
My heart ever longing.

I wish I could hold,
and sip you my darling.

We will be together again,
this I promise to do.

I wish that everyday
I could enjoy your fresh brew.

Vexed, I miss you,
My stomach's a pit.

Next to Philz...
everything is shit!
--------------------------------------------------

BEST COFFEE EVER!!!!!  (and I do mean ever)

I worked across the street from the store in SOMA for about two years and had a 2 cup a day habit that was kind of like crack.  After I finished the project I was working on, I moved to Seattle (which is supposedly the "home of the coffee shop") and frankly this town is shit-out-of-luck to not have Philz.  Nothing quite holds a candle to their coffee and Ive tried EVERYTHING!!!

Out of all the stores, the vibe at this location is the best...  a must visit for any visitor or local!

Must haves:
1) Turkish
2) Mocha
3) Everything Else

I miss Philz more than you know!!
author: Matthew K.

description:
I was SHOCKED and amazed when, while in San Jose, my friend took me to the new Philz Coffee, and the delightful young "barista" filled me in on the fact that I was not at the second Philz location, and that 24th and Folsom was in fact NOT the only other Philz in the bay area....

my jaw hit the floor.

I've been coming over to this location from Oakland because I love the Ambrosia roast so very very much!  Now that my eyes are open, I may try one of the other locations, but in my eyes, this Phiz is always going to make the BEST coffee and be the BEST coffee-house in the city!

Love you guys :)
author: Jessi K.

description:
Good gosh! O man! This place is by far the best cup of coffee I've every had, let's say coffees because of the great selection! I treat myself to one every time I'm in the SF. All the coffees have been very very very good. My favorite is still the Turkish. I highly recommend you ask for a mint leaf with your cup of Joe... excuse me cup of Philz'! 

You might think it's pretty pricey for a cup of coffee but compared to the espresso/latte type drinks it's pretty reasonable. If you are into an excellent cup of coffee and not really into the latte, frappe froo foo stuff and actually want to taste the coffee this is the place for you!

I got to meet that man himself and he's very friendly and takes the time to talk to his customers.
author: Alexander L.

description:
OK so it's officially been over a month now that I've developed my obsession with Philz. This included visiting 3 different locations in 2 days but we'll get to it later. I'm pretty sure this one obsession is here to stay... thanks to Eric E. and his raves, I've found a new coffee road...

What is up with Ross S. getting some kind of weird service at this one? Maybe I always luck out but I'm always helped by the girl with the dark hair who is just oozing all kinds of positive vibes. Anytime I see a new customer come in, the barista painstakingly goes through the entire list until they find the right one. Always asking me if it tastes right and not being offended if I request just a tiny bit more sugar, so lovely!  OK, maybe I can agree on the cashiers being a little bit indifferent but it's because they didn't put love into my coffee so it's OK.

It was the first location I visited and still the homiest of the now 4 Philz I've been to. Free wireless and I don't feel like people are going to bother me, which is always nice.

I tried the Mocha Tesora first and I have to say that I was blown away when I tasted that coffee with the right mixture of cream (REAL cream! it really limits the weekly intake of Philz... just not the same with any other kind of milk, truly) and sugar. I'm pretty sure I said, "Wow" out loud. Now I'm a Jacob's Wonderbar kind of girl but i still get that same pleasure when I take the first sip. I was never a coffee snob before (and still am not!) but I was drinking enough Philiz to tell the difference when I ventured into tasting the others. Find your love!

I know all the hippies are telling me stop drinking caffeine, that it's bad for me, drink mate, etc etc etc blech but it's just not going to happen. I love my coffee, I love my Manufacturers Cream, I love my Philz, just too damn delicious. And the ritual! Just the ritual of enjoying a hot cup of brew. Ahh...
author: Salina Z.

description: I hear this is the OG Philz. They make me consistently delicious mint mojitos and are conveniently located near the 24th Mission BART. Inside is cozy, which an assortment of dining tables and sofas to sit at. Warning: This is not a good Philz for studying due to the large amount of traffic and the loud music they play on the speakers (go to the one on Van Ness for studying!). Ugh for being so easily distracted...
author: Melody L.

description:
Absolutely the BEST coffee I have EVER had in my life!  It's coffee I love to drink black so it's not polluted with other flavors...  Although, if you love cream and sugar in your coffee, it is also amazing!  I am not a daily coffee drinker, but I love to have some Philz once or twice a week.

When my father-in-law came to visit, he had to walk to Philz on his own one early morning so he could experience a cup along with reading the paper.   He is a coffee addict and truly appreciated Philz.
author: GranolaGorilla Z.

description: I love this place! Great coffee and fantastic staff! :)
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I LOVE PHILZ COFFEE

I work down the street, and after our early morning meetings, a few of us go in to Philz for some thrills!

The people here are amazing, I love all of them.  I am always in a great mood after leaving this place.  I also like how the people who work there get to know their regular customers, so they know JUST how sweet I like my Canopy of Heaven.

I wish I could give them 100 stars.
author: Chelsea S.

description: This is the best cup a joe I've ever had. I still love peets but they have nothing on Philz. I never Used the  word silky to describe coffee before today. If you havent experienced Philz you must. Don't get thrown off by the line-it's worth it!
author: anne m.

description:
I've finally had the opportunity to try coffee from Philz and I am definitely a fan! Hands down the best coffee I could ever have besides brewing myself a cup.

It was confusing walking in for the first time and I didn't know where to start, but everyone was so kind to help me decide on what my tastebuds would like to try. We ended up with a large "Mocha" Tesora. Mmm.. I can still smell the coffee now.
author: Anne T.

description:
3 words: iced mint mojito. 

After smelling the Heavenly scent of Java & seeing the unexpectedly beautiful sign for Philz Coffee, two out-of-towners steered their suitcases into the busy coffeeshop, innocently looking for a decent cup o' joe to prop us back up after a busy day. 

One sip and it was decided: Best Coffee i've ever had in my LIFE. hands down. And i don't say that with little experience. I'm a coffee fiend. Correction, caffeine fiend. I'm trying to cut back from the 3 cups a day to 1. And for that i'm mildly thankful that Philz is on the west coast - otherwise, there'd be trouble.

We asked for the iced mint mojito. The barista was actually EXCITED to make the drink. She said so! She said 'i'm so stoked you ordered that - it's so fun to make!'  

Pause.

I'm sorry, What? A cheerful barista? Dorothy has left Manhattan. er. Kansas.

During our 4 day blitz of SF, my friend and I sent all our co-visitors on a mission to try the coffee at Philz. We all had nothing but love for every cup of coffee made, and more than a lil bit of a desire to hug the wonderfully cheerful Philz peeps for their creations.

Best. Coffee. Ever.
author: Sabeen A.

description:
I don't get it.  We live in the Bay Area, and are surrounded by people and places that care about the provenance of ingredients and the farmers who produce them.  

While everyone doesn't have to seek out micro lots of mountain grown El Salvadorian coffee, or Cup of Excellence Costa Rica, most nameless faceless coffee bought off the block is a commodity that only puts pennies per pound in the farmers pockets.  There are plenty of places in this city that source directly from farmers in coffee growing regions, and pay a fair price for a quality bean.  That being said (sorry Blue Bottle)

Blends are for the weak.

What are these stupidly named blends???? Why can't you tell me what beans are in them???  Or even what they really taste like? "Unicorns drifting through your mind dipped in chocolate and zen" is NOT helpful!


Finally- I AM A GROWN ASS WOMAN AND WANT TO PUT IN MY OWN CREAM AND SUGAR.
author: Kirsten H.

description: Really good strong coffee and friendly atmosphere, but sometimes the coffee is too strong. I always order the blends with the least amount of caffeine and I still get the shakes by the time I hit the bottom of the cup. That said, they have a huge variety of blends so there's always something new to try. The furniture in there is a little dingy, looks like it was all collected from free craigslist ads, but it's all comfy at least. Always a good spot to take visitors to because the single cup brew is a novelty. Overall I really like this place.
author: Taylor M.

description:
BEST coffee EVER.  What a great way to start the day.  Personalized drip coffee made the way YOU like it.  I went here for my first time today, and I never knew my coffee experience could taste so wonderful and enjoyable.  

I got a large-sized Tesora (medium roast) made slightly sweet (with cream and sugar).  DELICIOUS.  It's not commercialized, gives you an-SF, quaint, coffeehouse experience and is pooch-friendly.  

Small for a little over $2.50 and a large for $3.00 or so.
author: Sunny S.

description: Small black tesora, please! Love the handcrafted nature of each cup of coffee, makes me feel better about buying a $3 drip. The aura is sooooo "SF"....soooo "the mission". They have straight up garage sale type of seating and tables in there (and a pew for the people waiting for their coffee, hahaha) with people studying, homeless folk coming in and getting kicked out, people people watching. It's a nice and very typical SF cafe. Def want to try their other blends.
author: Alex R.

description:
Once upon a time I wandered into Philz looking for a cup of coffee. I found myself completely overwhelmed by the 20+ roasts to choose from! Each bean having a description that seems more fitting of a wine list than a coffee shop. That's when I knew I'd reached coffee heaven! It does exist! 

I stepped up to the counter and asked for a recommendation. Little did I know that my coffee was being made by Phil himself! He asked me if this was my first time in. When I confirmed this he said "we are going to steal you away from your favorite coffee shop!" And then asked me if I wanted cream or sugar in my coffee! I just about fell over in shock! A variety of beans to choose from, hand-brewed one cup at a time, cream & sugar added for you, fresh mint in your coffee, yummy baked goods and free wifi! It's too good to be true!

After living in Portland for five years I consider myself a bit of a coffee shop snob and am rarely impressed. But Phil & his wonderful team of super friendly baristas truly impressed me. 

P.S. Phil - you were absolutely right, I think I've been back everyday since!
author: Marissa P.

description: Philz is great coffee, I had to start getting it delivered to my place when I moved back to Boston. I had their iced Mint Mojito coffee almost everytime I visit. Not much to say here that hasn't been sad before.
author: Michael C.

description: Amazingly delicious coffee and I love that you get fresh mint, and that they put your cream and sugar in for you.
author: Tiffanae L.

description:
"That motherf@#ker made the shit out of my coffee!"

For the purposes of this review, I changed the original Louis CK line to the slightly less offensive "Motherf@#ker," but the theme is the same. I've never had a cup of coffee made with such pride. The coffee artist put his love into my coffee, although not literally as that would be gross. When dude passed me the coffee, he said "let me know how that is for ya."

Well to answer your question Mr. Coffington, it was god-damned delicious for me. Good show old sport. Good show indeed.
author: N S.

description:
These motherfuckers put crack in my coffee!

Now i'm feenin' for their drinks...catching the BART from Oakland to The Mission for a hit.

I can't stop itching....until i feel the sensation of their ambrosia embrace my lips.

I'm addicted...to what this shit did....
author: Dennis A.

description: I really enjoy the atmosphere, located in sunny mission/ folsom. The baraista is certainly not in any rush. She is the sweetest! I ordered hot chocolate, and she asked how sweet? I didn't know, so only made it regular. When i got my drink; she asked me to try it and make sure its sweet enough. It was not, she offered to add more sugar, and once again had me tasted it before I walked away. Awesome-NESS
author: Monika T.

description:
It is possible to experience great service and get a great cup of coffee for a low price. Here's my breakdown:
Peet's: Great service, fair coffee, mid-prices
Starbucks: Fair service, lousy coffee, mid-prices
Dunkin' Donuts: Lousy service, lousy coffee, low prices.
Finally...
Philz: Snooty, arrogant, slow, rude services, great coffee, high prices.

I get it, you make your coffee from scratch and put love into each cup. However, I get less coffee and 4 times the order time as a competitor. And, when I go to Peet's the baristas don't make me feel like a bonehead for asking if I get get an espresso. Plus, the barrista doesn't take time to shake the milk for 2 minutes (shaking milk? Huh?) or periodically take sips from his own coffee while he's preparing mine. Plus, Peet's doesn't cost $3.25 for a 12-ounce cup of iced coffee.

I like a great cup as much as the next guy, and Peet's is a great cup. But, arrogant employees doesn't exactly brighten my morning. Philz wouldn't make it in any city other than San Francisco, a place where lousy service and high prices are tolerated for something deemed by the Mission masses to be cool.
author: Ross S.

description:
Before I moved to my current location, less than a block away from Philz, I wasn't really a coffee drinker or a caffeine addict.  I was somewhat smug in my caffeine-free status and probably deserved to be cut down to size.  
Now I'm kind of a Philz addict.

I like the Ambrosia, the Silken Splendor, the Canopy of Heaven and the iced coffee Mint Mojito.  

I like the staff, and the ambience.  Sometimes I go here to get work done.  Often I get a cupcake. I read the flyers on the noticeboard.  I chuckle at the idea of somebody paying $50 for a Philz fedora.  This place has a lovely neighborhood feel. 

It makes me feel warm and fuzzy.
author: Jane F.

description:
GREAT coffee and fabulous location. You can read about all the types of coffee and what exactly they will taste like.. its kinda like wine tasting? The flavor comes FROM THE BEAN with nothing added. This totally enchanted me. Get with cream and sugar for best flavor.

Location was huge, lots of interesting things to look at and lots of space to spread out and study if needed!
author: Sirina K.

description: They serve the BEST coffee I've tasted.  Love Turkish with light cream and sugar. They also have the best Baklavas.  Not too sweet compare to others.
author: MT D.

description: The line goes quick, though you will still have to wait for your cup of brew.  Each drip coffee is made fresh by the multiple excellently friendly and helpful baristas. Yup, they don't drip it till you order it, so unless the owner figures out how to create super gravity  to make the water pick up the goodness and drip into the cup faster, the time per cup is pretty fixed. This gives you plenty of time to take in the  laid back atmosphere and chat up the cutie next to you or figure what fashion trend to steal.
author: Lams L.

description:
Philz has become part of my life, as the mister is quite addicted. I must admit, even though I drink coffee, I don't necessary love the taste but Philz coffee is straigt up delicious. I'm in love with the "Turkish" blend. It's really sweet, creamy and yummy. I love how they add fresh mint in each cup, too. Great touch. The workers are super, super friendly and helpful. Baristas are out-of-this-world friendly and chipper. I've been to other locations but the Mission location has a lot of personality and charm, it's my favorite.  Lots of friendly characterts, it feels like a small town coffee shop in there. If my life was that show "Friends," Philz would be my Central Perk.

But BEWARE...each cup is jam-packed with caffeine so keep that in mind. I'm not sensitive to caffeine at all but several hours after drinking half a cup, i noticed that my hand was shaking in a meeting. I found it amusing.
author: Hanan H.

description:
Even though it's a (local) chain, I like this particular Philz.  Aside from the "handmade cup of coffee" thing (and I like dealing with the actual person who makes my cup for some reason, rather than just a cashier), they have something like 20+ types of beans to choose from.  So the fact that's a bit more expensive than comparable coffee places seems justifiable; more labor-intensive.  I also really enjoy being able to be totally un-self conscious in a place that has a lot of beat-up couches, empty and full cardboard boxes strewn around, arguably no identifiable decor, and a generally unpretentious environment that also has wifi.

The only discordant thing is the numerous tributes to the SFPD and SFFD around the space, like the wall of hanging SFFD t-shirts and an encomium to the SFPD officers "who make our city a better place to live," which I found somewhat weird and preachy -- not exactly something that everyone can heartily embrace without some qualifications.  Get rid of those, add a star.
author: moosedog i.

description:
BEST Cup of Coffee on the planet. Each year, I travel from the east coast to San Francisco and each year I experience caffeinated bliss at Philz. Love the coffee, Love the staff, and love working with you guys!! 

See you in August in the park!!

Zack W.
Philadelphia, PA
author: Zack W.

description: Great Coffee!!!   Love my Tesora hot and the pastries are all great!  Crazy to find parking but I enjoy the envirnment when I come here.  You can catch Phill talking to the clients outside at times and the staff are all super great and fast.  Lines move quick and always busy.
author: Ray of L.

description:
I've never been here before. It's all the rage, and the inner hipster in me said I should go try it out. Of course it's ironic because I don't drink coffee, BUT, I do drink tea and I was happy to see there was tea on the menu!

I got in the long line, and waited. While I waited, I was trying to figure out how the ordering process went. I saw people getting called up one by one, kind of like they were at the DMV and chatting it up with the barrista. I then saw this interesting character with a fancy mustache and fedora, which by then I realized that paintings of him were all over the wall. My attention turned to one of the paintings that had the name Phil on it. I put two and two together as to who that was. Of course, I wasn't helped by Phil, but I was helped by this lovely man who made a joke about what I wanted in my tea ("so you want green, and you want tea in it"), and asked me if I wanted mint in it. I said why not. I also went back to him quickly after I ordered and asked him how I pay and how I would get my drink (it was my first time) and he was really nice about it and explained the whole process, such as how they do a tasting process (very cool!) but since it's tea and it's super hot, I wouldn't be able to do it right away. Yet, I still went back and forth and asked how I would know my tea was ready. Yes... I was THAT customer for the day. When I finally got my tea, I have to say that I really liked it. The mint gave it a nice flavor. I feel like the $2.50 I spent was well spent. 

There isn't really much a tea drinker can do here at Philz, but, I think at some point I will have to try the coffee here. I also think at some point I will attack the pastry display, because everything looked delicious!
author: Caroline L.

description:
For my first post I have got to go with Philz:

Before tasting a sip of Philz coffee I was convinced that noticeable difference in coffee quality did not exist- how Phil proved me wrong...

Each blend is different from the rest, and superior to any other coffee I have tried.  Since moving to the city, introducing visiting friends and family to Philz has been a must!

Stop by when you get a chance, enjoy the friendly warm atmosphere created by the employees who believe in the product they sell, and be ready for a short wait if you slide in during the rush hour.  

Relatively pricey, but worth it nonetheless!
author: Noah A.

description: Incredible coffee. Great service.   I began chatting with a real cool dude outside the the store one day. Turns out it was Phil himself. He has a true passion for coffee and was incredibly friendly. The place is inspiring.
author: Tanner B.

description:
The silken smooth is on point. Hand dripped to perfection.

They use whole cream - no half and half. And real sugar. I'm certain you could get the artificial stuff here too.
author: Judy L.

description:
I have been going to this place for almost a year now and felt that I owed them something else besides the a standard tip. The coffees are definitely great (even though I only order the Ether), but the Baristas are the best thing about the place. Regardless of the time of day (generally I am there right when they open), they are genuinely friendly and pretty damn fun(ny).

They are not only kind to me, but every time I bring someone over there from out of town, they treat them with endearment. My out of town visitors always enjoy themselves too.

Order and rules tend to be absent, but the crowd is reflective of a base that enjoys this level of randomness. 

So, cheers to the team of Philz because they can change my mood in an instant.
author: Pico S.

description:
I felt like a coffee pilgrim making a trip to my caffienated house of worship.....!!

This shop is very homey (cluttered furniture, music, rustic interior) compared to its Berkeley shop, but very much an enjoyable experience. 

A pleasant surprise was the red velvet mini cupcake (from Mission Mini's) that I purchased to accompany my drink! 

Hoooorray for Philz!!!
author: Hilda Z.

description:
Their Mocha Tesora is the BEST Mocha I've ever had. They give you the option of not so sweet, slightly sweet, or sweet. I always go with not so sweet and it's just rich cocoa chocolate. Love it. 

I wish there was a Philz closer to my neighborhood though!
author: vicki c.

description:
This is a coffee house in the tradition of fine coffee houses.  The coffee is really good, and packs a kick.  The baristas are friendly and fun to talk to (unless the place is super busy).  The decor is run-down living room and dining room rolled into one.  What more could one want?

The coffee is made one cup at a time, and the barista will sit and talk with you about what you're looking again.  To get this experience, you'd best avoid the super busy times (like mornings).

It's a great place to hang out, read a book or fiddle on your laptop.  Wireless is available.

This is where all the fireman come to hang out, so you can sit outside and watch them try to park the fire trucks out front ... if that's your thing.
author: Douglas P.

description:
Philz Coffee is unequivocally man's greatest achievement. 

Their drinks have reached new heights of deliciousness previously unbeknownst to coffee snobs. 

They are an San Francisco institution. 

Phil himself is a legend.

They are often busy, and they brew each cup individually, so be sure to make enough time to get your coffee when so desire (this ain't Starbucks).
author: Adam B.

description:
don't believe the hype people, this place is nowhere near best in the world...

I actually went in here on a hunt for ritual which according to yelp was on the corner.  as I watched all the pomp and showmanship I wondered at the mint leaves.  maybe my "Turkish" won't have that, but it did.  

I found a table off in the corner and sat down. sipping the brew all I could think was this is the usual deli brew.  not burnt or anything but not world class coffee.  then I smelled a funny smell.  the idea of a cat popped into my head, but I thought nothing of it.  as I setup my Internet I thought, gee that odd effulance smells strangely like what a cat might leave behind.  I sniffed some more & it got stronger.  I peered behind the chair & there was indeed a pile of something & I quickly grabbed my bag & moved.  I surfed & surfed.  yelp reviews claimed there was a ritual spot on this corner, but I could not find it. I checked the site & found Haus.  I then hit yelp again and realized that was the place!!  without thinking, almost by instinct I darted out the door tossing my wonderous philz brew. I was then crossing 2lanes of 24th st traffic & Folsom at the same time!!  it was then I finally eyed haus!
author: Sean S.

description: So glad that this is now part of my life. Philtered Soul was my recommendation from the barista and man was she right! I came here after lunch with my coworker after traveling all day from the east coast. I wasn't feeling the best and this coffee literally brought me back to life. It was delicious and smooth. Luckily I can order online :)
author: Rachel G.

description:
This Philz is located just a few blocks from my new apt, and so far its made me:
1) incredibly happy
2) super caffeinated and,
3) damn poor if I go too often

All that aside.. I enjoy Philz because the coffee is just delicious. Forget Starbucks.  I'm sure its been said 500x already, but each cup is made separately and each "flavor" is a blend Phil created himself (whom I saw during my last visit there and felt slightly star struck)! 

The coffees are bold, aromatic, earthy and full of flavor.  A few of my favs are the turkish, jacobs wonderbrew and mocha tesora.  There are still soooo many more to explore, and I have my handy-dandy Philz Coffee iPhone App to help me keep track of which I've tried/liked/disliked.....

5/5. My mom and grandma from out of town even loves Philz.
author: Jennie L.

description:
After our friend took us here on our last trip out to SF, we're forever spoiled for good coffee. 

Their mocha- supreme. It is actually unsweetened (as in no added sugar), which seems normal on the west coast from our experience, but us Eastern Coasters have to deal with overly sugary espresso drinks all the time. The coffee has a good variety and their Philharmonic is nicely balanced, especially with sugar/milk added.

The other drink I got was their Turkish coffee, which is the best I've had since I visited Greece in 2003. And yes, I know, don't kill me for that comparison. 

I'd say the system for ordering is weird, but it seems to work really well for them. I found myself waiting an appropriate amount of time for freshly made coffee, and not ever having to hustle or feel rushed, or crushed, despite the obvious busy popularity during breakfast rush.

Tasty donuts, as well, and their baklava was delicious. A fine repast to accompany the fine coffees.
author: Evan J.

description:
Ahhhhhhh, Philz. 
I finally had to write a review, although mine is the same as most of the others.
I usually get mocha tesora or Jacob's wonderbar, which taste creamy and smooth like a yummy mocha but without the actual chocolate and all the cream. I get mine with soy, and it is still fab. Today, I wanted to try something different but still nutty. The super kind and knowledgeable barista recommended the Philtered Soul, which is a dark roast. I took his advice, along with his recommended amount of soy and sugar, and it was so yummy!
This place is a little pricey, for sure, but so worth the price and the time it takes to wait for a freshly brewed custom made cup of artisan coffee.
Philz, I love you.
author: Lisa E.

description: Ordered the Tesora blend. Best coffee I've had. Full, flavorful, deep, complex -- drink it while its hot. Oh and I know not many people talked about the food, but the pastries were delicious! I had vegan donuts and croissants and both were absolutely splendid. Croissant was soft and flaky. The Vegan donut wasn't excessively sweet like traditional donuts.  Also, the baristas and employees are super nice and helpful. Tipped them both times.
author: Htown Y.

description:
Having visited the Mission Bay location in the past, I knew the deal with Philz was making really damn good strong coffee to your specific tastes. However, one thing I would get picky on with this location is that I had no flipping idea what any of the coffees were, and I felt embarrassed to ask the baristas about each and every one in order to get a feel for which one would suit my tastebuds on a hangover Sunday. Instead, I ended up picking the Arabian coffee partially out of panic, partially because I had never had Arabian coffee before... so in a way, lack of detail was my friend... although it could have been my enemy too. 

Once I got to the counter to order, I saw the different pots of beans, I realised I had picked a dark coffee roast, not normally my choice. Oh well, too late now. 

The end result was a strong coffee with some bitter notes, but it was a really damn good cup of coffee. I also had a bunch of cream thrown in there to take some off the astringency out of the flavour, which was a first for me, as I don't normally use cream. The result was a decadent coffee that helped set me on the path of salvation, supported by an ice cream dessert at Humphrey Slocombe.

Incidentally, felt like while we were trying to decide, there was no where to stand so kept bumping into customers while the baristas kept offering to serve us. It's a bit of an awkward place to stand... until I saw the bench. Feels like I was in a bit of a coffee shop etiquette lesson. It was hipsterville too, so I felt very much out of place. But the cafe itself is lovely. Definitely could see people whiling away hours here. Not me, I can't really sit in one place too long, but it definitely looked like a major couples hangout.
author: Catriona C.

description:
So I keep hearing about Philz coffee and had to try it. We got the Turkish coffee and Sumatra. It was good but not great?! I was confused. Maybe I need to try more coffee places around the bay so I can compare. 
(I guess your have to be good if a local famous ice cream joint makes your coffee into ice cream....so does Philz have ice cream flavors elsewhere?) 

The people working here were really nice though...I wanted to try a Nabolom danish but the girl burned it so she gave us baklava on the house and it was quite good.
