I do have to say that there were flavors in my coffee I had never tasted before...slightly floral and spicy. Perhaps coffee connoisseurs can taste notes in coffees like a sommelier? I must've ordered the wrong things so I will probably try Philz upon another visit to the city.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
What a momentous occasion, my 500th review on a day I find a coffee place that is bomb!  

I do not drink coffee, but after this wonderful aroma and taste of Philz coffee hit my tongue I do now.  The experience of receiving your slow food movement coffee, brewed one cup at a time, was memorable.  However, the most IMPORTANT thing is the coffee bean and you can tell, unless you have the pallet of a fish, then I feel sorry for you.  The service was friendly, attentive, and they know what they are doing.  The Mocha Tesoro, Iced, is what I had slightly sweetened.  I was very happy with my selection and would gladly recommend it to my fellow friends and yelp readers.
author: Po L.

description: This place is pretty much unbeatable.  The coffee is amazing, the ambiance is laid back and unpretentious, and it seems like people from all walks of life in the neighborhood frequent the shop.  It's really nice when an establishment in a diverse area can appeal to so many different folks.  Also the people watching from the benches out front is second to none.  I've been to lots of Philz locations, and always love them, but this one is special.  A great place to take really your time and enjoy your coffee and conversation, and watch the world go by while you enjoy your java with fresh mint and love.
author: David B.

description:
love love love it!

This place is wonderful, enough said!  The coffee is brewed one cup at a time, and you get to taste test to make sure you are satisfied and that it is just the way you like it!

I have to say that my wife and I make this an every other sunday ritual.  You will not be disappointed unless you catch someone on an off day... but give it another go with an open mind if that happens.  It deserves it!
author: Wel S.

description:
I wish I could give Philz a whopping 5 stars because their coffee kicks a lot of ass, but some especially scenester-tastic baristas can be a little snooty with their coffee-making.  And if you ever had the misfortune of trying to get a cup of coffee during peak hours on weekends, it's like a mad house.  I wish they could come up with a better system, or maybe there should just be more room for people to stand while they wait.

That said, Phil and his scenester minions can definitely make a cup of coffee.  Ambrosia is excellent if you want something on the sweeter side.  And the decaf Swiss Water is delicious!  

There are old, comfy couches to sit on, free wifi, and it's good for some people watching.  Almost forgot, their vegan donuts are delectable (try the purple one).  And the gluten-free lavenders cookies are baked there for your chewing pleasure.  Can't get much better than that!
author: Lauren B.

description: Iced mint mojito always refreshing and makes me happy!
author: Larry L.

description: Like I need to say it. Philz is chillz.  Laid back but structured.  Baristas are great and coffee was awesome.  I'd have no need for Starbuck's in my life if only I lived closer to Phil.
author: Jason N.

description: Best coffee ever! The New Manhattan, Ether, Code 33, or any of the unique bean blends that Philz creates are truly awesome. No wonder why when I discovered Philz he had three locations and now I believe 14 locations including Stanford and Berkeley. A real unique San Francisco treat.
author: Dennis E.

description:
Thought I'd make my first Philz Coffee visit to the original Mission store even though there's one a couple blocks away from me in the Civic Center area.  In any case, I have only good things to say.

The coffee is good.  I tried to order an iced mocha tesora as was recommended in another yelp review, but as I wanted it not so sweet with just a bit of cream, the extremely nice barista suggested I just get an iced coffee with a touch of cream and sugar (which she recommended I at least try).  She also held my order to let me try it and she could remake it if it were too sweet.  Well, it was perfect.  And she was awesome!

The prices are great, the coffee is great, and the service was great.  Although it was pretty full, there were still places to sit.

Thumbs up for the original Philz location.  Time to try my local.
author: Timothy Y.

description:
Each cup of Joe is individually dripped to order.  Arabica beans, Hazelnut beans, what you like?  We got it! 
I told the nice lady around what I wanted, and she made me a mix that was to perfection!  Thanks! 

And they mix the combustion with their "special saucy sauce sweet cream" to top it off! yahoo....sipping on it now!

OOOOOhh and the Baklavah...was actually good!  Light, not too sweet, and fluffy...um....YUM!
author: Stephanie W.

description: I've always wanted to try other coffees, but for some reason, always resorted to my usual - mint mojito or ginger snap iced coffees. I hate change, but finally had enough guts to try the mocha tesora! And it was perfect. The beautiful blend of coffee and dark chocolate worked so well, resulting in a very rich, smooth and satisfying drink. Available iced, just ask :)
author: Cindy T.

description:
Today, I went on a date with a super cool fella this afternoon who just raved and raved and raved about this place.  Our first meeting was over a small cup of coffee called "ether" with cream and honey...at Philz this afternoon.  Well... this guy knows a good cup of coffee (so I am totally impressed). The coffee maker lady behind the counter was super nice and asked me if she needed to adjust the taste after I took my first sip of my order!  WOW!  now that's service... she totally scored my date major points!   Who knows if there will be a second or third date with this fine fella?  Wherever it goes, I know he's made me a convert to Philz coffee... and I will be back to try more cups of coffee there!

To add, my date oriented me to the science of Philz... supposedly, there's a way how to order, how to get out of the way when the order is made, etc... The one or two stars must come from patrons who may have probably gotten sneers and jeers from other customers (or from behind the counter for not" reading the situation well"... although, the folks behind the counter where just so super nice.., maybe I was just lucky---it was sunny outside (which was a nice change from the SF ICE AGE Summer Weather)... so maybe that's why everyone was so friendly at Philz.  Who knows, I may have gotten the sneers and jeers if I had not gotten proper orientation or if I came on an icy day that turn san franciscans into icy people (whoops, sorry native san franciscans...i mean mean east coast transplants).  Anyhow, I will definitely be back to Philz !
author: Alex D.

description:
The coffee here is like no other!

The first time you go to Philz you tell them the type of coffee you like and you get an explanation of the different sorts they have.  I normally go for the Ambrosia or Ether.

They take time making each individual cup of coffee with such care and precision - you cannot rush the process of creating a divine, crack-like cup of coffee.

The staff all seem super chilled out, the decor is equally chilled (a bunch of old mismatched sofas and tables clumped together) the music has always been awesome when I've been here (they play everything from Devo to Bjork) and the general vibe is comfortable...what the heck do they put in that cofffee...?!

Within a few blocks walking distance from my beloved St Francis Fountain, you can wander down here and let the coffee and couches lull you from your food coma into a caffeine daze.

Perfect place to read a book whilst savouring a deliciously fresh brew and munching on a half peanut/half chocolate collision cookie.
author: Melanie B.

description: Definitely an over-hyped place. They claim to have authentic Turkish style coffee. However, I brought my good friend whom is a foreign exchange student from Turkey here in Cali to try their coffee. He directly said, "This is not Turkish coffee". My friend and I gave this place multiple tries. We had the drip and Mojito. Both of us didn't like it. Personal preference I guess, seeing all these great reviews.
author: Aaron H.

description:
Great coffee.  A little awkward to order if you never been there before - you order a drink from the baristas and then go to the cashier to pay later.
We ordered the tarosa which is their "standard" coffee.  First sip was awesome- no bitterness, mildly sweet, loads of flavor.  Be warned though that the barista puts creams and sugar for you, so don't expect to pour your own.
author: Nolan Z.

description: Was not impressed. I ordered the iced mojito, waited 15 minutes while the barista I ordered it with forgot my order and then nonchalantly whispered it to a barista so it could get made. The ordering process is completely unapparent, unless you're like me and learned about it through Yelp reviews. The baristas are just a bunch of snobby hipster doofuses. Coffee was super sweet and reminded me of crappy Starbucks, and just as expensive. Something like $5 for a small cup of sugary "coffee" spiked with mint syrup and a ton of mint leaves. Logo looks like it was designed by the Insane Clown Posse.  Total BS.
author: Catface G.

description:
What can one say about Philz that hasn't been said before?  I mean, there are only so many ways to express 'OMG, that coffee was so effing good I'd sell my children for just one more cup,' you know?

But I love a challenge, so I'm gonna give it a shot anyway.  Here goes:

A few months ago, I was minding my own business working as a corporate lawyer on Wall Street, which, being located in New York, is frustratingly far from the nearest Philz location.  Anyway, like most of my colleagues, I was making bank, but hating life.  

However, I had this dream of ditching it all and moving to the Bay.  Which seemed like a great idea except for the minor hitch that I had neither a job, nor a license to practice law in California, which would render my hard-earned Ivy League law degree more or less worthless.  Undeterred, I decided to make a list of reasons to move to CA.  And sure, there are cool people and beautiful landscapes and giant redwoods and all that, but the thing on the very tip-top of my list was Philz Coffee.  I used to lie awake at night in Brooklyn wondering if I would ever again taste the bracing, seductively mint-laced, creamy, caffeinated goodness embodied in a cup of Philz iced coffee.

Finally one day, June 17, 2009 to be exact, I walked into a partner's office and quit my job.  I packed up all my junk, found a place in Berkeley, bought a one-way plane ticket, and here I am.

Yesterday, I went to Philz and fulfilled my dream for $3.25 (plus tip, natch).  It was totally worth it.
author: Katie S.

description:
I'd been to the Philz location in the Castro a few times, but never really "got it" until I visited this one.  I was startled to learn that they don't have lattes.  But the bartender (coffee tender?  they really do create the beverages so it's more like bartending than barista-ing) said she could make something that tasted like a latte.  

It wasn't until I abandoned my preconceptions about what coffee should be and embraced the Philz tradition that I truly savored my new favorite coffee drink.  

Once I had their Turkish coffee, blended according to my specifications, I was in love with Philz.  That, and the fact that the cafe is so unimpressed with itself.  It looks like the type of place, at first glance, that would try hard to create an image, but the truth is that they haven't tried at all.  

They just are.  And it's great.  The furniture is kind of strewn around, not because someone tried to make it look that way, but because it probably was just thrown together when they opened the location.  It's comfortable.  The bathroom is decent, and they have a selection of refrigerated beverages for any of you eschewing the caffeinated chance of a lifetime to try something new.  The music selection is good and not overly intrusive.  

Bagels and pastries are available; they toasted my bagel and put just the right amount of cream cheese on it.  I enjoy the Turkish coffee so much (it's #2 on their posted menu) that I haven't gotten further down their menu!  

All the more reason to go back.
author: Diana G.

description: Great strong coffee. Friendly staff, and Phil is a cool guy to meet. Always at the Mission shop Saturday mornings when i go there.
author: Ed O.

description: One of my favorite coffee houses in mission. I'm not a huge coffee fan, but I have to say their coffee is top notch. Oh, and did I mention they also sell Peeples vegan donuts?
author: Priscilla M.

description:
I lived a couple of blocks from Philz Coffee in 2002(ish). Getting coffee from Phil on my way to work always made my day -- perhaps because it made me INCREDIBLY caffeinated.  He always made me taste the coffee before I paid and gave me a quarter or two off the list price.  I felt so special.

Philz has now become something of an institution and he has several locations, but his delicious hand-crafted coffee is still my favorite.  

I suggest a small turkish with whole milk and medium sugar (with cream if you're feeling crazy!).  Yum!
author: Jennie R.

description:
I love Philz but feel compelled to offer up my bad experience as a cautionary tale. The seating area is REALLY packed. Like, you pretty much have to shove past people, bump their chairs and generally cause chaos to get to an open seat. And even then, you're about 2 inches from your neighbors.

So last time I was at Philz, I was working on my laptop (as most people at Philz are), and my friend moved his laptop. Unfortunately my full, un-lidded coffee was next to it, and this caused it to knock over, spilling about half a cup of coffee into my work laptop. I still go to Philz to read a book or hang out with friends, but when I have to do work I take my (new) laptop to Haus.
author: Anonymous F.

description:
Epic. EPIC. Orgasmic, truly.

Perfection in a cup. Almost too good. Is that possible?

Some have tried to argue that Blue Bottle is better. Blue Bottle is good but Philz is other-wordly.

Try the Philharmonic w/cream and sugar.
author: Faith S.

description:
Philz, Mr. Phil, Amazing Wonderful Baristas and such, I love your coffee.

I used to treat myself to a large Tesora on the way out of town. Not only did this incredible coffee pack a caffeinated punch that could have shot me to the moon, but it was a delectably bitter treat. A garnish of freshly picked mint rounds out this dreamy cup. Well, since living in the bay area, I haven't treated myself nearly as well, forgetting that the best cup in town is still at Philz. And then, I went for an iced coffee, and the memories came rushing back. 

Cream and sugar exactly how I like it, a sprig of fresh mint, strong, sultry, bitter, deeply flavored individual drip cups. It's a simple concept, at simple prices, with astounding results. And I couldn't be happier every time I have a cup of Philz in my hand.
author: Shannon F.

description:
I had a great Turkish coffee here. The guy and the gal baristas working when I was there were both really sexy. The coffee and Iced tea were delicious. The location is lovely, in the Mission, on a street populated with leafy trees. There seemed to be interesting dive bars and taqerias and other coffee shops in the area.

There are some benches outside on the sidewalk with some potted plants. Really great atmosphere. Huge windows on two sides so you can sit and chat and drink your coffee and watch people go by on the street from the confines of a comfy chair... or I suppose you could hideaway in the corner away from the windows and read a book or write your thesis or send erotic emails to you lover.

Plenty of beautiful people to look at, coming and going here.
author: David K.

description:
Ok, so I have had their coffee. HOLY MACKEREL. Completely changed my coffee experience. I don't crave coffee, but I DO crave Philz coffee. I usually take my coffee black, but here... cream and sugar is a YES, yes yes.

The flavors are robust, distinct, and satisfying. If you  have ever scoffed at other coffee places claiming to have "nutty" "fruity" "earthy" coffees, you will change your mind here. Their coffees really do have flavors.
author: Donna K.

description:
Wow.
Best coffee in town. No doubt about it.

I can't believe I've only discovered Philz this year. And I haven't even been to their other locations.

I should also mention that the staff is very friendly and helpful. They take pride in the awesome coffees they serve.
author: Evan A.

description:
Pros

The coffee's good. My first cup there was phenomenal. It had the PERFECT amount of cream and sugar. How'd you know, sez I?  I just read you, sez she. But I haven't tried the house coffee yet.

Each cup is individually strained. Takes about a second longer. But since there's no extra cream/sugar/stirrer space bottleneck -- that's at the cashier -- and with more than one coffee "maker" on duty they dispatch long lines of customers that can curve around out to the sidewalk in a reasonable time. It's a different model than Starbucks' but they let staff dress and act normally.  They all look really smart too, which is important when you're getting coffee, right? 

The layout inside is OK.

Philz allows non-customers to use the bench outside during street events like fairs, Carnaval and the Food fest. This is what you call being a good neighbor. 


Cons

Pricey, at maybe $3.75 a cup for non-small, non-house, non-Fair Trade coffee. Their prices are not prominently displayed on their website either.

Some people like to add their own cream & sugar.  Only my first cup was perfect but they'll tune it up for you.

I don't like the guy in the hat.  Is this outgoing, gregarious personality Phil?  He told me he was the owner. Next time he said he wasn't. Which is it? Once he let someone walk around me with their coffee and pay in front of me.  Police, first responders, Muni, DPT ?  .. all cool. But someone in civvies, without an explanation?  Not cool. 

3 stars, after a 1/2-point deduction for schizophrenia and lack of line management. Rounded off (truncated) instead of rounding "up" from 3-1/2. Not ready to say Yay, I'm a Fan just yet. Too bad, because the coffee preparers are all nice. 

Yelp powers, how do you go from a 2, Experienced Better, to a 3, A-OK? This is a quantum leap.  How about a mediocre or average rating?
author: Robert F.

description:
BEST COFFEE EVER. I'm total coffee snob, not addict, I drink for the taste not the addiction. 

They have 20+ different kinds of roast, not flavored beans (like hazelnut, pumpkin, raspberry, ew...) Every roast has their own characteristics, taste, and their own fans. Ask the barista for recommendation if it's your first couple times here. They are usually very knowledgeable and helpful. They add cream and sugar in for you, and I always ask for light cream no sugar so I could taste the beans. 

If you have a sweet tooth, the mint mojito iced coffee, HEAVENLY on a hot day! And mocha tesora is to die for on a cold day! 

This location has the most interesting and authentic character. Love it!
author: Yuchi C.

description:
When I was a young girl hangin' in La Mision I was in love with one of my best friend's boyfriend's brothers.  He was old school Latino.  He was older and he was cool in my young girl eyes.  I always tagged along with my friend as she was a guera dating a cholo who lived in the middle of the Mission.  I went as a bodyguard of sorts and most importantly to make google-y eyes at the brother.  He made google-y eyes back at me but told me I was too young for him.  That did not deter me.  He worked on cars a lot as he was an expert in hydraulics and it was the era of low riders.  I "helped" him whenever I could.  Not being much help as my eyes were only on him.  I had it bad.

One day my friend's boyfriend took me aside and said:

"Mamita, stay away from my brother.  He's a chipper."

"What is a chipper?"

"A non-addicted heroin user."

I watched all the after school specials.  I saw Born to Win.  I thought that if you even looked at heroin sideways, you were a junkie.   I didn't understand.

"It's inevitable that my brother will go from chipper to junkie."

I was heartbroken.  Lainie don't mess with junkies. . .so thus ended my mad,  passionate schoolgirl crush.  

What the hell am I mucho blah blah-ing about?  

Well. . long story short (ha!) I find that I am chippin' on Philz.    In the Heroin Users guide, the general chipping rule is 72 hours in between hits.  Which is about where I am with Philz.  Since they are all the way in the city, I can't easily score my fix and the chipping rule is firmly intact.  

My fix of choice:  Philtered Soul.  Coffee with a velvet chocolate undertone.  My eye is twitching as I write that.  Chippin' is a hard road.  Yesterday, the pusher. . I mean brewer informed me that you can get Philtered Soul mocha style with just a small amount of chocolate added to the mix.   twitch, twitch. . twitch, twitch.   The secret to Philz is the roasting and the fact that when you get cream in your coffee they don't trifle with 1/2 & 1/2 - hell no. . this is primo Grade A stuff. . they bust out the Manufacturing Cream which is higher fat cream.  Hell yes!  

Apparently, Philz will be opening a dealing house in the East Bay soon. . .
chipper to junkie. . .it's inevitable.
author: Lainie L.

description:
I try to like this place, for their location (block and half away from my house) and their admirably extensive list of individual cups of coffee you can get. That being said, there are reasons why I don't like this coffee shop at all. 

First off, the baristas know phil'z coffee and phil'z customers but fail to understand coffee customers of other kinds. This is not the type of coffee shop where you can pour your own cream and sugar, which I don't since I take my coffee black. Ok, so I order black, and every time I do, the barista says, "Really? No cream, no sugar? Ughhh... OK?" Yes, OK, please don't question me, that's what I ordered. And it has happened before when the barista felt it was alright to slip in a piece of mint on their own doing. The barista has also told me to cheer up, smile, and that made me even more put off. I don't go get coffee for cult like attitude, and certainly not for some hyper happy behind a counter to give me life advice. Not normal coffee shop behavior.  

Secondly, annoying people sit around Phil'z. I think this place is some what cult-ish, but don't blame me for being put off by the google crazed freak sitting next to me blabbing on her cell phone in a business call. They don't have a no cell phone policy, so I guess Phil'z is not to be blamed, but nevertheless that incident has caused me to go home and now write this. 

I have tried maybe 5 or 6 different varieties of their coffee, and I can't say I like any of them more than blue bottle or ritual. I think coffee should be drank black, and not masked by "turkish" aromas, mint, or sweet additives. This place is still better than the corner store, and it is still down the block from my house. Many people love it and I can see why, but I don't think it hits the mark of being the top coffee shop in San Francisco for several reasons.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
I like their kind messy warm home style ambience. 
ther descriptions of lots kind of cofee are  written down on the menu board though, Im not familar with coffee and just picked mocha i only knew. then the choice was perfect! the mocha was the best i had ever!
other coffee must be delicious too.
I would need to read the menu more to get what i should order next time.
author: Spinof P.

description:
First Date:
You scoff at me for not wanting cream. (I think) I know what I want; I want it black. I cave under pressure and allow you to taint my cup. First date = mixed feelings. Who do you think you are?!?

My coffee companion wants a frou-frou espresso drink. He's perplexed, eyes frantically scanning the menu board.

You're edgy, like the Mission girls in unmatched skirts and leggings that frequent your vintage arm chairs.
You lack a 'tude, I'm just an ignorant Philz consumer.
You're everything one could hope for, it's just knowing how to ask for it.

Nearly two years pass before our second encounter.
Second date becomes a third, a fourth, a fifth... enough that I've worked my way through the roasts and blends. We have a standing date on Sunday mornings, you just don't know it. I leave with a smile, air in my step, and a (no-longer-secret) desire to get frisky up against the glass case of sugar-coasted miniature donuts. I love waking up to you.
author: Alissa A.

description:
oh man...this place puts all of the other coffee places out there to shame!  i was in the city and made it a point to stop by and pick up a cup of their magnificent tesora...YUMMY.  the freshness is unbeatable...and i love how their service is always fantastic.  if you're a newbie, don't be afraid to ask questions...that's what they're there for...and they're so proud to talk about their blends.  

the iced mint mojito coffee is just AMAZING.  fresh mint...yummy coffee...yummy everything.  

i was tempted to drop by the san jo location on the way home...but man, one cup is strong enough to keep your heart pounding for the rest of the night.  BEST COFFEE EVER!!!  EVEEEEEEEEEER!!!
author: Jen W.

description: Love this place. I'm not a big coffee person but I definitely appreciate a great fresh cup. If I need a coffee fix, I'll end up here.
author: Brittany L.

description:
I love coffee.  Especially good coffee.  I drove by this place one day and saw the big sign.  "Philz" and "Best Handmade Coffee" ... I thought, Who's Phil?  

So of course, I Yelped Philz and saw that it was highly recommended.  I went the next morning and wasn't sure how the flow went in there.  But I worked it out.  Order from the back and pay in the front.  Got it.  

As I was handed my coffee I had a whiff of it and I just knew it was going to be good.  

I took that first sip and immediately thought, damn I am definitely not in the know!!  Philz IS the BEST HANDMADE COFFEE!!  :)
author: Delilah B.

description: Endroits sympa pour faire une pause après une exploration du street art de San Francisco: en 3 mots bon café, Bon wifi et super canapés
author: Yoann A.

description: Philz has an amazing array of single cup coffee.  It's even a bit mind-boggling.  But what makes their coffee stand out in my mind is that I can drink it totally black.  When paying over $2.00 for a cup of coffee, I try to just taste the coffee au natural; Philz makes this easy.  This was truly a tasty cup of java....and I've been to Java!
author: Melissa M.

description: Spent Christmas Day morning here Skyping with my family in Mississippi while the spectacular Phil chatted up the room.  I love this place.  My mom loves this place.  Take it one cup at a time, people!
author: Austin R.

description:
Been here twice - great impressions both times. Excellent coffee. Had a really delicious iced coffee here with interesting chocolaty undetones and realized how crappy the iced coffee at Starbucks really is.

Great service, too. Easy to ask for a recommendation. One of the guys making my coffee asked me to taste it before buying to make sure I liked what he'd prepared - it tasted excellent.

The environment is chill. Big dining room tables to plop your laptop down and get some work done. Like the jungle/sky scenery painted on the ceiling.
author: Pete P.

description: Wow! The iced coffee mint mojito is awesome. Great place to meet (but very popular so it may take some time to find a place to sit). I will definitely be back!
author: Ana C.

description: So dang good!!!    Do you put butter in your coffee??? Awesome peeps to chat with behind the counter while you are there too... yummmmmmm
author: Adrienne G.

description:
this coffee establishment is one of many of God's gifts... SO GOOD, u will be awaken to what good coffee really is. and you'll realize that you don't need a frappe or anything to take away from the coffee, because it's just THAT YUMMY.

I tried most them, i think?  and liked every one.  I always get it with some cream and sugar.  


go with a few people, try each other's cups because every single brewed cup of Joe is unique and rich in flavor.
if only there were more PHILZ around the city /or on my way to work, i'd get one EVERYDAY without batting an eyelash.   *melts*
author: Miss J.

description:
I had been hearing many things about Philz so I finally was able to go to SF to try it out. 

The Tesora and Jacob's wonderbrew were okay, I thought they were on the acidic side which was disappointing. We also bought a pound of tesora beans which weren't so acidic when we made it with a french press. I was able to try my friend's mint mojito which I thought was really good compared to their black coffee.
author: Retired B.

description:
BEST CUP OF COFFEE I'VE EVER HAD.  Seriously.  Canopy of heaven with a touch of cream has layers of flavor that I didn't even know could happen in a beverage.  

Their "delicious baklava?"  Yep.  It's delicious.

The staff runs the gamut of totally nice and easy going to super-cool and aloof hipster.  I prefer the former, but let's be honest: a coffee shop ain't a real coffee shop until you get one of the latter...

Phil, I'll be back!
author: Ashley S.

description: This was seriously some of the BEST coffee I have ever had. I was immediately greeted by a gentleman who worked the back counter who helped me with my coffee selection, and boy did he get it right! I had the ambrosia which was perfect! I will definitely be back!
author: Mary G.

description:
What can you say about this place. It is a serious dump but who cares! The coffee is
the best. I am from Portland and whenever I come to SF I need to get my Philz fix. I don't know how they do it but the coffee is superb even in the paper cups they have. 
i always buy a large cup because it only costs a few cents more and then I can sip it for a long time. 
Most of the baristas are a hoot too. 
A couple of times we were there even the the Phil of Philz was there and he was a lot of fun.
author: Keith G.

description:
I know, I know, everybody loves Philz! It's a phenomenon and now even an iPhone app (???) , so what new could be said? 

Still I want to toss my hat in the ring about how refreshing it is to receive a delightful personally- crafted cup of coffee in a welcoming atmosphere where the staff at least successfully pretends to really really like you and really really love what they're doing! That kind of sentiment - real or pretend - does make the world feel like a sweeter & gentler place.

The tasting ritual, the aroma of fresh mint, the Turkish coffee, medium sweet  - I love it!
author: Sandra A.

description:
I LOVE COFFEE!

But I also am what they call a coffee snob, living in Italy and with a lot of Italian friends i soon discovered  espresso, and trust me wherever you are in Italy, your coffee is great, also, if you order latte after noon, they will laugh.

So with that said it has been hard for me to find good coffee in The States, you guys seem to like a bit weaker then I do but Phil your coffee is not bad at all.

I like it and i really like the place and the area.
author: cecilia k.

description: Love the coffee here! I usually get the mocha tesora for something slightly sweet and slightly mocha flavored. I love that this coffee is not too sweet and very smooth. On a hot day nothing beats the mint mojito ice coffee. Just be prepared to wait sometimes.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Totally love this place. Everyone here is really nice. Tesoro is great, and if you are in for a treat, the way they make it the best. They have opened a few others, my only thoughts RE the new ones, are that they are in some random locations and totally lack the like, feel of coziness the original one. 

A bit pricey, so you are buying the lifestyle of appreciating the finer things in life. I am into it,
author: Danielle V.

description:
Where's the other 1/2 star?  I have no idea how you could not give Phil all five of your Yelp stars.  

My very favorite thing about this particular Philz is that on any given day, Phil could make your coffee (in your mug with his photo on it if you're a devotee like me).... or Jacob could serve you his namesake blend (my favorite).  What could be better than that?

My very best order recommendations: Jacobs made the lowfat way (1/2 cream, 1/2 milk) + honey.  OR, the Istanbul Treat with milk.

Everyone here is friendly, totally Mission-esque and makes a fantastic cup o' coffee.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Very nice kids behind the counter... I asked for hi caffiene beans and the nice young man delivered. They all had great attitude!

I got the Anesthesia To The Upside beans.

It brewed up nice this morning, and nice buzz. I gave it the straight shot test and it was super smooth. 

Hats off to you Phil Jaber and his son Jacob, nice place!!!
author: Jim S.

description: Philz....an institution by itself for good coffee, interesting people watching, and inappropriate conversation...or at least that was me and my friend.  We went for coffee and studying and ended up with coffee and watching Mark Ronson music videos featuring Q-Tip and English kids doing the C-walk.  The coffee helped me wake up after only having 4 hours of sleep the night before.  Delicious and practical.
author: Ashley I.

description:
Stopped by to order a plain, black, house blend coffee on a recent Saturday morning.  I just moved to SF, so I had no expectations for what Philz coffee was like - it just happens to be a couple blocks from my apartment and on the way to the BART.  However, it turned out I'd happened upon some of the best coffee I've ever had.  The handmade/dripped coffee experience was totally new to me, but it was totally worth the $3 -- so much better than Starbucks!

Only 4 stars though because of the total chaos of the ordering/paying process. It's not surprising that it would be busy on a weekend morning, but it was totally unclear where you should order, wait, pay, etc., which added some frustration to an otherwise very pleasant experience.
author: Kristen K.

description:
Do we really need almost 400 reviews for Phiz? Not really, but I want to get to 500 reviews for my profile sometime. 

I am a die hard coffee drinker. I like a dark roast, never a "French" roast. NO cream or sugar, EVER. 

That all changed when I went to Philz the other day. Being a newbie, I had no idea there were so many choices. Asking for a recommendation, the girl behind the counter must have known I was a newbie. She recommended the Tesora blend, as is custom with new Philz customers. As you all know, they make it by the cup, adding cream and sugar for you. I was not disappointed. I even took a little of their cream in my coffee. but still no sugar. I was in heaven. It was balanced, had good bite to it, and the cream tasted really good with the coffee. 

Next time I wanted to try a darker roast and tried Julie's Ultimate, but forgot the no sugar part. I will still get no sugar next time, as I want to taste the coffee, not all the cream and sugar. I liked the Tesora blend, light cream, no sugar much better than Julie's. 

Odd setup on the inside, and it gets quite crowded with chairs and tables, mostly not matching, thrown just about everywhere. 

I was remembered from my previous visit and she almost prepared a Tesora blend for me, but I stopped her, wanting to try a different blend. I want to go back a lot more and try more of the different coffees. You will pay a lot more than you would at your normal coffee place, but Philz is one of a kind. 

Free Wi-Fi and pay by time computers are available. Some baked goods are available, but I likely won't get many of those, as I'll only be there late in the afternoon. Those tiny donuts looks fake, but was assured they are real, but I didn't try any.
author: Michael M.

description: Hipster central, and I love it. I love the Ambrosia especially. I love watching the scene here, from tarot card reading to massaging with a magic wand, it's happenin' here.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Philz Coffee.  Is the best.  Ever.  In all the world.  Amen.

I also like that Phil hangs out.

BESTCOFFEEEVER.
author: tracy m.

description:
Delicious coffee. An actual *selection* of decaf (as that's all I can drink these days, sadly). Extremely dog-friendly. And a great place to waste a Saturday reading, or a Wednesday working. Also, the right price (and you can choose your barista, if you know who you like).

Their new pastries are delicious and seemingly not terribly unhealthy.

Worst parts are the confusion and contention in lines, and how fracking long it takes to pay (I don't mind waiting 8 minutes for coffee, but it usually takes far longer to pay).
author: Jono S.

description:
This has turned into my daily coffee spot. It's on my walk to work, so I'm thoroughly awake by the time I get there. And I mean thoroughly awake. Lovely pastry selection (ahem, apple croissant), and delightful staff. Thank you for making my mornings easier.

I still believe the caffeine is really crack.
author: Kiki C.

description:
Get any of their coffees or teas. You won't be disappointed.

I personally love the Iced Mint Mojito and the Tesora. Fantastic!
author: X O.

description:
lovely coffee--had a blend that tasted like it had a shot of whiskey in it.  strong city.

great staff, great crowd, comfy couches, and the best ever music---who doesn't wanna hear some old school janet and missy elliot in the am hours?  

xxoo
author: Jessica G.

description: Hands down my favorite coffee shop in the world - and I LOVE coffee and traveling. Philz coffee is a unique style of drip coffee so maybe it's not for everyone, but I love the Philtered Soul or Philharmonic, though an Iced Mint Mojito may be the most unique drink they offer.  This particular Philz is also great because the atmosphere has a great vibe and is a fun place to read (if you don't mind background noise) or hang out with friends.
author: Megan C.

description: Still the best, most gourmet, single cup brewed original coffee you can get. Heard a lot of buzz about the mint mojito coffee. Went there, ordered it and when I got it I didn't even know it was suposed to be an iced coffee. It was a sweet surprise because I was looking for something refreshing. When asked to give it their signature taste test, I saw it sitting there all pretty with had a bunch of mint leaves garnishing the top of the cup with ices cubes floating next to them. First taste, perfect. It really does taste like a cool minty sweet mojito in a ice cold creamy bold flavored cup of coffee. This could easily become my new choice of coffee at Philz :-)
author: Patrick L.

description:
The best drip coffee I've had, hands down. Most of the famous Mission coffeehouses are all about the bean - Ritual, Four Barrel go to great lengths to visit plantations and pick out their favorite single-origin coffees. You're told all about the bean - this is from Ethiopia, we had dinner with the farmers, etc.

You get none of that at Philz. While I'm sure they use great beans, I have no idea where they come from, and it actually doesn't matter. The focus is on the coffee in the cup - someone (Phil) went out of their way to create their ideal flavors, and the beans were just a means to an end. 

So you'll get some strange things. The Philtered Soul doesn't taste as coffee "should", but it sure as hell tastes *good*. It's a nice change from all the other cafes in the area. Drip coffee that isn't the burnt mess from Starbucks, isn't the "earthy with mandarin orange marmalade in the finish" from Ritual; drip coffee that's just Philz. Go give it a shot.
author: Victor L.

description: 3 words..... ICED MINT MOJITIO. They make my days better and my work days shorter. Amen to Philz
author: Stephanie S.

description:
This is where I go for a serious freakin' cup of coffee.  

They don't waste their time with those silly espresso drinks, they just make delicious, amazing, intense coffee.  One cup at a time.    I'm personally a big fan of the Philtered Soul, which reminds me of toasted marshmallows (particularly if you get it with cream & sugar).  

Minus one star for costing twice as much as a cup of coffee anywhere else... It's probably good that it's a little too out of my way to hit it up every morning.  It's worth it for a special occasion, but I already spend too much money on coffee as it is!
author: Jane A.

description: i hate giving philz a less than spectacular review. i love their coffee, but have to say that i've always hated that i can't put in my own cream and sugar...it's so personal, how could anyone else know exactly how i like it? coffee is such a vice and pleasure for me and i need things to be just right. ruin my coffee and you ruin my day!  the last time i went to philz there was so much cream in my coffee i couldn't taste the coffee (& i didn't order a latte!). i didn't realize the amazing amount of cream until i was rushing on my way to my next destination since foam was cleverly disguising the surface. needless to say, i was very disappointed. i think i will try ritual or bello on 24th from now on and skip the philz experience unless they decide to change their set up where i can have more coffee control.
author: locustgirl ..

description:
Best cup I ever had. Was dumb and the bartender helped me pick the perfect cup. Tried the cupcakes they were ok, The coffee is fantastic. Medium roast with cream and sugar. She told me I'd love it and I did.

I want more. God I miss San Francisco!
author: Dustin R.

description:
The absolute best. There really is nothing out there like Philz. Don't get me wrong, other beans like Ritual, Blue Bottle, Four Barrel, etc. are good, but Philz is on a plane of its own -- it's really unique and ultra smooth. Just go have a cup and you'll see what I mean. I absolutely love their coffee, but not to be overlooked is their excellent fresh chai (none of that pre-sweetened crap), yerba mate, and other teas. I still have yet to find another place that makes chai as well as they do. Also, the baristas are great and they offer suggestions if you don't know what to order or just want to try something new. The food options are also pretty good. 

I really, really miss Philz, especially this one in the Mission (great atmosphere). Now that I live in Los Angeles, I'm just waiting for Phil to open one here... :)
author: Viola L.

description:
2 words - nuff said
2 more words - Mocha Tesora
9 more words - I could use some Philz coffee right about now
7 more words - how about a philz in walnut creek?
last 2 words - killer boots!
author: Brent A.

description: My first time here I didnt know what to order since I wanted hot coffee.  So they suggested the Terosa.  Perfectly strong and full bodied.  The 2nd and 3rd time I ordered their famous Iced Mint Mojito...WOW!  Very refreshing and satisfied my coffee craving.  But the 4th time here I wanted the Iced mojito but wasnt pleased like I was before.  So I guess it depends on who's making your coffee.  This girl put too much cream which over powered the iced mint feel.  But overall I love Philz
author: Marilou A.

description: The coffee is really good. Service is a bit wierd. Do not ask for a latte or they will look at you like you have an octopus coming out of your nose.
author: J H.

description:
People working here are NICE.

Coffee is great.  They do individual press pots here.  Most of the time I'm annoyed by these.  But here they do it because they've been doing it for a damn long time, they know how to do it properly and they're not doing it as a gimmick.

Ginger bread and banana-walnut bread were great.  Coffee was outstanding.  Environment was unlike no other.  Terrific place to spend hours and hours.
author: Jason C.

description:
I wrote a review for the San Jose location already... but here it is again-5 stars.

Simply because I was greeted by Phil himself this time around and the Philharmonic was still BOMB!

The end.
author: Lynn C.

description:
#200 had to be something special.. something near and dear to me. For those few moments of taste bud bliss as the coffee slides down my throat and the lingering flavor dances on my tongue, I dedicate my 200 to Philz.

I've been going to Philz for a while now, but a couple of weeks ago, I ordered with Phil himself.. ZOMG!   :O   *_*  -  BEST Iced Philtered Soul I've had.

Coffee is like crack here. I'm cutting down on all other spending, but won't give up this addiction. Philz is the pick-me-up for those days where you wake up all groggy and the first thing you think of is Philz (and when I say 'those days', I mean every day, but unfortunately, I don't live close enough to go every day..). Speaking of which, my soul hasn't been philtered this morning.. :(  

'The Ecstactic' iced coffee and Mocha Tesora  are my other favorites. 

It's hard to find a seat here on Sundays, but we usually manage. Free wifi, and free people-watching.. *fist pump* 

Philz will get you outta your morning funk and give you some soul. -- I got soul, but I'm not a soldier.. Oh wait.. I guess I am following the crowd with this one though.. 5 sexy, caffeinated stars!
author: Donna H.

description:
Here is exactly how it went down.  

Last night, Maria D. sent me a link to this:  http://www.yelp.com/biz/tXaFSi6GrMHV26dv0IPylQ

I FREAK THE FUCK OUT.  I mean, I am fr-iz-eaking.  I call all of the places in San Francisco that carry these donuts and they are all sold out.  I am pissed off.  It was all I could do to not burn Ritual Coffee Roasters to the ground.  Then, I remember, they are not Blue Bottle and so they are spared.  Also, Blue Bottle coffee kills babies, pass that around.

I go to Jazzercise.  I go to dinner.  I pretend to enjoy conversation with my fellow man.  ALL I CAN THINK ABOUT IS THIS FUCKING DONUT.  I feed my foster dogs.  I walk my foster dogs.  I imagine their heads as gigantic donuts.  Delicious.  I call my mom.  I pretend to care about her problems.  I write some stuff for work.  I can't even remember what I typed.  I proof read my work, i have put the word "donut" in the middle of TWO sentences.  I eat second dinner because all i want is this fucking donut and i can't fucking have it so i have to eat three baked potatoes instead!  I clip my DONUT toenails.  I go to bed.  

5 am.  I'm up.  Staring at the ceiling.  5:30 am.  I'm out of bed and ready to DO IT TO IT.  F&*&(*&UYUIASDASING Boss called and I'm forced to work...I hate this man so much I can't begin to explain in words DONUT.  10:30 am.  I walk down to Philz.  Coffee?  Fuck that!  I'll take a DONUT!  Okay, actually, I'll take a coffee and four donuts.  I'm bringing some to my friends.  The ones who live in my stomach.  KIT BFF.

The donuts?  Build up is a son-of-a-bitch.  It's like finally getting the super cute dude into bed and you're like, "Really?  That's it?"  Actually, that's pretty much ANY guy but anywayz.  Let's try this again.  The donuts?  They're good.  The vanilla ones are actually really good.  They taste like they won't kill you from unhealthiness, which is a nice change of pace from the normal donut.  The vanilla ones are better than the chocolate ones.  They remind me of a super fresh version of the "Nutrilicious" brand vegan donuts that you can get at Whole Foods.  I will definitely have them again and they are worth seeking out, especially for us vegans and those who don't want to die from the scrumptious fattiness of the regular donut.  The vanilla ones with sprinkles are the standout.  Sprinkles.  Delicious.  

The coffee?  It's good.  I don't get this whole "french pressed" revolution that's sweepin' the city but I like the vanilla flavored cappuccinos from 7-11 because GUESS WHAT?  That shit is straight up DELICIOSO.  Coffee snobs, I get you, but I honestly can't taste the difference between this fancy coffee and Chock Full O' Nuts.  And no, I'm not meeting you in person to tell you this to your face.  I already did that with the old dude from Blue Balls Crapee and I'm done with full grown men running down the street to get away from me.  I've had boyfriends, I'm familiar with this game.
author: Laura B.

description:
What makes a coffeehouse lovely:

(1) Quality beans.
(2) Great shots of espresso.
(3) Friendly service.
(4) Hot hipster bariste.

Philz has plenty of (1) and extreme amounts of (3), but sadly falls short in the (2) department. However, their drip coffee stands supreme, and the refreshingly authentic smiles I received can't help but warrant Philz five stars. Still, I crave the endless whooshing of steaming hot jet streams that could cause an explosion if handled improperly. Coffee is like sex, in that it's better when there's an element of sudden death involved...

And to the (4) - call me ;-)
author: Keane L.

description: I Love love love Philz Coffee. I am a coffee fiend and I can safely say that Philz is the best coffee I have ever had. The Turkish roast is so pleasant, vibrant and aromatic, with a hint of cardamom, it is a roast you can never get tired of. Julie's Ultimate is so delicately floral and elegant it brings joy to my mouth. I like my coffee black making getting coffee a big hit or miss depending on the quality. With Philz, you can get it however you want and it will taste amazing!
author: Maria L.

description: Lots of people rave about Blue Bottle; I think Philz is at least as good. Nice, airy, old-school funky coffeehouse décor, really great coffee and pastries, very friendly, accommodating staff- will go here anytime I'm in the neighborhood.
author: JOHN S.

description:
Jazz on Sunday - bright and cheery. 
Beautiful bariste - I like them hipsters. 
Mocha Tesora - sweetened just right. 
Iced Philtered Soul - when I like it cold.
Playing the "Spot the Strangest Beard" game with friends. You will have a field day with this one. There are so many to choose from...
Surfing the wireless interwebs. 

Five glorious stars!

I will remember to snack/eat elsewhere. A vegan cookie is ~83.33% the cost of a small Mocha Tesora, and it was a little on the dry side.

As for the dogs, I read in another review that there was a recent ban. I am a dog owner, and even I don't mind that so much. If the owners of certain dogs who happened to make their way into Philz would actually take responsibility for them, it would be alright. It is NOT COOL, however, to tell your dog to get down, which essentially means laying its 50-pound body across the top of a stranger's bag, which may or may not contain something fragile inside. NOT COOL. 

I love Philz [location-specific, as I have not visited the other two], even though I leave the place completely jittery from caffeine. Five glorious stars.
author: Tinna H.

description: A cup of Jacob's Wonderbar Brew can seriously make my day.
author: Bora K.

description:
I was invited to Philz for coffee and vegan donuts by one of my favorite Yelpers. I hate to name drop but let's just say her name rhymes with Laura B. The plan was I'd meet at her place then walk down to Philz with her foster dog Sweet Jane. Sweet Jane is, as her name would imply, very sweet and also named Jane so you should adopt her immediately. I have to admit though, that I couldn't help but notice her her huge nipples. She also, apparently, has a vag that says, "Been there, done that." Not literally or else she'd be on Letterman. Anyway, if your criteria for adopting a dog involves the condition of its nipples and vag then you, sir, are one sick motherfu...I'm getting a little off subject here but bear with me because there is a point.

Philz is the kind of funky cafe that you would expect in the Mission. Mismatched old furniture, houseplants and newspapers. The kind of bohemian joint you can snuggle up with your honeypants and plan a revolution.

So we get there and I order a drip coffee. It's what they do, make drip coffee one cup at a time. I must have said something wrong because the woman behind the counter hesitated, said, "Um, okaaay," and the old dude in line behind me practically yells in my ear, "ROOKIE!" Now, I've only been to Philz a couple of times but I didn't realize how presumptuous it was to simply ask for a cup of coffee at a cafe. Luckily, I am a patient person and practiced at dealing with douchebags which, unfortunately, make up the majority of society. See how good I am at that?

I think it's a little weird that, if you take cream or sugar, they put it in your coffee for you. Despite that, it's always been to my liking so I guess they know what they're doing. Oh, and they use cream not half & half. I only know this because the older gentleman was trying to persuade Laura to have the cream in her coffee. She's a vegan and apparently practiced in the same social skills as me. We're a couple of gaddamned SAINTS I tell you.

True enough, there were vegan donuts and between the two of us we purchased their entire selection. I'm an omnivore and by that I mean I eat ANYTHING. Shit that's fallen on the floor, something hanging off your face, well you get it. The white cake donuts weren't bad but the chocolate was just not right. To illustrate this point, when offered a half a chocolate donut Sweet Jane spit it out. Let me repeat that just in case the gravity of that statement was missed. A DOG, who most likely suffered some amount of trauma in her life, (I don't know this for sure but one doesn't get nipples like that without SOME trauma) refused a FREE donut. I mean, shit, even I ate the chocolate one. This dog clearly has more discriminating tastes than myself.

Anyway, despite the mediocre vegan donuts and elitism the coffee is exceptional. This stuff might even help you kick that nasty meth smoking habit you have.
author: Josua P.

description: I loves me some Philz.  Every cup is truly handcrafted, but without the attitude of some other SF single drip coffee spots.  I'm usually a fan of slightly darker roasts, but I must say that Philz is near the top of my list of best coffees ever.
author: Jeff D.

description:
Here is the breakdown of my Sunday morning coffeehouse experience, narrated by various body parts:

NOSE: Holy crap, what is that amazing smell?  Let's get it.
FEET: No... I'm too tired from moving furniture yesterday.  I don't want to walk anymore.
NOSE: Suck it up.  You need some coffee and you'll be fine.
EYEBALL: Yeah, Feet.  And I saw that there were couches in there last time you walked by.  You and Ass can rest.
FEET: That is a valid point.  Ok, let's go.

EYEBALL:  Wow, this place is really arty and comfy looking.  And the barista has beautiful eyes.  I'm jealous.
STOMACH: Hey, get me one of those pastries.  And some of that free mint for the picking.  And whip cream.
THIGHS: No whip cream.  Please.

MOUTH: WOW.  I mean, WOW this coffee is good.  I love the fresh sprig of mint in my Turkish coffee!
NOSE:  See?  Told ya.
ASS: Mmmmm I'm going to snuggle into this comfy, broken-in couch.  How you doin, Feet?
FEET: Golden.

EARS: Dude you guys, I'm bored.  
EYES: Don't worry, they're setting up a little jam session in the front window over there.  They'll start playing in a few.
BRAIN: Note to self: body says yes to Phillz.  Return frequently.
author: Mari C.

description:
I came through here quickly and asked for a house coffee, just like an asshole, without realizing that there was an abundant menu of coffees on the board above me, none of which were called "House Coffee".  They were having open mike night, and I wished I was here to hang out rather than to run on to the next thing.

A complete and total horse's ass, blissful in my ignorance, I await as the barista makes me a killer cup of whateverthefuck kind of coffee it was, BY HAND, grinding and brewing the beans right into my cup, and plucks a mint leaf off of a plant on the counter to put on top of this ridiculous yummy coffee.  By now I'm thoroughly aromatherapized by all the bags of beans they have piled around everywhere, and I have NOTICED the menu, and I take the coffee from the cute perfect barista boy as I come into the knowledge that I ordered coffee like a stupid fucking idiot.  And this barista allowed the opportunity to scorn me....pass.  No hate, just coolness and a smile.

I had asked for soy, and a little sugar, and he put it in the coffee for me.  I took a sip and realized that this was a really great coffeehouse.

Two dollar tip!!!
author: Randy F.

description: (24th & Folsom) They make great drinks, especially tea, since I don't like coffee.  The hot chocolate is also greatly done.  Pretty good desserts, but get there early because they run out of choices too quickly.  The downside here is that the Internet goes down frequently, and by frequently I mean almost every time I go there.  It is so frustrating that I have stopped going much lately and strying to other cafes.  The staff are great, but much of this is out of their control.  I do like the relaxed atmosphere, but I call for a few more outlets.  Lets face it, a lot of people want wi-fi at a cafe and I for one will not frequent a cafe without it.  But what's worse then no wi-fi is wi-fi that's sketchy.  What a tease.  And teases wonder why they get cheated on.  Hmmmm, I'm just saying.
author: Scott A.

description:
goodbye blue bottle and HELLO PHILZ!

so much talk over the years about blue bottle but the best kept secret is that philz coffee just may be alot better. this is a great shop with a very cool upstair for live music and sitting back and relaxing with my favorite cup of coffee. another plus is the free wifi and the place was packed so i think many know about the free wifi and love their great coffee blends. i have many favorite coffees hear but i really love the tesora, philarmonic and the silk and splendor. i always make sure to stock up on the beans whenever i'm in the neighborhood.
author: Scotty D.

description: I'm writing this review from Hawaii because I just got a yelp and have been craving Philz so bad! Nothing compares. Somebody send me a bag of Ambrosia!
author: Dr. Kevin C.

description: Good service,  Emily was extremely helpful and courteous. Will definitely come back.
author: H Y.

description:
Philz is great. i feel like i'm at the Friend's tv show coffee shop. only this one though. the other ones i just want to get coffee and go. but i would have to say that its some good shiet. its custom coffee drinks without all the heavy milk and espresso drinks. its just pure coffee taste. although its sometimes so strong that i'm hair stands up. nose hairs too... hahaha.

great thing is that you can discover new coffee tastes. you find a new appreciation for pure coffee with a tad of milk instead of at starbucks where they give you one shot with a whole lot of milk or their daily brews that sit in the pot. they have different brews but rather taste the same each time anyways. its interesting that you go from place to place... and each time the coffee taste is distinctive and by far philz is one of the most distinctive in flavor. what i like is when Phil actually walks around the coffee shop and chats with you to learn about your day. or actually spends time personally kicking out the bums loitering his bench shops.
author: Darren C.

description:
Dear Philz,

Thank you for making me feel all funny, like I am in love or something. I laughed a lot when I was at your place today. Though the laughter was provided by the great company I was with, you gave us a perfect environment in which to share hilarious stories. You also made me feel like I had butterflies in my stomach. I am not sure if it was your strong coffee or my two day hangover or if you just give me that silly nervous feeling. I am going with the third because after I finished my coffee I was all sweaty, hot and bothered and needed to chain smoke. You are special Philz. What are you doing later?? I might have to stalk you. 

Love always,

Your secret admirer.

P.S. Eric W rocks!
author: Drue C.

description:
don't go!  this place will spoil you for coffee elsewhere.

but if you MUST have the ULTIMATE coffee experience, i recommend "Sooo Good" or "Greater Alarm".

this is not your grandfather's coffee.
author: Steve F.

description:
i feel like im forced to give this place 3 stars because everybody else is giving it good stars and i'll look like a hater if i give it anything lower.................

but i was seriously not impressed with the mocha tesora. but i can DEFINITELY see why real coffee lovers would love it. its REALLY strong! but im more of a mixed coffee drinker and strongly brewed coffees make me sick. but yeah.. i seriously felt like i was drinking espresso with a hint of chocolate instead of mocha. which i feel should be equal or close to it!

however i do think its impressive that they seriously brew one coffee cup at a time. how do they afford that....???

i guess by cutting costs of what their place looks like inside. omggahhh when i showed up here with some friends i was seriously like.. wtf.. this place looks so trashy. but other people would call it "hipster" and "cool".

i dont want to give up on it yet though. i just need to find that one drink that'll make me go WOW! because im very sure philz has something like that for me there..
author: Rebecca K.

description:
Okay, Phil, while possessing an admirable entrepenurial spirit and self avowed love of coffee, is, simply, a creepy wierdo who likes to 'spoonfeed his cream' to any woman in the 25-35 age bracket that happens to stumble into his store unaccompanied by a bodybuilder of a male companion.  He also once paid my friend in a counterfeit $100 bill and then refused to own up to it/pay her back.  I've also heard from another employee that all his coffee varieties, the 'Jacob's Wonderbar', the 'Philharmonic' and so on are really the same type of bean with a different label put on their little bin.  I mean, what did you expect, a coffee roaster in the back of the joint?
Still, good ol' creepy Phil gets three stars for pulling the wool over all your sorry asses, and now that he's expanding city wide, all the more better.  Maybe the lines at blue bottle and ritual will get a little shorter.
author: Ben V.

description:
I take friends from Austin and Seattle here to prove that they have NOTHING on SF. (Which isn't entirely true: Seattle has incredible heroin and Austin has fantastic queso, but I can generally do without.)

Since I went from gainfully employed public relations/marketing whore to being a self/unemployed full-time student, I've needed a place to go and get shit done. It's too easy to be diverted by internet porn and my cats (not at the same time) in my living room, and it's a sin to not be riding my bike around in this perfect goddamned weather while most of the rest of you are sloughing away in cubicle hell and wishing you could go out and play. (See? I do this for you.) 

Philz is a perfect destination. Great coffee, big windows, unoffensive music, living room atmosphere, free wifi, those ridiculously tasty samosas, cute early-twenties kids walking in all sweaty after riding their fixies around (no hating here, just pheromones), and close enough to everything that I want to eat for a quick lunch. I love it here. I'm here right now, and I'm perfectly content.

I've heard rumors that Phil is a misogynist or whatever, and you know what? Speaking as a Jew, Phil could be a Nazi Darth Vader demon monster, and I'd still come by. So long as he doesn't Nazi Darth Vader demon monster at me. But in my experience, he's a charming, warm, and friendly guy so none of that matters.

(Ritual can suck my ass.)
author: jason l.

description:
One time I went here and my coffee was only good, and not great. But almost all the time the coffee is really great, but that's not the best part. The best part is that you can almost always find a comfortable place to sit. Oh, and there is wifi. And, the staff is really nice and full of cute people. 

Oh, and for when I am being too lazy to take the bus, you can find unmetered parking within  a reasonable distance on Saturdays, and of course on Sunday, the meters are free and plentiful.
author: neil c.

description: Mint Mojito Iced Coffee. Brilliant. Enough said. Best coffee house ever.
author: Jorge H.

description:
Came here at the end of my visit here in San Francisco. I visited a couple of the other popular coffee houses and was not impressed. Attitude was
snobby and rude. When I came to Philz I was already thinking I would get the same attitude here. I was a little intimidated with their list of drinks, almost about to leave expecting attitude if I asked any questions. When it was my turn to order, I kind of cringed expecting rolling eyes and attitude. Boy, was I wrong. Totally, the opposite. I explained that it was my first time at Philz and didn't know what to order. The guy was soooo nice! He welcomed me, he began to explain to me how to order. He made it so easy for me, honestly I was still in shock at how extremely nice he was. I became so relaxed, like I was talking to a long time friend. These guys looked like they wanted to be there and really enjoyed what they were doing. He even offered my son a hot cocoa!  It was the best cup of coffee and experience I have had my entire stay in San Francisco. Thanks for making my ending to my trip in San Francisco the best. I didn't get the baristas name, he was tall and had dark hair. The short little guy was really funny!
author: Nancy M.

description:
was it happenchance that i found a parking space almost in front of philz's?  maybe the coffee fairies wanted to show me what good coffee really tasted like. i  saw the banner  "voted by sf weekly's  #1 coffee" "organic", etc. 

the left of the "coffee shop" had many couches that were filled with couples drinking, reading, or watching the tv. the right had 2  young white female barristas making coffee, etc.

i look at the menu. none of the names made sense to me. the barrista
asked me what i wanted. "medium coffee to go" i said. she proceeded to grind some beans and brewed my coffee to order.

"do you brew each order individuallly"?  i asked.
"yes" she said "what coffee do you like most?"
i thought for a while and said "independents. of the chains, i like tullys" .
"there's no tully's in frisco"
"i get it in marin, oakland, or the ballpark."
"do you want cream and sugar"?  she asks. 
"yes, just a little"
she then proceeded to pour the brewed coffee back and forth between two cups, " to cool it down".
when i tasted the coffee(3.25), it was something i never tasted before. very chocolate like, or cocca like. she then said "there's phil next to you"
i turned to the left and saw a young man in his 20's.
"no,  the other side" i turned to my right side and saw an unassuming
older gentlemen. i said  "nice to meet you"
phil said "i'm phil #2, he's phil #1" and walked away. 

when i reached the bottom of my coffee drink, i didn't experience any bitter aftertaste. (as is typical of most coffees i've tasted.  how sweet!
author: Victor G.

description:
This place was delicious!-- finger-lickin good!  Not that I spilled my coffee all over and was licking my fingers, but~ if I did... I probably would!  The barista was very nice and patient as she watched me choose from what seemed like 100 different options... But she made my coffee -- individually of course-- and asked if I wanted milk and sugar --to which I said yes -- and mixed it to perfection!  She didn't even taste it (at least not from where I was standing)!  

It was pretty amazing coffee, I think I got something with the word "silk" in the name~ which proved to be exactly that.  Silky smooth :)
Definitely going back when I get the chance!
author: Katherine B.

description: Went here for the first time and the Batista gave a great recommendation. Great tasting individual dripped coffee. It had the perfect perfect combination of sugar and cream.
author: Steven B.

description:
PHIL-ER-UP
After contemplating with the barrista about which one of the many coffees was 'me', she made one of the best cups I've had. I find this surprising too, since I'm not a frou frou coffee drinker. (usually the shittier the better)
The individual cup of coffee she made for me was glorious. I caught my tongue getting frisky with the paper cup after I was done with the drink.
 I can't get over the '1 cup at a time' thing...where I work we are constantly brewing for the masses. People must be really patient in that neighborhood. I guess that's what makes Phil'z coffee an experience. As the English have their tea time, Phil makes coffee an event. 
Tongue & I hope to get lucky on the second date.
author: Nicole L.

description: 6/19/11: Fantastic coffee, long wait but certainly worth it. I was quite curious what one-cup-drip meant, five minutes after placing the order I can confirm that it indeed is a one cup drip. I found the atmosphere more comforting, a random collection of orphaned chairs, tables end tables all in an orderly chaotic layout which created a very communal feel. I felt like we stuck out having a baby with us, most everyone else appeared single and out of work, just as I remember the bay area!
author: Jesse W.

description:
All I have to say is this:

Coffee so good that it has converted a friend who is not a coffee drinker into being a coffee drinker.

Or, at least a coffee sip-stealer.  Bastard.

Totally worth the $3.50 per cup and waiting in line.
author: Kate R.

description:
Recently relocating to the mission, I'd taken an evening stroll. It was one of those dusky times of night when the full moon is just about to pop up, and it's getting chily. I needed coffee. I needed it bad.
I walked past Philz Cofee and saw a sign that said "turkish coffee here!"
I'd never had it before, so I went in and was greeted by a laid back atmosphere and clouds on the ceiling. A helpful and cute barista who explained to me what turkish coffee was, how they made it, and put a nice little mint leaf on my foaming confection. 
Oh, and it was good. Good enough to smoke after. Bitter and warm and sweet and soft. It made me put off walking home and instead wandering down balmy to take in some murals and finish my drink.
 I recommend coming here for a strong (yet oh, so gentle) cup of turkish delight.
author: Addyline L.

description:
Something creepy about this place. They have all these items on the menu and I don't know how the roasts are on any of these beans. Humorous names, but wierd.

I walk in. It seems busy and there's a line.  And shortly after I get in line some lady comes behind, "Are you in line." Uh...  No.  I'm just hitching a ride." I feel like I'm supposed to ask the people in front of me if they're in line.  So I do... --Blank stares and, "Yeah..." --  My conclusion...  Everyone was in line and that lady was at the end.

So I get to the counter and this lady has three coffee stations that use filter directly over the cup.  Not a bad idea.  So I order a Mocha cause that's the closest they got to my WM. 

Soon after I see two ladies working on two separate drinks and start dancing with these cartons of half and half.  No, seriously.  They're shaking and shaking.  I thought they were just trying to make some bubbles since there's no frother type thing that I could see. But no...  They keep going for a straight three or four full minutes.  I'm like, "What could be so serious that they have to shake these things for so long."  Anyway...

So, I go to sit down and enjoy my drink (shhh...  I see hippies.  Lots of them.  And I look like a yuppie reading my Sony Reader.) I take a sip.  Why's it taste so filmy like someone put egg whites in my coffee.  Anyway.  I should've got a small because I didn't even get past half the small.

Sorry, Phil, but I won't be back and I won't send my friends here.

Alcides.
author: Alcides G.

description:
Quite possibly, maybe, conceivably, perhaps, perchance, and plausibly the best cup of coffee in the entire freaking world. And I say this after one $3 cup of coffee-- their "house" brew, perfect temperature, with cream, sugar and mint. Mint? Who would have thought of putting mint in coffee? Well, obviously, Philz did. How can I grow mint at home, so I can treat myself to this little bonus? And how did the coffee sommelier know exactly how much cream and sugar to add? Did they do a molecular scan of my taste buds when I walked in? What gives them the right to be so damned good?

When Starbucks charges as much for a "fancy" cup of somewhat generic coffee / espresso / whatever, why not get a seriously delicious cup of hand-brewed ambrosia? Yes, Starbucks in on every corner, but if you're near Philz... treat yourself.

I have eighteen more beans to try. This is going to be... fun!
author: Paul B.

description:
If I could leave a still beating heart in place of this written review, I would.  It might have been the state of bliss I was in while arriving at a friend's birthday party at Philz, but I realized just how fricking cool it is to live in San Francisco, and abandon all conditioned thinking of not talking to strangers.

It was a private party which apparently Phil does on occasion for a select few, or maybe just anyone who'll pay him, who knows.  He was in the flesh making Irish coffee all night while the BYO beer and wine bar supplied the spirits.  I had been to another Philz before, but this was definitely my favorite trip.  This is a fabulous idea for anyone trying to plan a different kind of birthday.  There was enough room for about 25 people, hundreds of bags of fresh Colombian coffee, a few fedoras for sale, and salsa lessons.  

Hands down best Irish coffee in town and the best hospitality this side of the Mississippi.  Cue: banjo.... can't get that damn bluegrass outta my head.
author: Kelly H.

description: Somewhat inconsistent, but always better than any other coffee shop. So tasty, and so caffeinated!!
author: Pickles T.

description:
So, I'm a drip coffee person...no fancy latte shit for me. 

Philz knows how get it right!  When that little fella Phil (or some mission kid) slaves with the hot water, freshly grinding my coffee and swooning over my single coffee experience I will pay...

Now yes, I hear you $3.25 for a cup of coffee but I mean Phil knows just how much cream I like in my coffee, perfectly sweetened with the delicate balance of sugar & fresh mint...Totally worth every penny & catching an early bus to pick up a cup before Caltrain!
author: KT F.

description:
This is one of my favorite coffee shops in the city. It is a great place to hang out, they have lots of plugs and great WiFi, their coffee is AMAZING, the employees are super friendly and cool. It really doesn't get any better that Philz Coffee on 24th St. and Folsom. I love this place! 

I drink my coffee black and love the "Sooooo Good". If you are a first timer tell them and they will make it very special just for you.

Bring your own cup! (My only complaint is that they don't have glassware and I would knock off half a star for that...but they are too good to lose a whole star.)
author: Paul d.

description:
Not a coffee aficionado, but an occasional drinker. My boyfriend loves the crap out of this place, so we stop in. I walk up to what feels like a drafty meat counter, look up at the menu and decide on a cafe au lait. Simple, straight forward. Half coffee, half steamed milk. I order:

"May I have a small cafe au lait?"
Philz employee looks like I've just insulted his dying Mother. "We don't HAVE.. cafe au lait. We just have.. really - good - coffee." It felt like he was going to follow it up by heaving a sigh or saying "UH.. DUH."

Confused I look at the menu again, re-reading the text. Obviously, I wasn't going to get what I wanted. He insisted on giving me something with mint in it, and goddammit do I hate mint anything unless it comes out of a tube and contains fluoride, but I took it and gave him  my money. I didn't regain sight out of my third eye or have ultimate understanding of the cosmos when I took a drink, so I say this places' head is up its bean filled ass.
author: Serene L.

description: and just when i thought it couldn't get better, the came out with handmade truffles featuring their coffee flavors.  WOW!  a total compliment with the coffee!
author: Sheri N.

description: Supreme coffee of all the bay area! BLOWS away house of coffee in the sunset as well as Ritual "snobs" coffee! Fast & knowledgable baristas, excellent blends, awesome flavors, great prices for the quality you'll be receiving! They DO NOT use expresso machines but individually Funnel Cone your brew.
author: Cee B.

description: The last time I was in there, it was perfect: there the hipster was, taking their grandmah to his favorite coffee spot and she wondered while waiting in the 15 minute line, "I mean, it's JUST coffee..." She obviously doesn't understand. Philz has a cult following for a reason. Their brews are delicious. Don't go there for a latte - don't go there for date - just go for the Tesora or Mint Mojito.
author: Catherine C.

description:
I would be very suspicious if they gave the first Turkish Delight free just to get you hooked, because if I lived closer and/or could get there more often, I would be a serious addict.

   "What the matter honey?"
   "I am jonesing for Philz, that is what is the freakin' matter!"

I am just saying, there is a serious rush, buzz, feeling of pure joy  that caresses one's soul when you partake of this liquid heaven.  

It should be illegal, but it is not, it is just good.
author: Bruce R.

description:
I just don't know.....  I really like all the plants and stuff, sometimes some parrots hang out and phil himself is quite an interesting guy.  The drinks blow. I don't really like coffe, more of an espresso girl so i have the tea.  tried the mint tea about five times.  When my roommate and I are the only ones in the store, and there are three people working you would think that just ONE of them might have heard both our requests for no cream, no sugar.  

but alas, here comes our cups ladden with about three spoons of sugar and cream, plus once it was so hot it melted the plastic on the inside of my cup into my drink, yuck.
  Cream does not go into tea, it just doesnt shouldnt never ever - i do not want heavey cream with mint, i want tea!!!!!!!!!!!!  Won't go back.
author: amy b.

description: not a coffee drinker but dang this was good flavored coffee. had a small mocha tesora iced and it was good. i got a energized to walk the city! cute place and staff was very helpful since i had no idea what coffee was what. THANK YOU!
author: Elaine Y.

description: Wonderfully tasty coffee...even good ol' decaf!
author: P G.

description:
There are multiple locations but nothing beats the original, right? If you believe that adage, then head over to this location. Each cup is brewed individually and you get to choose from 25 different blends. Plus, Dynamo Donuts is just 3 blocks away.
http://www.dynamodonut.com/our_donuts.html

On a personal level, I have a lot of love towards the shop in Castro where I first locked lips with Tesora (a medium roast blend).
author: Regina A.

description:
this is my new fave place in the world to get coffee. it'll be one of my first stops if i'm ever back in the area.
