classic case of not judging a book by its cover. we walked into one in palo alto and it only smelled like yerba mate or tea or something. we were going to walk out after i looked at the menu and only saw drip coffees. 

the barista assured us that it would taste better than any fancy latte or mocha we've had so we shared a large iced ecstatic, a little on the sweet side. best coffee everrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr.

we were a bit lost in what we perceived was the ghetto when we saw this philz coffee. this one didn't smell like yerba mate, had the austin hipster vibe, but everyone was so friendly. the older barista is the best - he is too cool.
author: David C.

description:
A good way to pause your day.

Took a break during Saturday cycling; stopped the heavy pedal, silenced the Fugee rhymes, and ordered the Turkish blend.  

The blends sweetness is complex, lemony, & lightly rich.  I requested a touch of cream but it would be good straight-up too.  The hints of cardamom mixed with mint spring adds complexity.

Great place and colorful clientele/employees.
author: Adam W.

description: Busy place for weekends, but I always manage to find a seat/ a couch and do my work. LOVE their coffee!
author: Sans S.

description:
5/30/08:
O wow! On the recommendation of Patrick M., I had to try Philz Coffee. I made it a point to stop by here before going to the 'See Jane Run' store.  And what can I say?...This place, Phil, the barista, the coffee, and the menu were not a disappointment at all! I was too mesmerized by the drink options, so I asked the knowledgeable barista what was good here..."Everything!" Then Phil steps in and asked me where I normally get my coffee.  I said at Peet's, and based on that, he told the barista to brew me the Jacob's Wunderbar- a medium brew with a hint of cream and sugar.  I took the first sip and I loved it!  It was smooth and sweet; I definitely could taste the strong-ness and fullness of the beans, but it wasn't too overpowering, it wasn't too diluted or too bitter...it was perfect. Every sip left a hint of flavor in my mouth that made me want to keep sipping. And for some reason, as I babied my coffee, it tasted better each time. 

I'm definitely returning to try the Tantalizing Turkish and Tesora. Loved the homey, unique atmosphere ...definitely not your average coffee shop and they truly live up to their motto of "one cup at a time"

Sorry Peet, Starbucks, and Grove....I'm now in love with Phil!!

6/5/08 update: 
Came back for the Tantalizing Turkish...mmmmmm!! The fresh mint was something new that I've never had before in coffee, besides in a mojito.  Who would have thought to infuse coffee with an herb?? Brilliant because it added so much flavor!!!
author: Lisa C.

description:
[Great Northern waitress pours Agent Cooper's coffee]
Cooper: Wait a minute! Wait a minute!
[sips, sighs blissfully]
This is--
excuse me--a DAMN fine cup of coffee.
I've had I don't know how many cups of coffee in my life, but this is one of the best.

Agent Cooper would love Philz.
author: Sheri R.

description: Boyfriend loves the iced mint mojito and would drink it even in frigidly freezing weather. Being the more sane one, I opt for the mocha tesora. So rich with the chocolate. I tried their chai and it was more milk than chai flavor, so that was a disappointment. I've yet to try everything else. This place is always packed, too. Students (and everyone, for that matter) are practically tethered to this place. Not your typical Starbucks.
author: Tracey T.

description: Good old coffee house the way they used to make them.  But they can get some new chairs and couches.  Wouldn't hurt.  I like getting a mojito iced latte and sitting outside in the benches with a magazine enjoying the sunshine.  Downside is that there are crackies and bums and other freaks that thrives in this neighborhood... so sometimes not as enjoyable as others.
author: Janet S.

description:
If you are suffering from too much blood in the caffeine system, or want a warm place to meet or think,  Philz is your place. 

I live and work within 5 walking minutes of 3 different major chain coffee places, 3 independents and a tea place. And I'll spend 20 minutes to get to Philz. It's that good. The coffee is wonderful and the atmosphere is perfect. Last visit Phil brought some Baklava by the table because he felt like it. Its quiet enough to read but loud enough to have a conversation without disturbing anyone. Its spacious. And even without the free stuff its less than Starbucks

Free WiFi, coffee tastings  Tues/Thurs/Sun afternoon. If its your first time tell them, they have a first time special coffee. Its awesome.
author: Bill S.

description:
A customer asked Phil if he purchased his beans or roasted them on site to which he replied "We steeeal them!"

Ha! It just might be true because I have really never tasted coffee like this before (and to give some insight I have enjoyed a lot of coffee in a lot of places over the years) and the names are not really all that helpful when ordering. 

Just tell Phil or one of the other competent baristas (are they baristas here?) what type of coffee you enjoy and they'll steer you in the right direction and brew you an individual cup right before your eyes. 

If you have time you should sit in Philz and take in the ambiance, nope it's not fancy, and generally I have a strange aversion to overgrown houseplants, but everything at Philz feels authentic and in this day and age of affected ambiance it is a refreshing feeling even if it doesn't conform to my personal tastes.  

Just be warned that you will be all jittery afterwards. These guys aren't afraid of a strong brew!
author: Michelle B.

description:
I'm a total coffee snob.  I can't drink most of the crap served at  the 1,000+ coffee shops SF has to offer.

Phil is my coffee god!  They offer, without a doubt, the best coffee in the city.
Each cup is brewed to order meaning extra fresh deliciousness.

The menu is a little more confusing now since they only list the names without the descriptions.  BUT I can still go up and say: "I want coffee. Make it good. I'll have it sweet."  And they're more than willing to oblige.

I go out of my way to get Philz coffee.  
This place ROCKS.
author: Shayna N.

description:
my go-to coffee spot. since experiencing philz i try to steer clear of the other chain coffee places. i've tried most of their roasts but my favs are the turkish (brewed with cardamom, but add a mint for that kick), philtered soul (amazing rendition of hazelnut), jacobs (for that dark chocolate finish), ecstatic iced (best iced coffee EVER) and... oh hell i love them all! i seriously never had a bad cup o' joe from philz. 

the baristas add the cream & sugar for you so you just need to let 'em know to make it without sugar/cream, a little sweet, medium sweet or very sweet. one time i heard them yell "ridiculously" sweet (yowsers!). you can also substitute with honey instead of sugar.

and their teas do not disappoint either. the istanbul treat and mint tea are yummy goodness with cream & honey. and the philz bagel with organic love & hummus... to die for! who wouldn't love lemon-thyme hummus shmeared on a toasted bagel with a tomato & cucumber slices?!! *drool*

if you're a repeat customer, take advantage of their gift card offer only available through December. $50 gc for $45 (10% off) or a $100 gc for $80 (20% off).

Philz, i am a fan FOR LIFE.
author: Grace V.

description:
The coffee is delicious.
The creamer is wonderful.
And, the people who work there are friendly with a lot of character.
Favorite coffee shop in the city.
author: Raegan T.

description:
The best coffee that can be bought. Second to none.

Here's a piece of advice if you've never been there: Order your coffee, pay for it, then move out of the way so others can place their order. I give this advice because my only beef with the place is the organization of the shop.
author: Neil C.

description: The employees here were really nice, but the coffee was just so-so.  They said they blend coffees from different parts of the world, which I didn't like. There were just too many flavors going on.   The drip process gave it a unique flavor, but it was overly bitter while at the same time weak.  I'd probably try ordering something different if I were passing by again, but I won't go out of my way for it.
author: Nadine F.

description: The coffee here so great! Each cup is made fresh especially for you. The baristas are very friendly and will make sure you get the cup of coffee that's right for you. I had a dark roast blend called Jacob's Wonderbar. It was really bold and rich with a chocolate infusion -so wonderful!
author: Lucia D.

description: I came her for the first time over the weekend and the service was awesome! I ordered their one of their ice coffees and yummerz!! Sooo delicious!! I have to come back!
author: Kim A.

description:
On a recent trip to San Francisco I went to Philz on three consecutive days, and on three consecutive days I had the best coffee of my life. 

The folks who work there are wonderful as well.
author: Jake I.

description:
I put off going to Philz for a while because I was sick of hearing people talk about it.  I was on Philz overload and thought there would be no way it could live up to the hype.  I was burned by Ritual as I'd heard so much (sure the coffee is great) and then once I ventured in the first thing I noticed was a "design excellence" award on the counter - I still think that's hilarious.  

Philz will not be receiving any design awards for their interior but they have the best coffee in SF.  I can't believe I'm saying this but I like it better than Blue Bottle.  I like the concept, you order, they add cream and sugar (so east coast I love it), and you pay.  Great assortment of healthy (hello vegan doughnuts?) and not so healthy baked treats from which to choose.  The people are totally friendly.

The coffee is EXCELLENT.  They serve it hot (thank you!), and literally this coffee should come with a warning because I felt like cleaning the whole house after my one cup.  Yeah!
author: James M.

description:
Philz Coffee suffers from classic Technician's Dilemma.  Or kind of like, the reversed-polarity Technician's Dilemma.

See, every time I come here on my own -- which is always in the morning -- the coffee is fantastic.  I take it black, no sugar, because I want to taste the actual coffee.  And it's great, no matter which mythical blend I order.

And then I bring someone here, generally after I've been hyping the coffee to them like some kind of coffee-hyping dipstick, and we go in the afternoon because that's just when you do things with other people, right, and it's anything but great.  It's all of the things people who didn't like it have said about it:  watery, or "thick and muddy", whatever.

Place-wise, I really dig it.  With all the old wooden furnishings, and lush foliage from the guy who sells houseplants within the cafe, it reminds me of being in Seattle or Portland.  Wifi always available, power outlets occasionally.  I like the mix of people that stay or don't stay, and I feel comfortable spending anywhere between 5 minutes and 5 hours here.

It's not the best coffee I've ever tasted, but it's definitely great.  The inconsistency is a shame.  Try it in the morning and you'll minimize your risk of disappointing, suboptimal brew.
author: Naomi M.

description:
Do you know what is NOT hip, cool, and irreverent these days? Making fun of hipsters! However, making fun of your siblings is always AWESOME, right? 

My brother lurves the biking, but he assures me that he is in NO WAY a hipster. I take his word for this- blood thicker than water, you know. So I schlepped over to Philz on the 49 to deliver him his favorite bike lock that was accidentally in my possession (at least this time no one was SMOKING OUT at the back of the bus, but also the mariachi band wasn't playing, BOO!) as it was convenient for his journey from BART over from the land of stuffwhitepeoplelike.com, aka Berkeley.

Anyway I was a bit confused by the egalitarian/ chaotic lack of lines, also mesmerized by the shelves and shelves of different types of beans- I just got some iced coffee. Then I stared in disgust at VEGAN DONUTS.

If I ever have to go to hell, they will be playing the movie What About Bob in an endless loop and they will make me eat VEGAN DONUTS i cannot even COMPREHEND the disgustingness of this idea, do not even try to make me. OMG.

So. Brother insisted on sharing a vegan cookie- Let me tell ya, I had MUCHO trepidation and GUESS WHAT it wasn't that BAD!!
 "HOLY CRAP this cookie isn't making ME VOMIT" I exclaimed. 
"Yes, sister, vegan cooking really has come along way in the past few years," brother replies.
 *blinks* "You realize that I could say something mean and cutting about you being a vegan hipster white person, but I am not because I am so NICE. Also this iced coffee is awesome."
author: Katie H.

description:
Philz Coffee is what psychedelic dreams are made of. 

It never fails to bring me to a low euphoric groan right before ejecting me into a caffeine triathlon.

While the freshly ground coffee beans are nothing to be ignored, it is really the care in which Philz accomplices prepare each cup of coffee that makes the entire experience a delicacy. Take my advice, relinquish control, walk in with an open mind, and ask them to give you their best stuff. 

And please, do not resist the mint leaf.
author: Meghan R.

description: While walking around the neighborhood one morning killing time while my car's oil was being changed I spied Phillz and decided that a cup of coffee was in order. I was a bit baffled by the huge selection of different coffee roasts so the barista asked for my preferences and then suggested the Jacob's Wonderbar which took about 5min to hand make but was totally KILLER - which was expected for a $3.75 cup of coffee
author: Bumble B.

description: Went to Philz for the first time after hearing about it. The location was clean friendly and not too pricey. Asked for a Mocha and they made it to my specifications. Even though I asked for light chocolate that was 90% of what I could taste.
author: Mike T.

description:
I love the ambiance of this place. However, as a loyal Peet's drinker who buys fresh coffee to brew at home, I feel that while Philz has a vast selection of coffees, none of them come close in flavor to what is available at other places. 

I have a theory...perhaps Philz appeals to coffee drinkers who like their coffee drink with a little sum'n sum'n. The cream, the mint, the personal attention...it's fabulous. But when it gets down to it...the beans, that is, the coffee... just doesn't measure up. I enjoy rich coffee-flavored coffee, with a splash of cream. I don't need a mint leaf and fancy footwork to mask what truly good coffee tastes like. 

That being said, I do enjoy having a venerable establishment like Philz in the hood. The place with all the pictures on the wall, the couches, the hipsters...just makes me feel all warm and fuzzy inside. I just wish they sold decent coffee.
author: kristi c.

description:
O.G. Review, 06/26/06;

The coffee is excellent and Phil is nuts! I used to go there 3 or 4 times a week, passing at least four different coffee places on my way. I'd even dragged a number of friends in, who all became fans. Phil was always really cool to me, even as I was totally skeeved out by his druggy regulars (holdovers from when Phils was a liquor store). 

At some point the lines started getting longer and the price of a cup went up. Then after I'd waited in the queue AND for my brew. Phil got into the habit of offering a taste of my coffee to someone waiting behind me (either by pouring into a 2nd cup or off his crusty spoon). To them he'd say "Doesn't this taste like love?". Did I mention that I'd still yet to pay for the coffee? Phil's sips are expensive and I work for a living. He did this to me like 5 times. 

Finally when my best buddy (whom I had brought there originally) complained that Phil had been doing this to him too the last 3 times he'd been, I hit the road and haven't looked back. 

Five star coffee, no star crazy.

Updates Alert; 12/24/06

Philz iz a Corna Store. Note the seedy irregulars, as well as the Ancient mixerz Philz haz stashedzz in odd cornaz of tha Store. Thizz wud be a shi++y Corna Storezz ta hav I +hinkzz.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Phil'z coffee is a great example of a true runaway commercial success story. This is not a Starbuck's type of store either but they're extremely successful and I truly believe that their coffee can run circles around Starbucks, Pete's, Tully's you name it. 

I've seen it with my own eyes and the next generation is frequenting their coffee shops in massive numbers.  In case you haven't tried the Turkish style of coffee or curious about what it's like I highly encourage trying it. The best coffee I've ever tasted in my life. The taste is more smooth bold (think latte vs coffee) than a typical cup of coffee. Great business model Phil has here. Completely word of mouth marketing and it works because it's prime quality. I hope they're going to follow up on their success with more stores, more products, etc.. can't wait.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
philz!!! THEEEE BEST!!

the iced coffee is my absolute favorite. and wow, that mint sprig is an amazing touch!! 

heaven in a little cup o' goodness!
author: alyssa p.

description:
The first time I went here I ordered a mocha which is how I decide if a place is great or not. I took one sip and was very disappointed. It was bad.  I really wanted to like this place. Then I was told I ordered the wrong thing and I should just order a coffee next time. 

I finally got a chance to try Philz again last week and had to go to there Mission location since their 18th street location closed. Boohoo. It took me an hour & a half to get here but it was worth it! The coffee was amazing. I even think if you don't like coffee you will like Philz coffee the stuff is just that good.

I wish they were closer.... only complaint.
author: Stacy F.

description: I feel wrong and bad for giving Philz a 3 star review but, I just don't feel the flavor of the coffee is on par with my SF favorites.  I'd love for Philz to be more inspiring, more flavorful.  I've tried the Turkish and Jacob's Wonderbrew both several times. While not bad, they both seem too heavy and bitter tasting for my likes.
author: Ivan L.

description:
aaaahhHH Philz!  I love Phil and I love Philz.  This place is awesome...not only does the coffee taste absolutely delectable and pump your veins full of some high octane caffeine - the coffees have cute names too!  Yes. Cute.  I mean, who wants to order an Italian roast or French roast or even that old Fog Lifter when you can get some Jet Fuel or Canopy of Heaven or Philz 'That'?!  Not me.  Brewed by the cup!  With a little secret cream action and a sprig of ming.  Good.  If Phil is actually in the house you get a great smile and warm greeting too.

I've tried some other 'brewed by the cup' coffee, specifically at 24th and Guerrero.  TERRIBLE!  If I knew the name of it I would give it quite the opposite of this review.

*I do miss Gordon's falafel cart.  Those bagels were damn good.
author: Shannon B.

description:
Amazing coffee.  I always have so much energy after a cup, but not in a crazy-person caffeine-binge kind of way.

Made to order cup by cup, so if you're in a hurry, skip it. And it's kind of dark and dreary-- not someplace I really want to hang out.

But the coffee is totally fucking amazing.  I still haven't tried all the varieties, but I aim to.  My coffee is always just *exactly* what I wanted.  Plus they mix in your sugar or cream or whatever for you, which magically ends up tasting so much more incredible than had you done it yourself. 

I have friends who come all the way from Toronto for Philz.
author: Christy T.

description:
It's like falling in love with coffee all over again. 

It's been three days since I was introduced to Philz and I've already begun reshaping my afternoons and lunches around my PM caffeination trip to Philz. 

I just learned that there's a Philz by my new place near the Castro. So f-in excellent.

To the fools whose cups drip, don't you know to always put the seam to the back of the lid? I think Philz cupz are just right - no extra sleeve because it's built in.
author: Tyler M.

description: I have learned that some blends to have spices added to them.  Just wanted to make a note since on my last rieview I said they don't add anything.  You can always ask at the counter if you are curious if there are any extra spices in your blend.
author: Louis C.

description:
After passing Philz on my way to work for years, I finally popped in. Quickly hooked on Philtered Soul. The clientele is a mix of professionals, cops, fire department, and of course lots of hipsters, most of which are smoking out front.  And the hip staff is friendly as hell, tho again, when on break, they are out front smoking too (why are hipsters so dumb?). In general tho, fun, eclectic crowd, several decades away from their spots-on-lung x-ray result.
 
Noticed after a few weeks tho, that I was gaining weight. Finally realized that it was the enormous amount of cream they were putting in the coffee, far more than I would dare if pouring it myself. When I switched to milk or soy, I found my delicious Philtered Soul wound  up tasting bitter and it was easier to notice the flavored coffee flavor. Not so good.

Swore it off a few months ago and am back to Martha's. I did stop in the other day for the full philtered soul milkshake experience. Damn, that is good!
author: k m.

description:
Ducked in randomly during the carnaval parade and discovered coffee nirvana!

If Casablanca was a coffeeshop in San Francisco this would be it...with its timeless vintage feeling...left half has plenty of comfortable seating...including lots of cozy victorian chairs...obligatory books and chess...well-maintained, perfect location for mellow metaphysical conversations...relaxed atmosphere and wonderful coffee aromas inside was a nice counterpoint to the parade.

The right side area is where the magic happens...about dozen people milling around waiting for their fix...breaking the code for proper ordering was difficult for me since I have been weaned on franchise coffeeshops where the order is taken at the register...the 20 choices of different varieties of coffee was overwhelming...when I mentioned my newbie status to the barrista she turned to an older fellow for recommendation...lo and behold, it was the namesake Phil Jaber...he directed me to order the  #19 Tesoro (which appropriately translates as 'treasure' but I wouldn't have been surprised if had been called 'lujuria').

The coffee was brewed one cup at a time...rested on a long church pew while waiting for the barrista's alchemy (a couple minutes seems like an eternity when you are used to starbucks).

The coffee had a meniscal froth since the barrista violently shook the carton of cream before pouring it...when I was handed the cup of coffee I was immediately mesmerized by its intoxicating aromatic halo...this is such stuff dreams are made on. 

Say what you will about making inferences from a single data point, but everything came together in perfect harmony for one brief moment while I savored what may very well have been the single best cup of coffee in the universe!
author: Matthew L.

description: I recently tasted something so wonderful, I had to post an update.  I urge everyone who likes iced coffee and mint to try the Mint Mojito.  It's a super refreshing blend of Philz roasts, served over ice with muddled mint.  Amazing for an afternoon pick-me-up.  Enjoy!
author: Jenna C.

description: Philz so good! (Sometimes love don't fee...) Anyway, the coffee at Philz must be tried to be believed.  If you don't like it, you may not get most of the Mission, but unless you ride a fixie and hate yuppies, who really does?  The point is, Philz is an experience.  Try the Tesora, but don't tell them how you want it, just get it the way they make it - heavy cream, lots of sugar and a mint leaf.  You won't believe the flavors that come out of their single-cup drip coffee.  Seriously, try it.  Even if you are an experienced coffee drinker, you'll catch a buzz and be thirsting for more.  It probably isn't an event for your every day, but it probably is the best cup of coffee in the Mission.
author: Brett C.

description: As friendly as the coffee is delicious. Definitely coming back to explore more of these unique and awesome brews =)
author: Cooper J.

description:
This review is for the mail-order coffee only. 

I am a coffee fiend-always looking for the next greatest  coffee to try. I hopped off the Starbucks bandwagon years ago after they got too big and "chainy". 

Through Yelp, I have found Philz.  It is as delicious as everyone says it is-even when it is made in my own little coffee maker at home.  I ordered the Tesora-smooth, light and fresh tasting-not a burnt bean in the bunch. Philz has 20+ coffees on their web site and they will grind them however you wish. The web site has great descriptions of each coffee. Each is a little different-nothing too wild-just good tasting coffee. They have light, medium and dark blends and roasts.  I wish that I could experience the coffee first hand at the store, but thank goodness for mail order.  My next order will include their Tantalizing Turkish-coffee with a "subtle touch of Cardamom"  in it-sounds great.  If you are tired of "chain coffee" and are willing to brew your own-if you aren't in the SF area-try Philz mail order-delicious!
author: Mary S.

description:
The most fabulous hot chocolate in the world...yes, I have checked.
its a sipping chocolate..which means that you could go into a chocolate induced coma if you gulp this Guittard mouthful seasoned with cinnamon and marsh mellows too quickly....thick rich decadent good!!! The people who work here are angels. Beautiful and angelic children that deliverer this nectar of the Gods!!!
  OH MY GOD YUM! and the small is enough to fuel you through your chocolate haze of a day...groovy couches that slouch in all the right places, trippy mags to enjoy, and the locals are real locals! not the shipped in extras that starbucks hires!!   and OH YES...the coffee rocks too!!!  One cup at a time...a good rule for coffee  and  life!!  xoxo
author: Christina M.

description: Mint mojito iced mocha... Enough said! Paired w dynamo donuts!
author: E A.

description:
the iced mint coffee mojito is one the best coffee inventions ever.  this original philz is my first stop on every trip to the bay area.  

i am a big fan of his original blend and the wonderbar.  both have been in my espresso machine at home.  i am trying the anesthesia blend now.  

the blueberry vegan donuts are unbelievable. 

parking is surprisingly not too bad in that hood. 

the crowd is appropriately mission funky and eclectic.  

i picked up a bag of the philtered soul, and it wasn't my fav. it wasn't bad at all and it certainly brewed a nice cup.  it just had a flavor that wasn't right for me. 

my only other complaint, and it's not REALLY a complaint, but they don't do italian style espressos.  so if you are looking for that little cup with the crema, this won't be your joint.  but if you exceptionally flavorful cups of coffee, or unbelievably well crafted blends for your own machine, you won't go wrong.

one more note, had a nice convo with phil in the store yesterday.  nice guy.  great coffee. i'm a fan.
author: Jim P.

description:
(( AMENDED POST )) - 07/23/2012
I am amending my review of Philz. In part I feel that my initial reaction to Philz coffee was that I was not finding my taste among the wide array of beans they offer. 

I know have found at least one "It'z the Best" roast I love that has the earthyness & depth I particularly enjoy in a medium roast...

Cheers,
Joey


(( ORIGINAL POST )) - Sometime in 2011
Philz is better than you average cup but they over roast there beans and burn the complexity out.

I made four attempts for a nutty / earthy medium roast and ended up with plain French Roast(ala burned) and acrid flavor each time. I'll keep trying, and maybe check out their lighter roasts however if you want a satisfying cup in SOMA in what I like to call the coffee triangle then go to "The Creamery" on 4th & Townsend or to Cento(Pr'nc'd Chento) in the alley off Townsend at Ritch Street.
author: Joey N.

description:
i LOVE philz ICED MINT MOJITO COFFEE!!

and i love how each cup is made one at a time. the beans are grinded, roasted, and prepared individually with each order

so long starbucks, you'll only be my choice of coffee when there isn't a philz in town

im officially addicted to philz!
author: Katherine C.

description:
Sunday afternoon. 4:35 PM. I'm sitting on their couch with my laptop enjoying the free 6 piece jazz ensemble, sipping a perfectly conceived chai tea, the cafe's namesake is napping quietly on the other couch, I'm exchanging flirting glances with the HOT lady reading her book next to me, a little kid and puppy are engaged in a seriously cute staredown.

Community is hard to come by in this part of the mission. It's definitely found here. I want to wake up Phil and give him a big bear hug for creating this wonderful environment. 5 stars.

Yes. I know it's a chain now...blessed so.
author: John T.

description:
I'd been meaning to come back to Philz for over a year, since the first time I set foot in the place. I was in the neighborhood for Carnivale yesterday, & I finally had my chance.

It was better than I remember it being. Granted, the first time I was here was at 6:30am on a Sunday morning after a particularly raucous all-night house party at a friend's place in the 'hood. I cut out with another friend who lived just around the corner from Philz & we wandered over & strolled in as they threw open their doors on a Sunday morning. We sat & let the caffeine go to work, & talked for a few hours as the church crowd began to stroll in. Eventually I felt the pull, so I moseyed up the street to catch the 24 bus home. 

Yesterday I had a small cup of Wunderbar, & I honestly don't think I've ever had a cup of dark roast that was even close to being so delicious. It was rich, chocolatey, & naturally sweet, somehow. I've been daydreaming about drinking another cup ever since. 

If it didn't seem like such an insurmountable task, I'd make a play on convincing Phil to expand his corner empire up to the Western Addition. But when in a city like this, with coffee shops seemingly popping up on every corner...well, it seems like quite a hurdle. 

I'll just have to make a special effort to head down to the Mission & see Phil & the gang more often.
author: Pete J.

description:
The coffee is strong but smooth. 
The vibe is hippie but urban. 
The tunes are diverse but cool. 
The neighborhood is hip but divey. 
The place is grubby but clean. 
I like Philz.
author: Melinda K.

description: I am a scientist, and as a scientist I need mad amounts of caffeine to carry on. Its safe to say I know my coffee. I was a bit hesitant to grab some coffee at a place that serves NO espresso  (I got some crazy looks when I asked for an Americano my first time here) but I was blown away by the amazing coffee served here. The iced coffee is amazing, and the mocha is pretty damn good. This place has become my go to coffee place. I would encourage everyone to give it a try... you'll get addicted.
author: Beatriz A.

description:
This is where Philz started as a corner market and it all exploded when the man in the fedora himself changed his business model to selling this singular coffee - one cup at at time.

'Course this has been euro coffee for centuries, but it's new to our Starbucks-centric country. It's all about the drug of coffee - a dizzying array of blends, obsesssive preparation of your one cup. At Philz in the Mission, you almost feel like you're back in an Amsterdam coffee shop and should be able to order up a gram along with your Sumatra. Yes, it's addictive.
author: maureen f.

description:
I love Seattle and I love the coffee here but Philz more than holds its own with nearly every overblown Seattle shop with a fraction of the hubris.

The Turkish coffee I had was divine and when it's on my short list of places to go ASAP when I'm in town.
author: Alan F.

description: couldn't imagine a cooler place to get coffee. line was long but weirdly efficient. ecstatic iced coffee was amazing! that said, it was amazing in more of a milk shake sort of way, so when asked about cream and sugar, they aim to make you a desert even when they say medium sweet.
author: James D.

description: my favorite coffee in SF..hands down...! Tesora "sweetened" coffee FTW! Philz Coffee = real coffee
author: Mark K.

description:
Best coffee ever.  They (as I'm sure you've read) make it one cup at a time.  Don't feel guilty and get it with turbinado and cream...and a sprig of mint.  The cup will make you wish you could have more.  Don't drink anymore or you will get the shakes.  

I've seen some really great Jazz here, and have a friend that works here.  Other than that, the seating is lacking, and the ambiance is not the greatest, but the coffee blows it all away.  I can't get coffee anywhere else now.
author: Ben H.

description: I am such a fan! This place take a little bit of time to make your coffee it it is a perfect cup every time. Definitely worth the extra couple of minutes!
author: Shannon M.

description:
Sofas Couches and Loveseats Galore!! THIS makes a coffee place.

Did i mention they have the tastiest coffee I've ever had? I hate coffee but i love Philz.
author: III I.

description: I've never taken part in this store's services because I was told by my roommate, who worked there, that there were rats and cockroaches frequenting the store - and being ignored or only treated by shoe-smashings from Phil. That alone makes me want to call the Health Department.
author: Melanie P.

description: Let me start by saying San Francisco is not my type of city, I don't like the over liberal protesters, the pastel colored houses, or the over dramatic "art". I hate everything about this city, except Philz Coffee. Now that says a lot. The tesaro is hands down the best cup of joe I've had, I just can't bring myself to give 5 stars because, I really don't like SF... Oh, and the line is kind of a cluster.
author: Claudia Z.

description: Tried the pastries here and the tea. (I don't really drink coffee). Croissants were are good and big. Tea here was EXCELLENT!! I ordered both the Philz Chai Tea and the Mint Tea. They ask if you want it not too sweet, unsweetened, or sweet. They use honey. Then after it was made, they made me taste it to make sure it was good and of course, it was perfect. Also asked if I wanted cream in it. To my surprise I found mint leaves in my tea as I was seeping it, which made it tastes soo much better. Steeping organic mint leaves=the best! everything they use at this place is organic.
author: Liwei Y.

description:
Philz is something extremely special if you like coffee. I've really never had coffee so good, so fresh and so complex. Some of the blends are almost a wine like experience with flavors, hints, aromas, and complexity beyond what we usually imagine from coffee. The turkish brew I had there was a mind boggling experience not for the faint of heart, but the house blend and the Philharmonic are a fulfill your highest expectations for coffee without going beyond your comfort zone. Philz is a place I expect I will be able to explore for years to come and continue exploring new flavors. 

Going beyond the coffee, Philz is a great place to hang out with couches, live music, photos and art. 

The staff varies from wonderfully friendly conversationalists (Phil included), to total hipster doofus pricks who can manage to ignore you for 5 minutes plus while the finish their Clerks like conversation, but that is a minor inconvenience for coffee this good.
author: Karl L.

description: Disgusting... They use heavy cream. Honestly, I still liek the turkish but I can only have it once a while now. I usually go up the street to Cafe Venice or I go to the castro coffee company in the castro for coffee now
author: Hubert L.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinking, and maybe it's just the hype over this place, but I actually like their coffee. Couches, tables with chairs, sofas, church pews, outdoor seating - take your pick. They also offer free wifi so you can sip on some delicious coffee, snack on a pastry and go online.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
How have I not reviewed this place? I'm ashamed of myself. Really.

Philz is the kind of coffee-shop every neighborhood needs. It's eclectic, comfortable, cozy, and has some of the best damned coffee I've ever raised to my lips.

I remember trying it for the first time about a year ago. My roommate was a huge fan and gave me my first sip of a Philz "Mocha" Tesora and I was sold. Dark, smooth, perfectly-sweetened. These people know what they're doing with coffee.

Philz is also my first experience with the brew-by-the-cup method of coffee. They have a ridiculous amount of coffees to choose from, and I'm sure anyone can waltz right in and find something that suits their needs. But beware: the dark ones are strong. Hella strong. You'll be jolt-y for a bit, and you've been forewarned. 

The atmosphere is ecelectic: mis-matched old couches and tables, random bits of furniture. Fliers for all sorts of going-upons taped to the walls and windows. Cleanliness *might* not be their thing, but it's totally comfortable. I think the place must have been a corner-store in a previous life...the big 'fridges on one wall suggest as much.

They also have People's (vegan) Donuts here. Scorsies.
author: Danyell K.

description:
Philz is not regualr coffee people!  Philz is at its own level!

Philz is art....  Tesora is really a treasure....  I treasure every sip of it.

The amazing blend of cardamom and Philz fine pick of beans in the Philharmonic is one of my favorite!

And the Silken Spendor.. ohh soo silky smooth.  

And last time we went, Phil was actually brewing our coffee, and he received a thumbs up from the bf.

The bf didn't even drink coffee prior Philz, but now he's a fan :)
author: Gigi T.

description:
I HEART Philz (only at this location though).

I miss great coffee... strong, flavorful, Italian or Turkish style. Americans have been deprived for way too long. I blame Starbucks teaching you all bad habits. And believing that espresso coffees are 'premium' (that's such BS - go visit humble little Sydney sometime).

So why do I love Philz?

... Because it taste like coffee
... Because the ROI of caffeine vs. cost per cup is on my side
... Because the girl behind the counter is too cool for school, but nice enough to dispense her nuggets of coffee wisdom
... Because I can sit on the recycled furniture for hours and discuss the meaning of life
... Because I took a then boyfriend there and it changed his life (then we broke up, that's another story)
... because I can pick up a little something across the road, at the Mexican bakery, and take it into Philz so it goes with my strong wonderful coffee

That is why I keep going back, even though its in the middle of no where.
author: Joyce L.

description: Cafes like Phil'z make me prefer cafes over libraries to do classwork at. Very friendly place, good music, nice environment, good variety of coffees, and friendly studious customers. I think the studious customers is the best part because it placed me in an environment of people working hard and knowing to be quiet. Everyone is busy with things where they aren't a distraction. Love environments like that. People use a cafe for work and not a place to be noisy. Def. coming back, but I'll make sure to come back in the day time. Parking is difficult to find around here.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
What can I say that 403 previous reviews haven't already said?

This. Is. The. Best. Coffee. Ever. Brewed.

I regularly contemplate driving 9 hours from San Diego for a cup of freshly brewed, individually made Jacob's Wonderbar.  It's serious. Anytime I have a friend go to SF I beg them bring me back a pound of it.  I've also had the pleasure of trying the Mint Mojito.  Never in a million years would I think to put mint in coffee, but alas, that's what Philz is there for - to make you rethink your favorite steaming beverage.

For you first timers - please let them make the coffee the way it was meant to be made. Don't get Splenda. Don't refuse the cream. Just let them do their thing. You won't regret it. If you can't get whole bean and grind it yourself, I recommend getting it ground course and using a french press at home.
author: Holly H.

description:
I don't belive caffeine is physically addictive, but Philz coffee is!  I've now tried every flavor listed on their board, and my favorite is the New Manhattan.  I heard one of the employees referring to it as New Man, so now I shorten it to Newman when I order.

I have friends who swear by the Turkish and Ether blends, which are also both very good.

In my opinion, places like Blue Bottle and Ritual represent excellent coffee, but in the end, it's just excellent coffee.  Philz, on the other hand, is completely different and completely special.  If you've never been, go to the one on 24th.
author: Eddie K.

description: Might have been the best cup of coffee I have ever had. Freaking out that I am almost done, lol. My finance feels the same so its just not my caffeine withdrawals.
author: arthur s.

description:
You'll know Phil when you see him.  He's the older gentleman who knows he owns that corner in the Mission.  He'll stare you down and challenge you with this question, "Have you tried my coffee?"  The answer should always be "no," because he'll insist on making it "special" for you.

The beans are ground and filtered individually for each cup.  If its not made by Phil, it wlll be attended to by one of his hipster disciples, who he's brainwashed into taking special care with each cup.  I love these people for it, but let's face it, they're weird about coffee.

The best cup of coffee in the city.  At $3 a cup, it fucking better be.
author: Jackson R.

description:
I think they put crack in their coffee because I wake up thinking about it!!! But really . . . . great great coffee. If you hit the 24th location you'll meet Phil, and can clearly see how passionate he is about coffee. That is also a good location to chill out, read, piddle around on the computer, etc. Sunday mornings they have music (typically) so its a nice way to start the day. Good crowd too . . . . Mission-Portrero folk. My 'hood does rule :)

I recommend the Hazelnut Creme .  . . yum!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
There's no place else I'd rather be than when I'm sipping my Philharmonic  #3 and listening to the horn section of the 8-Legged Monster.

BEST COFFEE IN SF!!!

If you're after dimension, Philz' coffee offers that experience. Fuller than Peet's-- different than Blue Bottle.
author: Dianne N.

description:
Interesting coffee! I went with a decaf since it was after 2 pm. And that last thing anyone needs is Sonam on coffee! It keeps me up the whole night! And then the next day, I am cranky!!!!

The taste was strange at first since it reminded me of drinking chai in India. I do want to go and try it again. Nice ambiance, Phil and his helpers were really friendly!
author: sonam d.

description: Iced mint mojito was the bomb today on this sunny warm day in SF.  Made a trip during my lunch break to the original Philz coffee in the Mission and it was all worthwhile.  The large cup of ice coffee was not enough and wish it came in a supersize.  Full of mint flavor with the lovely taste of drip coffee...you can taste the rich flavor of the bean...unlike Starbucks (bleh).  This location is not too far from Humphrey Slocombe and has a nice bohemian style sitting area to sit with your laptop.
author: Lisa W.

description: Is Philz coffee a San Francisco landmark yet? I heard the local tour companies are including Philz Coffee in their City tour route.  Great coffee! I bet you can't just have one cup..........
author: Betsy W.

description:
Some may say $3.50 is expensive for a cup of coffee. I say $3.50 is expensive to waste on a piece of crap cappuccino from some second rate chain coffee shop when you can get the most delicious, perfectly cream and sugared coffee for the same price. Trust me, you won't even miss the foam, its just filler anyways.

Bonus for the fact that those working behind the counter are not pretentious baristas that scoff if you don't know what a wet or dry cappuccino is. They're all so friendly, from the one taking your order to the one taking your money.

Plus, who doesn't like when people replace "s" with "z"? Its just so quirky.
author: sholeh m.

description: Full disclosure: I'm not a fan of coffee even when it's deluted or very doctored up, but I must admit I really liked the Mocha I had. Best of all it didn't upset my stomach (which almost always happens when I consume anything with coffee in it).
author: Jacob P.

description:
Mighty interesting reading these Philz reviews.  I guess you either love it or hate it which says something about the product.  Philz coffee is just straight out bold and strong as hell.  I happen to like my coffee strong.  Many years ago, when I was a younger man with a younger man's kidneys, I loved to drink a cup of Spinelli coffee every day.  Spinelli was the first local roaster chain that I remember outside of North Beach.  There was one just kitty corner to my apartment in the Castro (it's now a Tully's).  Anyway, it was fabulously strong and dark, like drinking dirt, and I LOVED it.  Unfortunately I eventually discovered that, aside from making me a kind of a jerk at work, it also started giving me back problems.

*sigh*

Now I reserve my coffee for once a week, usually on Saturdays.  Quality over Quantity, that's my motto.  To that end, after religiously driving across town to Blue Bottle in Hayes Valley, I decided to branch out and try some other alternatives.  Phliz is my current favorite and, even though Blue Bottle still has a special place in my caffeine lovin' heart, Philz is my favorite vice.  I have been branching out lately but still my favorite is the Tesora where they cream and sugar it for you.  It is an extremely pleasurable cup of joe although I can't drink anything larger than a small for fear of grinding all my teeth to a pulp.  It's is some serious stimulant.

Now, I should also mention that, after reading the 7X7 article on the micro-roasting phenomenon happening in SF right now, a major factor in the enjoyment of your cup of coffee is the culture in which you are consuming it.  For instance, Philz is all about the drip coffee, one cup at a time, ground per person with the blend of your choice.  You don't come here for the espresso as far as I can tell, that's not Philz market.  You come for the drip.  You want espresso, read one of my other reviews which, when I write it, will illustrate the better locale for an espresso.

But for drip, Philz is a favorite of mine and, as you can tell from the rest of these reviews, it's worth coming in, just to see if it's the kind of thing you dig.
author: Torbin B.

description:
When i go to Philz coffee (which I do to infrequently) - (Hey!  What can i say, i won a years worth of Peets coffee in a raffle) i say' "hey Phil, hook me up."  he makes me the latest brew he is working on.

Now Phil has been at that location for over 20 years.  I have lived around the corner for 11 years or so.   I watched this truly distinguishable store go from one of the three corner stores on the corner of Folsom and 24th to something quite different.  And still it was always unique because it had -Phil of course!    First the cigarettes left, than most of the hard booze.  
the Junk food started dwindling as did most of the other foods that aren't cafe food.  It changes every single time that you go in there.  Plants and trees are being sold, plants and trees are not being sold. There is a new shelving unit, then it is gone.  It is a work always in progress.  

But the coffee remains the same.  It is the star of this establishment.  Phil spent some time getting a degree in Coffee-ology.  He is serious about his brews!  he is a one of a kind wonderful person.

I Heart PhilZ!
author: Leslie I.

description: When planning a nice, relaxing day after a stressful midterm or final, I trek over to Philz in my pajamas. It's delicious. I loved the Tantalizing Turkish but I now drink Ether and Tesora the most. All the roasts are delicious, though. They're never bitter, never burnt-tasting... Just delicious! :) The Berkeley location in particular is my favorite because of it's large area to sit back and relax/read/whatever. Sometimes they have live paino music. :)
author: Mike I.

description: Interesting menu, but I take my coffee black.  It was good, but definitely did not knock my socks off.
author: Yeeman N.

description:
Yeah, Philz. Awesome.

Get it with cream, get it with honey, get it with however they think is best and don't forget one of those tiny little mini donuts.
author: Katherine B.

description:
I am so happy that I can easily walk to this location from my new apartment and get my fix.  Maybe being so accessible could become a problem because Philz is strangely addictive.  Halfway through a cup-o-Philz, you realize that what you are drinking has to be illegal somewhere because it tastes so good...or maybe it's the fact that you suddenly transform into the most perky productive person you have ever known...and you almost annoy yourself.  I am still not convinced that there is only caffeine in my coffee....but, you will NEVER hear me complain about a noticeable spike in energy that lasts for hours. =)

While I feel like Philz deserves 5 stars for the coffee selection and fabulous brewing technique (complete with creaming and sugaring to your liking)...there was a rather angry vegan in the store that was demanding to know how in the world a vegan donut could be made.  The coffee brewing professional behind the counter dryly explained that they were called vegan because there was a lack of animal products in them and smiled sweetly as she walked away.  This was not good enough for the vegan...she wanted ingredients! Now!  

Though I kinda think most vegans become militant and angry because they are secretly starving, I kind of sided with her on this one.  Please make the ingredients available for your bakery items.  There are lots of special diets out there that could benefit from this information (i.e. gluten allergy, vegan, nut allergies, etc.).  In a progressive city like ours that loves to know where food comes from (sustainable, organic, local), I don't think this is too much to ask.  Plus, the poor hungry vegan would have been able to actually eat a donut with a clear conscience.  All that aside, I heart  Philz and I can't wait for my next cup.
author: Sarah B.

description:
some coffee is silky, some coffee is flat
some coffee is milky, some black
I prefer mines silky, full-bodied and black
not too bitter, oily, or too much like crack
and when I can afford it, to Philz Ill come back
author: Jen L.

description:
Strong, bold drip coffee one cup at a time with some Blackstar comin' through the speakers -- it doesn't get much better than this.

Walking through the mission East of S Van Ness feels like walking through another country to me sometimes, and I love it.  Philz is right on the corner of 24th and Folsom with wonderful tall trees hugging it, and I just want to take pictures of the whole thing.  It's how I imagine stumbling upon a cafe in Uruguay would feel.

Inside keeps up the whole aura of South America with sky mural ceilings and friendly tropical plants.  The whole atmosphere of the place is the kind of different that makes it okay that I'm unemployed and unable to travel.

And now to the coffee!  I don't know much, but I know that I like savory coffee that leaves roasted nutty flavors on my tongue, and the Tesora (house specialty) excels.  The baristas were friendly and knowledgeable and ready with recommendations based off my poor uneducated coffee preference descriptions.  And with a menu of 20+ drinks, I'll be coming back to try more.

I'm totally drinking in the vibe.
author: Alec D.

description: Nothing beats Philz coffee. Love their tesora, itz the best, ambrosia and farmer's cheese!
author: Regine G.

description:
Philz Philz Philz...Look their coffe is OK. Tasty, they make it one cup at a time blah blah blah....I went in to this location for my first Pilz experience and the cup I got was OK. Really just OK, not magic in a cup or the most spectacular thing I've ever had....If you read all the other reviews they say how it was an experience that was out of this world, really? No. it wasn't. It's just OK. 
Obviously the major problem wasn't just there OK coffee, it was the people that worked there that ruined my experience. They were rude snooty, pretentious, and who I assumed was actually Phil that was working who was the biggest monkey in the place. Yelling at the customers and his workers like it was some kind of Soup Nazi fantasy that we was living out, but since his coffee is just OK people are suppose to suck his balls because his coffee is tasty. Wrong. Not worth it. Waste of money. Time. Just don't go because, there are plenty of places to get coffee with out any attitude at all. If you're willing to sacrifice any kind of personal comfort for OK coffee then go for it. I'm not and I know other's agree. 
I hope you go out of business Phil, end up on the streets of San Francisco so you'll just be another crazy mumbler on the streets that people ignore. Get over yourself you ugly old man.
author: Tim G.

description: I travel the country and look for great coffee shops.  Philz is now tied for first.  Their Coffee is amazing!!!
author: Steven Z.

description:
Best coffee I've ever had, I totally go out of my way for a cup whenever I can! I tried Bluebottle which everyone raves about, and it's hell of good, but it doesn't get me excited like Philz does. If you haven't tried Philz yet, DOOOO EEEETTT!!!

They've got something like 19 different roasts to choose from; each order ground and dripped one cup at a time. My favorites are the Soooo Good (a full-bodied, full-flavored light roast with low acidity) and the Mocha Tesora (which is, basically, a mocha. a fantastic one). 

They will ask if you want cream and sugar. Say yes. They will then cream and sugar it for you. I advise you to let them handle it (even if you think you're this hot-shit hardcore coffee drinker who knows whats best for your coffee) because they know exactly what they're doing and they do a fabulous job of it.

BTW if you see a yellow-frosted donut in the pastry case, grab it! Something about the way that lemony frosting dissolves on your tongue is so refreshing and compliments any of the coffees really well.
author: Stephen L.

description: I usually go to this location or the Van ness one(only cuz this is closer). I used to like Soo Good when I was a caffeine junkie and was trying everything on the Philz menu. After a while, my taste buds have finally settled for Ether and Tesora (House Blend). I usually get it very light on cream and very light on sugar. For those who is used to 2%milk or fat free milk, I'd suggest trying it light or very light with the cream instead. It really brings out the lovely taste of the coffee!
author: A L.

description:
Recently moved to the hood, and I love this joint. Really is much better than espresso drink places that sometimes burn the shot and make the coffee too hot to sip. Plus this joint is locally owned, a block from my crib, and they let me take my dog in there. Now if I could just find work so I can go there every morning......

MUAH! 
annette
author: Devi G.

description:
Note to self: line all internal organs with steel before imbibing Philz coffee.  
I hesitantly walked up to the cashier and said "large coffee please.?.?"  He tilted his head in that poor-thing kind of sympathetic look and said "first time here?"  I responded with a humble nod.  He turned to the barista and said "Make her a cup of coffee that will blow her mind."  He asked about milk and sugar and just how sweet I wanted it and by golly, it did blow my mind.  Unfortunately that's not the only thing that blew up because of it.  It is entirely possible that what the cashier (who was hot) said to the barista was in code and what it really meant was "Let's see how long she lasts until her face contorts in discomfort and she makes a bee-line for the potty."  
TMI Kelly E.  TMI.
author: ellyk E.

description:
Wow, wow, and wow!!!

I've been here well over a dozen times (and am actually surprised I haven't reviewed it yet!)

I was first brought here by my boyfriend, an avid coffee fan.

I love the fact that each cup of coffee is brewed individually.  You will ALWAYS have a fresh cup.  Keep in mind that means this isn't a quick, in-and-out coffee joint as a result.  

Their blends are incredible!!!  They have a large menu and I would highly recommend experimenting.

Some of my favorites include: Philharmonic, Ether, and Ambrosia.

Bear in mind that they use manufacturer's cream, which means that your coffee will taste incredible, will be extremely addicting, and will make you fat.  Very, very fat.  I had to change to regular milk!

Their prices aren't the lowest, but the quality is superb, well worth the price of admission.  When they finish making your drink, they have you taste it to make sure you like it...  Yeah!!!  Who does that?!

Come to Philz if you want to try some delicious coffee!  And Phil is a pretty cool guy too.  Always has a smile on his face!  I guess I'd be smiling too if I was making that much money... :)
author: Jess R.

description:
Move over Blue Bottle there is a new fedora wearing sheriff in town...name is Philz. I  went out of my morning way to try this coffee and it was definitely worth it! 

Soooo Good! That's the roast I tried- the name says it all!  I will be back to try the iced coffee and the Mocha Tesora.
author: Sarah B.

description: I don't know how I existed before meeting you, Mint Mojito Iced Coffee, but I know it wasn't pretty.  Now that I know that you exist, plain coffee just doesn't do it for me and I wake up dreaming about you and your minty refreshing deliciousness.  So enamored am I that I am driving to Berkeley today to seek out my nearest Philz for another hit of amazing.  I don't care what my coffee at home thinks; we were meant to be together.
author: Liss D.

description:
A mint leaf and hella cream doesn't mean GOOD coffee. It means that your trying to mask the flavor of something gross. Why do you think people make mixed drinks with shit and make straight ones with quality booze?

They do have chess boards though.
author: Joe G.

description: I will honestly say that I have never been here or tried this place. I am only giving it 5 stars because the default picture of the owner (Philz) looks like Walter from Breaking Bad. If I ever go here I will call him "Heisenberg". Just saying. Haha!
author: Chris Q.

description:
I  stopped into the mission district shop while visiting a friend in SF and had a couple different delicious brews to-go and both were quite tasty and fresh (albeit the first one wasn't able to overcome the partying I did the night before :) ).  

Even though we had our coffee to go, it seemed like there were enough places for a small hipster army to sit...and it looked like there was one forming at the time.

I also decided to pick up a few half-pound bags before my flight home and was lucky enough to pick the Tesora which is their crazy good house blend.  I liked it so much that I went online when I got back to Austin and ordered a ton more which got here in record time...only 3 days!  Fedora hats off to you Phil.
author: Jason G.

description:
Strongest cup of coffee I've ever loved.

And the home of the ONLY coffee I have tried that reminds me of Fruity Pebbles.  

Yup, Fruity Pebbles.

Service is getting warmer, and the curly long haired number makes miracles when she is behind the coffee.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
It's worth noting the opinions on Philz are either wholly positive or else wholly negative (though the overall bulk of the responses clearly lean positive). There's very little "middle ground" and I think that reflects how strongly people hold an opinion about coffee (whereas, I just can't imagine you'd have such a strong swing of opinions over a sandwich shop). 

Personally, I love Philz coffee: the #1 with sugar and cream. I think they make a much stronger and much more complex and rich cup of coffee than any other cafe I've found in SF. I think the unique flavor of his coffee is precisely why people love it or hate it - it won't remind you of Peet's or any other generic coffee chain. Philz is Philz. 

I haven't been to Ritual yet but I have been to Blue Bottle on numerous occassions. BB can make a good drip but they change their beans all the time so you don't always get the same cup twice whereas I appreciate the consistency at Philz. BB's mocha is overpriced and dull compared to Philz. That said, I do think BB is pretty good. Just not as good as Philz. 

Just to note: I live within 5 minutes of five cafes but I will get in my car and drive across town for a cup of Philz. Yeah, I'm that addicted. 

By the way, for those who found his coffee too sweet - they ALWAYS ask if you want sugar and cream. You can always say no and then add what you want, your way. 

My only complaint about Philz is that not all the baristas there will knock out the same cup of coffee. I usually prefer to have Phil or his son make my cup and sometimes, I'll get back a so-so cup from one of the other folks who work there or at the 18th st. location. It's rare that I get a mediocre cup but it will happen when the sugar/cream mixture is out of whack.
author: Oliver W.

description:
I'll agree with an earlier reviewer that Phil can be a bit creepy, but as a member of the "target" demographic of young women, the service is always excellent and I've never minded the extra attention. 

It is a VERY STRONG cup of coffee. Take it with cream, even if you normally drink black, as I do. 

I'm not sure I'd start off every morning with Philz (can't now that I live in Philly), but it's one of the places that reminds me of SF and how much I miss the city.
author: Tullia F.

description:
I hate this place ... they suck $6.50 of my money every week now.  I can't get my Saturday or Sunday started without it.

But for that $6.50, I get the best damn coffee ever.  My favorites are the Julie's Ultimate or the Wunderbar.
author: Ankur P.

description:
Really good coffee.  But its not super awesome blow your mind off the planet .. just good coffee.    Well, i had the Jacob's something something, for the record.

Atmosphere and service is average for coffee shops in the mission.
author: chad n.

description:
I am brave enough to be one of the few lone dissenters.
It's good but it's not going to change your life. Sometimes I think people want to like something because everyone else likes it and thats how I felt about Philz.
Also the ordering process for a caffeine deprived NOOB was confusing and my barrista sort of made me feel like an ass. Who needs that???
Yeah I will give it ONE more try because I'm eternally optimistic...and I like coffee.
author: Catty C.

description:
It's been my ritual on the weekend to throw the headphones on and walk to phils for the jacob's wonderbar or the mocha tesora. The coffee is very rich and strong, you will be able to do any one of the following after drinking:

1. ALL your laundry
2. Clean the bathroom
3. Have sporadic bursts of conversation with the roomates 
4. Play any video game and complete it within 2 hours
5. Finish that freelance job in 5 hours instead of 10
6. Get the courage to go to the gym but reconsider after you've ran your first mile.
7. Type out a LIST just like this averaging 150 words per min

It's great coffee, just try it out - 
-t
author: Tony G.

description:
I had a chai here that was made to my sweetness preferences PURRfectly. AND the caffeine kick left a boot print on my ass.

Staff was super friendly and the couches and table are DAH best. Gather with all the other unemployed folks midday and avoid the morning crowds. 

Not a classic for the wrong reasons. Stellar.
author: Miel H.

description:
Now this is real coffee!!!! Strong, put hair on your chest, throw your head back and holler, "I'm a coffee drinker!" coffee. And the coffee barrista--I have a huge crush.

My partner is so addicted to this place, he drives across town to get their coffee. It's sooooo good.
author: Cate F.

description:
The Ether was the best dark roast i've had in recent memory. the chica behind the counter suggested in and it was served fabulously.

one star off for being another place in SF with the damn door open in DECEMBER. i shivered once the coffee tweak passed.
author: Clover Dan ..

description:
These people are so full of themselves it is laughable.  Several weeks ago I went in with my friend and we ordered two soy lattes.  The barista said they don't have lattes, they have something similar that tastes better.  I said ok... make two of them, one with sugar.

He makes the coffees and I ask him which one has the sugar and he says both of them do.  He then remakes them and we taste them. 
He asks what we think and we tell him these dont' taste anything like soy lattes. He says... "well, they taste better then soy lattes".  I said to him, "no,  they don't taste better,  they taste lousy".  He just smiled.
 We left the place and dumped them in a trash can.  

Guys,  check your egos before you go to work.  Your smugness is not at all appealing.  We'll never go back there.
author: Craig A.

description:
Umm WOW. I was taken to this place which was completely out of our way (we were going to the airport to drop someone off from san mateo to oakland) to get the "best coffee in the whole world" i was thinking what a waste it's coffee...BUT IT'S NOT JUST COFFEE. 

it takes a little while to brew which is well worth the wait. I had the ambrosia and it is coffee of the gods. so delicious and not like any coffee you've tasted. and the mint leaf? i've never had coffee with a mint leaf in it and it was WONDERFUL. 

SO worth the excursion i would be hooked on coffee if there was one near me everyday but for now i'll have to save my carbon points and go only when i'm close.
author: sophie p.

description:
AYE-MAYEZING

Each coffee cup is individual brewed and made just for you.

Its rich of flavor, lots of care and personal attention is added to the cup as the barista is preparing it for you.

The Iced Coffee Mojito is by FAR the best iced coffee that I have had in my coffee consuming career.
author: Z L.

description:
I have to hook up my man Phil with 5 stars, I just can't help it.  The "one cup at a time" motto works well.  Phil asked me years back, "Where did you have your favorite cup of coffee?"  Places like Atlas Cafe, Last Laugh Coffee House and The Little Spot cafe came to mind.  I tried Philz coffee, and it was damn good!  Who woulda thought to throw some mint in there.

More than the coffee, Phil is creating a good space in the neighborhood.  He has a nice upright piano, some good books and chessboards.  More than anything else, Phil is a great man.  I wish him the best of luck...one cup at a time.
author: Eric S.

description:
This place is so awesome! You can get "one cup at a time" at lots of little coffeeshops, but I have never had a barista (i'm using the more snobby coffee-maker term but these servers were anything but) fix my coffee with cream and sugar and then ask me if I liked it, and then add more sugar for me. No snobbery- only help! And the helpfulness is especially important when its early in the morning and you haven't had any caffeine yet- I mean seriously, why is it that at starbucks you are supposed to remember crazy italian words so you can pick your size.

 The staff was SO pleasant and friendly, Phil himself rang up my order, and the coffee (Turkish, with mint in it) was strong enough to get me through working on a lazy Sunday. Yummy delicious!!! Yay!
author: Lizzie C.

description: I love this place. It's well worth the wait because they really are making a good quality cup of coffee. My top three are the mint mojito, ginger nap and hot chocolate
author: Helen L.

description: I love this coffee!  I love Jacob's and the Mocha Tesoro.  Would go everyday if I could.
author: S G.

description:
I've been going to Philz for years, but today Phil himself ruined his brand for me. The last thing I want to encounter at 8:30 on a Sunday morning is a boss treating his staff like dirt while belittling labor laws. Phil was standing right behind the woman who was about to make me what would likely be a delicious cup of coffee (for which I had passed 3 other cafes along the way) so I heard way too much of his tantrum. 

Perhaps there was some problem with the way that breaks were given on Saturday. I dunno. But I do know that Phil was out of line today.  He chose to very publicly reprimand the employee whom he had entrusted with the task of giving breaks. When his employee explained her decision (Saturdays never slow down so staff may have to break during busy periods), he suggested that she pull people from breaks if it got busy again.  

When his employee reminded him that the law has clear requirements for breaks, Phil really lost his cool. Choice remarks included, "There's the law and then there's right and wrong". Sorry, Phil, but you're the one who's wrong here, not labor laws. If you have the capital to expand across SF, then you can fully staff your locations on Saturdays to prevent this problem. Your workers deserve the protections of the law and they also deserve more respect than you gave today. Maybe you were having a bad day, but your choice to publicly berate your staff was a poor one.

I'm not the only person who told the cashier that I won't go back if Phil insists on treating his employees this way. Sadly, Phil got grumpy with the cashier right as it was my turn to pay. I got my cup back empty and left without coffee. Walked back and got a nice cuppa at Park Cafe on Folsom instead.

2 stars because the (expensive) coffee tastes good and the staff was still super attentive and nice as their boss made the whole place look terrible.
author: r. k.

description:
I work nearby Philz once a week. I'm glad it's a cash job. And I'm extra-glad I don't LIVE near here, because I'd go broke drinking the best of the best of the best coffee. They know me well enough that even, at only once a week, they remember how I like my coffee (they add the cream and sugar for you so you don't overdo it) and make it PERFECTLY, and they always ask me to make sure. 

The first time I had Philz, I was all, "What?!? Three dollar coffee?" But I am a convert. I have seen the light roast. 

Also, you get a pretty hefty discount if you bring your own cup. They don't use stir sticks. AND they have the sort-your-trash bins for compost and recycling, which means if you have to use a paper cup, you can recycle all of it.

I know now that coffee has more caffeine than espresso, and light roast has more than dark. 

But it's not *all* about the caffeine. The coffee is creamy in consistency and never burned-tasting -- which is kind of Phil's point. My favorites are Canopy of Heaven (light), Anesthesia to the Upside (medium), and Ether (dark-ish). The descriptions of the blends are helpful if you know what you like; if you don't know, try one of my favorites. You'll like them. A little nutty, a little chocolatey, a little jungle-y.

The people who work here always seem to be enjoying themselves, which to me is what makes me want to keep patronizing a business.

Plus they have neat-o snacky snacks for lunch, like samosas and puff pastries.

(My personal coffeeshop checklist. Doesn't really impact the score.)
Outside seating? Yes, several benches.
Bathroom OK? Ish.
Nutmeg? No/NA
Splenda? Yes
author: Tarin T.

description:
Typically, I drink Starbucks coffee everyday. I'm used to the not-so-amazing flavor that helps wake me up in the morning or gives me an afternoon boost. Maybe that's why I feel so refreshed to be holding a cup of "Sooo Good" coffee from Philz.

The coffee is great and actually flavorful. The actual coffee shop has a nice vibe to it and the employees are very friendly.

I hate to admit it, but I'll probably continue to drink Starbucks more often, but when I'm feeling like a good cup of coffee (and am willing to pay for it) I'll go to to Philz.
author: Jon V.

description:
Philz coffee is certainly unique, and worth the visit.  Three baristas take orders, and brew and prepare each made-to-order coffee one at a time.  These folks love what they do and provide great service, which complements nicely the myriad of coffee selections. You must, however, be willing to give up control and allow these guys to work their magic based on what you have conveyed is your taste/sweetness preference. 

I tried their Turkish coffee, which was very well done.  Great taste with a velvety smooth finish.  While the mint leaf addition to the coffee was interesting, it doesn't add much to the flavor, and I will leave out next time.  Can't ask for much more when it comes to a hot cup of coffee.
author: Gregory C.

description:
I love this place! If you just simply love coffee and just coffee then this is the place to be with HUGE selections of coffee. Just like a candy store you'll need to find what you like best. 

I told them this was my first visit and had them recommended me a drink. They charged me a small cup size while upgraded me to large one. Nick was also kind enough to make me one of his specialties for free. I got to give brownie points for all this on top of the great tasting coffee.
author: Justin L.

description:
I have to agree with Jessica t. Philz has a good vibe about it! For all you old school Santa Cruz coffee shop fans....Philz reminds me of the Java house a bit. Similar warehousey look, with lots of plants, good coffee and a great vibe!

I am a coffee snob and I have to say wow! I'm in love. I had a cup of the house, #19  Tesora. Which as i understand was Philz first blend. Delicious, well balanced, good bodied coffee...did I say yum! My gf had the Ambrosia which was also delicious. We liked both some much that she got a 1/2 lb of Ambrosia and I got a 1/2 of Tesora.

Also gotta mentiond that they do make "one cup of coffee at a time," no bs. They have a drip bar setup and make it for you. I got to chatting with the baristas about the "espresso" and he was quick to admit that it's a misnomer. The way Philz achieves espresso is by running the coffee thru the grounds a couple times. While you get a good thick coffee that tastes like espresso, it doesn't have the wow, ohh--ahhh factor of getting a nice little shot of espresso from so fancy looking Italian machine.  But I digress...when the coffee is good who cares how you make it! They also have two styles of Chai tea, different spices, which I'll have to come back and try.

It's really nice when a place lives up to it's reputation. I'd heard quite a few good things about Philz over the last few months I've been living in the City. Unfortunately, many place can't deliver on the hype. Well, Philz does this and does it well! I can't wait to check out the other locations.
author: isaias J.

description:
This was the first place that I started drinking coffee, I had a couple of bad cups here and there on the east coast (Dunkin Donuts).  But was never a serious coffee drinker till trying Philz.  WHOA!  This is some of the best coffee ever, love the staff there, also loved the individual attention each cup gets.

My only complaint is the amount of cardamom varies with each visit, todays for example was way to strong.  Otherwise this place rocks.
author: frizzle-fry e.

description: Wonderful experience! Ray the assistant manager was so very helpful and sweet! He treated us to our coffee since it was our third year anniversary and drove all the way here from SFO.. We fought the rush-hour traffic just so we could experience Philz once again before our flight home. They have wonderful coffee and wonderful customer service.. And very artsy atmosphere.. You can expect a delicious cup of coffee tailor-made to your palate and taste!
author: Natalie P.

description:
This is a must have Mission Experience.

The first time I came here I had no idea how it worked and I ended up ordering a drip coffee.  The lady just sort stared at me, dumbfounded.  She couldn't undrest and why I didn't want the special one cup at a time cofffee. Not to mention she didnt' even know how muchh it cost. Stupid Rookie.  I guess I was feeling cheap cuz I couldn't imagin any coffee  being worth $3 a pop.   

Well, I was wrong.    Since my first naive experience I have tried about  three of the 6 different choices on the menu.  

The TURKISH is the way to go.  They add cardamom and it's simply amazing. It  adds this unique taste to the coffee that leaves wanting more, but you can't for fear that your heart might explode. It's quit strong

The indian somosas are also very tasty.  I suggest the lentil ones. The beef was not very good. sort of mealy.   I've also had the almond croissant. Besides having about  a stick of butter in it, it's F%$#Ing amazing.

Fully endorse Philz coffee.
author: Adam L.

description:
ARGUABLY the best cup of coffee I've ever had in the city. 

Or state, for that matter. 

Probably in this country, even. 

Waiting in line only increases the anticipation for repeat customers. Believe all the hype...it's true!
author: J C.

description: Some of the best coffe I've ever had!!! So many varieties!! The mojito coffee is amazing! I am lucky we dont have a philz closer or I would be broke!
author: athena k.

description: kinda expensive for a cup of joe but if a trendy shop with plenty of people staring at ya from above their Mac apples gets you going then this place is for you.  there is a place near 14th and mission that does the same one cup at a time deal and the owner there is cool as hell.  I would rather spend my $$'s at the mom and pop place.  philz is good coffee though but if you want super good coffee head to north beach.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Oh you like coffee? You have a place that makes the best coffee ever huh? 

well...go to Philz and tell me if you still believe your place is better? 

Better is subjective, but goddamn Philz coffee is retarded good. Honestly, coffee from Philz is a treat. I sometimes will wake up earlier and head deep into the mission to get me a cup to start my day....sometimes, certain days call for certain special coffee's.....like jacob's wunderbar, or Philz Harmonic....oooohh...im gettin thirsty just thinkin about it. 

Philz is what all coffee houses should strive for....unique, special, high quality. 

To Philz!
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Philz coffee really is the best and worth the wait to have good drip coffee. I suggest, embrace the wait and use it to meditate (hey that rhymes- anyway) or just people watch. It's good for that too.
