I miss Philz since I've moved to Mt. View. It's hard to get a good cup of coffee here. Sufi coffee is close but not close enough. 

Also at Philz there is really good baklava there. I don't even like baklava but whoever makes there's, makes it perfect. 

Phil is a very nice man who gave me a free piece of baklava when I told him I was moving away. The people that work their are very nice too.
author: Julia H.

description:
Simply the best coffee in San Francisco....
I've been there 2x today!
author: Tasha R.

description: Philz is the best - they make it just right.
author: Johnson H.

description:
That was simply the best cup of brewed coffee I've ever had.  And I've had many.  Many.

The super cute girl behind the counter was friendly and informative. I like to go to places people are happy to work at.  As the staff adds any cream or sugar to your coffee before you get it I just left that in her hands as she said the "philtered soul" (sp?) which I ordered was her favorite.  It's my favorite now, too.

We took our coffee to go, but the place looked nice and cozy.  The staff there looks like they're having at least a reasonably good time which also makes me happy.  Living where I do I have a lot of coffee places much closer, but I'll be making the bike ride to Philz next time I want a good cup.
author: Rich R.

description: Hi Phil!  I miss being able to just walk in and get an oh so delicious Turkish and then hang out and talk...until you fell asleep...because you were "relaxed."  Now, you are SO popular that I have to pick a weird time on a weekday to avoid a half hour line. It's like hot liquid dessert. YUM.
author: B B.

description:
This is an easy one. THE BEST COFFEE I HAVE EVER HAD. I grew up in Seattle, where coffee is essential to prevent yourself from going Cobain. IMHO coffee in San Francisco taste like garbage. People argue about how much better Peet's is over Starbucks. Truth is - they both suck equally. 

Phil'z on the other hand is remarkable, and not just remarkable in a SF kind of way, but remarkable in an everything I've ever learned about coffee way. And if you're reading this and know of any other great spots, I am ALL ears.
author: Scott S.

description:
I wouldn't consider myself a person who HAS to have her coffee in order to start the day, but Philz' stuff is pretty pretty good java.  I like the aroma, the full-bodied flavor, the warmth.  The amount of caffeine that's necessary to take me through the rest of the day is just a bonus!  I don't get all jumpy and edgy, and there's no bad crash in the end.  It's like a great rollercoaster ride, and when it's over, you simply get off and say, "That was fun!"

I haven't gone through every one of Philz' special coffees, but the Philharmonic and Greater Alarm are my faves so far.  I recently checked out one of them potato sambocas (sp?) and that was damn tasty.  I was bragging about it at work alllll day!  Just wait til I learn how to make those at home.

The people are sweet and friendly there, absent are the outcasts masquerading as the ultra-hip.  This makes sitting down in any of the comfortable chairs to sip and nosh that much more enjoyable.
author: Sheila G.

description:
The true and original one. I already loved the store at 4th st. The one here has better atmosphere and cheaper prices. And I happened to meet Phil. I was hanging out with a bunch of people, none of us American. When Phil asked us where we were from, and very proudly we were saying our different countries, he gave us the coolest answer ever ... "NO, wrong, we are all from the same place: the canopy of heaven. It is the same as coffee: coffee is coffee and doesn't understand of boundaries. Same thing with us. The rest are only names."

Great guy selling the best coffee in the city.
author: Javi V.

description:
I almost didn't want to review seeing as how many this place already had, but it's just that good.

I mean, they have it all. The coffee is A+. Thus far I haven't made it past the Tesora, or the Iced Turkish on hot days, but they have a shitload of options.

But the thing I really love about this place is the service. SF is the epicenter for bitchy baristas, and these guys are so friendly and attentive. Not in a canned way, but in a like, they actually care if you like your coffee way; following you out to the table, offering you extras if there's left over coffee. Also explaining things when they can tell you have a question. I mean, it's really on another level.

Def. my default place from now on.
author: Matt T.

description:
AMAZING COFFEE MADE ONE CUP AT A TIME

Best coffee in the world!  I have tried almost all of the blends and there is something for everyone.  Below is a list of my favorites:

Tesora
If it is your first time, I would suggest trying the Tesora blend.  It took seven years to develop this blend.

Ambrosia
This is my favorite, rich and never bitter.

Silken Splendor
A medium roast that has nutty flavors.

I like the casual atmosphere, friendly staff, and free wi-fi.
author: Rob L.

description:
What a cup of coffee that was!  I read about Philz on Yelp from someone who likes strong coffee and used to live in Italy.  Since I like strong coffee and generally like the coffee in Europe, I thought this would be a place worth trying.  I had the Philtered Soul, which is a medium dark roast.  The flavor was great.  You can taste the freshness and the nice finish of the coffee, but it does taste like flavored coffee (which I don't like) and it's too sweet for me.  The description did describe it as sweet, so I should have known it's flavored.    

My friend had the Jacob Wonderbar Brew which is a dark roast and it's not flavored coffee.  I had a sip and it was fantastic.  

The coffee choices are a bit overwhelming as they have some 18 or so choices of coffee, some of which are flavored.  I think this place has the best coffee in the city, but be sure to ask which coffees are flavored if you're not into flavored coffeed.  I am going back there for sure.
author: Paul K.

description: Worth the wait, all their blends are fantastic!
author: Aalok P.

description:
I happened in to Philz early one Tuesday morning, near desparate for coffee in a neighborhood I was unfamiliar with.
And boy did Fate smile on me.  I got the Turkish coffee and I loved it!
On Thursday I got the Arabic.  It too was fabulous.
I thought it was very nice that that the Owner (I think it was him) who made my coffe did not give me a dirty look when I asked for cream and sugar.  I always feel bad destroying what I suppose is a work of art - but my taste buds are picky little devils.
Later in the day a friend of mine did get a latte and it was too strong for her taste - but I thought mine was fabulous.
I would recommend Philz to any of my friends (minus my aforementioned one). (Especially the Turkish.)
author: Chrissy S.

description: Philz does coffee "one cup at a time." You pick the type of coffee you like, whether you like dark or light roast, more fruity or nutty, everything to your liking. Since I don't know too much about coffee, I ask the guy for some recommendations. I ended up trying Julie's blend (don't remember the exact name). It was great, but a bit pricey for coffee. But overall good service and good coffee, good experience.
author: Angela T.

description:
I first visited the place over two years ago, but was apparently unaffected by its remarkable charm -- for i neglected to visit until just last week.  After embarrassing myself by trying to order a latte, the barista explained to me their unorthodox method of caffeine delivery: one cup at a time.  Armed with the knowledge that they prepare their own exceptionally good cream, the Barista (who was lovely) recommended a dark, smoky blend called Jacob's Wonderbar.  At first sip, I knew again what coffee could, indeed should, be with hints of chocolate and nutty notes and a wonderfully robust, creamy texture.  I highly recommend this place for people looking to reconnect with coffee.

My only issue now is that I have a slew of flavors and nuances to sample -- but I certainly don't mind the challenge.
author: Victor R.

description:
Okay, I'll admit it: I'm one of those people that *LOVES* flavored creamer.  French vanilla, hazelnut, and those fancy kinds that only come out around the holidays with peppermint and such?  Mmmmmm.  I also use Splenda instead of sugar.  I am not one of those people that truly appreciates coffee in its natural form.

So, imagine my surprise in announcing that the cup of coffee from Philz was pure heaven... with just cream and sugar!!  Yes, the friendly staffer threw a fresh mint leaf in there as well, but this was still as close to pure coffee as I generally get, and I was literally commenting after every sip how ridiculously delicious it was!  Luckily I was with a couple other people who were Philz newbies as well, so it was fair to make a ten minute discussion topic out of which flavors we had each chosen and how much we loved it. 

Oh Philz.  Can you open a Santa Cruz branch?
author: Leslie R.

description:
Probably one of the best cups of coffee I've ever had. Had no idea how to order or what to pick or how to pay, but I still managed to do it all without feeling uncomfortable for a second. The woman who took our order recommended the roast then asked how sweet I wanted it. I said, "Like a dessert" and I guess she knew exactly what I meant because it was *perfect* !

I sat with my friend on the big orange...ish leather couch for a long time and talked while everyone else tippy-tapped on their laptops behind us. It was a great experience. At one point, I looked over at the counter and the man I saw taking payments at the register was sweeping and dancing to the music. Priceless scene. 

Told the pretty lady who made my cup that it was absolutely excellent and she smiled like "I know."  :)
author: Jan W.

description:
I have not been to Philz but what engenders a review like Rick C's is five stars to me.

1. Corligiano's First Symphony moved me like no other experience; to continue listening would have risked perfection to the possible disappointments of reality.

2. If Atlas Cafe won't do right by morning shouldn't I work it out one-on-one between me and tattoed tank top girl behind the counter rather than stray outside the relationship for cheap thrills?.  

3. Though addicted again to caffeine I  never learned the taste.  For me it''s all in the ritual, the place, the conversation.  The liquid itself, frankly, is one skanky cup of bitter nastiness.

One happy monday, once new year festivities dog down Nemesis and I will down a few on way to the gym, run treadmill two hearts pumping ambition, she'll make it all okay with her odd brilliant definitions of life and between jitters I'll write the real review.

Life has been rat, I'm getting grounded oh sweet skank that warms the dawn.
author: Gil S.

description: I thought Philz was on the pricey side, I spent about $3.50 for a cup of coffee, which I'm not used to, but it was excellent coffee. They brew their coffee a cup at a time and are very serious about quality. The Philz staff is also extremely friendly, as I had a ton of questions as a first time customer and they were patient and helpful. The man helping me suggested the tesora as a good coffee for a Philz newb, and it was all that and more. I'll definitely head back there the next time I'm in the Mission. Philz has a great atmosphere and a good amount of seating for those looking for a coffee shop to do some work in.
author: Derek L.

description:
The best drip coffee in, perhaps, the world.  Don't bother with the espresso drinks there -- they're good, but don't hold a candle to the killer blends and customization of every drink you get from the fresh-ground beans (and I mean ground-in-front-of-your-eyes fresh) and the friendly banter with the person making it (try telling Phil your mood instead of ordering off the menu; he'll make you something perfect).  Mint leaves on top are the perfect touch.

Not many places to sit (only a couple couches; tables at weird angles), but that's not worth taking off a star -- who needs to sit when you can have coffee this good?
author: Nori H.

description:
6 of us were on a San Francisco espresso crawl. We had heard Philz we awesome so we tried it out.

There was a sign outside that said they had Turkish. I thought "I LOVE turkish coffee! I guess I'll have to throw out consistency of my drink for this crawl." and went in the door.

First, the layout of the place is a bit weird for ordering. First we lined up at the cash register only to realize that we should move past the register to where there were hand written signs saying "Order Here". Then you order, then you go back to the register to pay then you go back to where you ordered to wait for your drink. You don't always have choice in the layout of your shop, but that wasn't so hot.

Then I walked up to an open barista and ordered a Turkish coffee. I realized I wasn't actually going to get a turkish coffee when she asked if I wanted cream or sugar. I look a closer look at the surroundings and realized I was getting a pour over coffee so I got it black, since that is how I get my drip coffee. (Let's all admit it - pour over coffee is just a fancy name for individually served drip coffee. It is the equivalent of getting a single cup Melitta handed to you, but you have to wait for someone else to pour the water and let the water go through the grounds).

The others ordered a variety of things including the "hand crafted espresso" which is just coffee grounds with water poured through 3 times, it seems.

We realized after we left that none of us were comfortable here. Perhaps because we didn't know what we were ordering or what we would get. I liken it to going to a bar for the very first time and seeing lots of people around ordering things you've never heard of, looking at a menu and only seeing terms like "Sex on a Beach" and "Mojito" with prices next to them, then being asked questions about how you want that drink when you have basically closed your eyes and pointed to the menu to decide what to order.

Anyway, so we get our drinks and leave. My turkish is completely undrinkable. I have no idea what this coffee is, but it is burned tasking and sour and bitter all at the same time. I poured mine out. The hand drawn espresso was awful too. Only one person got a drink that any of us liked and she said she couldn't pronounce it or spell it, but she was also sure it was because she got the cream and sugar that it was any good.

The fresh mint is a nice touch.
author: Mitch H.

description:
~ ~
  ~~ ~  ~
  ~  ~~   ~
 _______
l                l
 l              l
   l           l
    l____l

that's how awesome it is.  i finally drew something again.
the almond croissant was great too.
i got jacobs wonderbar something or another, mmmm....
i am so happy to have 2 favorite coffee places now.
author: Today Y.

description:
"This is coffee?"

Those were the first words to pop into my sleepy mind as I sipped a Turkish blend (variety #1). Where was the bitterness, the charred aroma of a BBQ gone bad? This was too silky smooth, a brew of swirling flavors, with a slight sprig of mint floating on top, ground and brewed to order through a paper filter.

I plopped in one of the random chairs, crammed together with other random chairs like the furniture section at Goodwill. I glanced around. At 11am, it was a melange of hipsters, middle aged foreigners, newspaper readers, laptop tappers. The usual Mission coffee crowd, nestled in this junkyard of chairs.

Three hours later I was back, needing no more caffeine in my bloodstream but powerless to resist. I tried another flavor, #19, and it was awesome in a totally different way.

My memories of Philz are intact, and my conclusion remains: I am so glad I live on the other side of town.
author: Eric M.

description:
We were headed to a BBQ on labor day and stopped in at the liquor store across the street.  While my friends were perusing the huge selection of dead stock beer (they have beer from the USSR.  Not Russia, THE USSR?!) I walked across the street to Philz to get some coffee.

Oh my are the people who work here super nice.  The girls were all smiles and made me what may be the best iced coffee I've had outside of Austin.  The inside of this place feels like a weird traveler stop in a foreign country with people talking, plotting, computing, and playing games.

Philz, please come to North Oakland.
author: Cory G.

description: Philz is amazing, even the cream they use is amazing, this Philz has a lot of room and is full of light, it's pretty ghetto and I'm down with that - I'm hooked and I can't drink normal brewed coffee anymore.
author: Heshy F.

description:
When an interviewer asked Keith Richards about "today's rock and roll" he replied,  with this gem:

"Man I never gotten past Robert Johnson."

That's how I feel about Tesora, Phil's house blend.  Keith Richards never could find the bottom of Robert Johnson's heart, nor his soul.  He just kept playing, and listening.  He never needed anything more, because Robert Johnson's blues was his nightly muse.  Tesora is my morning muse.
author: gabriel a.

description: I am a coffee drinker but I have to say that coffee rarely gets me excited.  I love the standard lattes or cappucinos but a cup of coffee  has to be really good to stand out on its own....and Philz coffee stands tall.  I crave Philz more often that I have it because I actually am cutting down on caffeine, but when I do have it, I remember why I crave it often.  Such a superior cup of java...faves are the Philtered Soul and Iced Coffee with their special cream.
author: V B.

description:
Okay peeps, there is coffee and there is Philz Coffee.  This stuff is the crack of coffees, I mean you will get hooked on this octane boostin' brown liquid of joy.   

Even us conservatives felt comfortable and welcome in this place (24th street location).  The place is somewhat run down, but the employees are very friendly and you just don't mind paying $2.50 for a drip cup.   

I got the regular, and this is no reg. coffee.... I have been to every coffee shop.. had coffee in Italy, Paris, San jose..huh San jose, how did that get in there?  - anyways enough going on and on.  Oh, and for your control freaks, let these people put the cream and sugar, just let them damn it.
author: H D.

description: Friendly barista and TOO many choices of bean. Too bad I don't live in SF to try more than one kind..
author: M M.

description:
I didn't know which one to review, since I love them all... so I chose the one I went to first.

This place... i cannot tell you how much time I have spent trying to find excuses (now that I don't live in SF) to swing by Philz and grab a tesora or something... But I've decided that it's OK, sometimes it deserves it's own reason, I mean, come on! 

The coffee tastes like coffee, no crazy flavors that mask the taste, no frappe crap. Just good coffee. I like that.

Just don't go ordering a coffee and a giant bran muffin like I did when I was new to Philz. yeesh. nuf said! (maybe too much actually.)
author: Marz J.

description:
Two stars for being different.

Different isn't always good, in fact in this case I think that it is just plain bad.  I want to like this uber esoteric coffee but I can't do it.  It tastes so thick and muddy.  There is something about the smell that turns my tummy.  Maybe I'm just to used to the boring drip coffee I grew up on?

I'm not saying don't go.  I'm saying that this isn't coffee for everyone.
author: Thadd L.

description:
I have a mixed reaction to Philz Coffee. Now, I've only been coming here for a couple of months, so maybe that's not enough time to accurately assess a place. 

So far, these are my observations:

-Boy, do the employees like to toot their own horns! One time I was in there for a few hours, I probably heard each girl who was working there that morning tell any customer willing to listen how fucking great and unique Philz coffee is! At first I thought that this might be some tactic to kiss up to Phil, but then realized that a lot of these proclamations were going on when Phil was no where within ear shot. The girl who made my cup of coffee that day went on and on about how much I was going to love it, and how Philz was the only coffee shop she would go to in the city, even before she worked there. It's like, okay, that's nice. I just want some coffee, yo. 

-That said, Phil himself seems like a pretty chill dude, and I've never heard HIM bragging about his coffee, so I don't know where the employees get this high and mighty attitude. Phil is rad; he smiles and says hi every time.

-The control freak in me is slightly irked by the fact that THEY put the cream and sugar in your cuppa joe FOR you. I have to say, it throws me off. It's a task that I am so used to doing on my own, and I like to control the amounts of cream and sugar that go into it. Also, along with the whole tooting their own horn thing, on a couple of occasions, I asked for a certain drink to be modified (like, no cream, but sugar is okay; or, can you please use milk today instead of cream...you know, thinking about my health, I guess) and they'd be like, "Can I please just make it for you the way it's supposed to be made? I PROMISE you're going to love it. It'll be the best cup of coffee you've ever had...okay?" So what do you say to that, huh? I'm just trying to go easy on the cream and this is what I'm met with. Well, thanks, that helps a lot!

-On to the environment, it's very relaxed, and that I like. I enjoy the big, air-y feel to the space, with the windows and large tables, and the weird assortment of chairs. The real reason I usually go there is for the free wi-fi. You could hang in there and get a lot of work done. Not a high-strung environment, like some of the other coffee spots in the mission. The vibe in Philz is super-chill. 

-Bathrooms are important to me. The bathroom here is large but very dark, even with the light on. Clean seeming, but also kind of feels like an outhouse. One time it smelled horrible, but last time I was there it smelled a-okay.

-I can't decide what I think about the mint leaves on top of the coffee. Again, messes with the control freak. I would like it more if YOU could pick a piece of mint and put it on top, if the mood struck. I just don't like giving so many verbal directions when it comes to getting a cup of coffee!

-As much as the employees have annoyed me throughout the summer, they are on top of their game, and very quick to serve you as soon as you come it. They are spot-on in terms of customer service. You may just be in for a preachy monologue, that's all.
author: Shannon R.

description:
One-cup-at-a-time. 

Seriously, what else is there to say. I get the one with the mint in it. and it is good n strong. mmm. reminds me of the strong ass coffee i would have in europe. yippeeee!

oh yes, and let us not forget the piano and guy who sells falafel who likes my friend. (falafel which i cannot vouch for, by the way.)
author: Jessica W.

description:
NEW UPDATE:
Philz I take it all back, baby, I'm sorry.  I don't know who that stupid blonde whore was, and I don't care.  Phil himself even made my coffee the other day.  I felt like a celebutante having her gown custom made by Carl Lagerfeld.  I love you i love you I loveyou

OLD REVIEW:
Writing this review makes me sad and angry at the same time.

I used to live down the street and my bus stop in the A.M. was across from Philz.  I am also a coffee snob and try to avoid corporate america so Philz was the obvious choice for coffee.  Add in the Turkish coffee and abundance of vegan cookies and even Phil himself and I really couldn't be happier with a coffee shop.

Then one day I went in, not long after the re-arrangement of countertops.  I got my coffee and looked for a lid.  You, know, the plastic kind that go on your disposable cup that don't cost a thing (but you probably should be using a travel mug from home).  Usually they are on the counters in abundance, but not that day.  Oh no.  They were no where to be found....except for on the counter kinda behind the cash register, but ambiguously within reach of the groggy customer (that would be me).  So as I'm handing my $2.50 for a cup of black coffee (overpriced but worth it), I ask the woman if I can have a lid.  She sorta pauses, goes "umm OK" as i go ahead and grab one.  Then she hands me my change and says "I'm only giving you $16 back because the lids are $1.50"

WHAT?  no sign?  couldn't have told me that before i grabbed it? For that price, the lid probably should be gold plated.  with at least a cubic zirconia bit of flair.  Where the fuck is Phil and who is this blond woman?

I cried robot tears onto my overpriced lid on my bus ride to work - I knew I'd never go back there ever again.
author: Katherine K.

description:
this place is awesome. The barista was super friendly & knowledgeable...and gave a great recommendation on the "silken something..." (name?) for a smooth,med roast!

in addition to the great coffee, he didn't even give me a hard time for inadvertently cutting the line w/ my order...first timer! ;)  and bring ur own commuter mug, pay the $mall price but get a large $ize -- love the green behavior & the rewarding part of it!

atmosphere: definitely in the mission and the more eclectic, artsy mix!  but people are super friendly...I chatted w/ a local photographer while standing in line to the restroom...he confirmed that the 'hood's definitely changed a bit...in the up$scale, pricing direction, of which I agree...but then again, that's the City as a whole!
author: Patty L.

description:
Everybody in the family knows to heed me little brothers words, especially when he says things like "It's the BEST coffee in SF." We met up at Philz in the Ghet-to to talk some bidniz. Ordered Turkish coffee, a departure from my usual, at again my brother's insistence. "You've got to have a Turkish coffee. It's the best here!" Now every Turkish coffee that I've ever had is served in a demitasse and for good reason: it packs a wallop! But NOOOOO! I went against better judgment and accepted the full-sized cup of heart-bomb. At 3am, teeth chattering, I was discussing the 2008 campaign with my cat. Thanks Philz, now I know what a llello-head feels like. "SAY HELLO TO MY LITTLE FRIEND!" 

If you're not used to Turkish Coffee, order it here just once for the taste experience. Otherwise you won't go wrong with the other flavorful roasts. 

Only downside is the furniture. Though I can appreciate the cafe hipoisie life-style, I have a hard time tolerating the Green Tortoise bus lines decor for any length of time.
author: Johnny C.

description:
Coffee that will change your life.  I am not kidding.

BUT it will change your waistline.  Cream and sugar in every cup tastes AMAZING, but damn if my jeans don't fit now.  So, I temper my loves Mocha Tesora and Estastic Iced Coffee with a BANGING Mint Tea with a little honey.  Soothes my throat after screaming at kids all day (at a day camp) and doesn't help me store my fat for winter.

Also, Phil is often about and he's a dream to talk to.

OH! And hit it up on Sunday morning to hear a delightful local band play awesome music.

Oh, Philz, you are a dream come true.
author: Jill K.

description: Decided that it really depends on the person making your coffee.  Yesterday I got a large black tea with honey and soy and the woman who made it worked some crazy MAGIC.  She also made my BFs regular large philharmonic and he said she did a better than average job.  I would give Philz 5 stars, but sometimes it's hit or miss.  They really need to train their baristas to all be at the same level.
author: Skye W.

description: I LOVE Philz.  The Turkish blend with a little cream and a hint of sugar is divine.  However, when you're paying $3 for a bagel, cream cheese and tomato, it should be prepared as you request.  It's not limited to Philz, but why is it that invariably at a cafe when I ask for a bagel "toasted well" it comes back lukewarm?  In the world at large this is a trifling thing, but I wish that the folks at Philz would put the same attentive care they give your coffee into the preparation of menu items.  That would hit it out of the ballpark!
author: Earl D.

description: I never been here the service was very helpful with the different kinds of selection of coffee so I decided to try a Mint Morita and it tasted delicious I think I well be coming back real soon and relax and read a newspaper or something I was in a rush so I had to hit and run.
author: Barbara S.

description:
Probably the best drips I've had! The Philharmonic is fantastic. And I love that I don't have to deal with cream and sugar (they do it -- and just the way I like it!).

Very friendly staff.

I haven't worked from here, but it seems like I could. They have a couple communal tables which seem comfy to work from.
author: Premshree P.

description:
Ah, coffee. I never understood the hype (no pun intended) surrounding this acidic black substance, having been exposed to the starbucks, peet's and mr. espresso's of the world.

Then i tried a cup of Philz "canopy of heaven" blend, made to order with the perfect amount of cream and sugar and topped off with a mint leaf. Its one of their light roasts, and therefore probably contains enough caffeine to awaken a comatose elephant.

Now i get the hype.
author: A K S.

description: Great location for this hand crafted coffee shop.  Located at the quite end of 24th in Noe Valley, you can actually find parking near and there is a park right next door.
author: Bruce B.

description:
My very first Yelp review!

I needed to get some work done online today in my neighborhood. All I wanted was a good cup of coffee, a place that takes credit cards, and free Wi-Fi. This is not exactly an unreasonable request, or so I thought DUN DUN DUN. I spent the next hour walking up and down Valencia, unable to find anybody who could provide these three things. Four Barrell is delicious but has no Wi-Fi. Borderlands has coffee and takes credit cards but has no Wi-Fi. A bunch of crappy places took credit cards and had Wi-Fi but had crappy coffee and a bad working atmosphere. As a last ditch try I went to Ritual, who I normally dislike, and had the worst possible experience. Finally my boyfriend's coworker suggested Philz. It's right by my house but I always forgot about it since I usually start out from my house in the opposite direction.

So here I come, really exhausted from walking around carrying my heavy laptop in the sun, frustrated by encountering so much poor service and such terrible, lazy, pretentious employees. After confirming that they do in fact take credit cards, I was kindly directed to the ordering bar. My barista was knowledgeable, patient, efficient, unpretentious and most of all funny! I ordered what he recommended and was soon presented with a delicious cup of coffee. Now I'm sitting in a comfortable chair using free Wi-Fi drinking good coffee, kicking myself for not coming here first, but glad that I finally know where I'm coming for coffee from now on.
author: Diana S.

description:
I don't drink coffee, but I do drink iced tea and I drink it unadulterated.  No sugar or lemon or anything.  Phill made me a pretty damn tasty iced tea in the strangest way possible.  He made a serving size of hot tea, then put it over ice, then gave me a separate cup with the lefotver tea that wouldn't fit in the first cup.  Since he put hot tea over ice, the first lot of ice melted almost immediately so I got him to fill the second "overflow" cup with more ice.  

WTF?  Either way it was a damn tasty iced tea.
author: matthew w.

description:
how can you not love Philz coffee?  Its all about the coffee here.....well maybe not.  ~~~Hey you, yeah you... do you need a fedora?~~~  Well they have some there too.  Strange but true.  But....oah yeah.... back to the coffee.  

Well, watch out whatcha order because you might just be searching for the nearest bathroom as you stroll down 24th.  Some of their coffee can be like liquid roto rooter, so watch yourself, seriously folks.  But its some tasty shit, even a little mint leaf on top if you're feeling fancy.

Free Wi-Fi, good day old baked goods for you cheap bastards out there, no mugs so bring your own cup slackers, and even get a discount.

If you don't know what you are ordering then ask, you'll be happy that you gauged your intake cause it might bite you in the ass...literally.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
I've been here three times, which I think warrants a substantial background for a decent review.
Overall: OK - here's why

1) The coffee: The primary reason people usually go to coffee shops, is for the coffee, so I'll start here. the coffee is OK. Not good, not AWESOME, just OK. As a matter of personal history into my own life, I am a coffee snob. I own my own french press, I buy premium whole beans, and I grind them in my Burr grinder.
Technically speaking, all the coffee's I've had there (each different), taste the same.  You get about 3 minutes of actual uniqueness, then every sip afterward, will be like the last cup of coffee you had.

Realistically speaking, since they are not a Star Bucks, and seem to be popular with the locals, and tout how great their coffee is with all their blends, you'd figure, I mean you'd *really really* figure, that they would invest in some actual glass mugs. Instead you get these crappy organic paper cups (yay, good for the environment, but puts a stale taste in your mouth). Seriously, it's like pouring Alagash or Chimay into a plastic cup, or serving Fillet Mignon on the carpet. Get with it Philz!

2) Service: Excellent. They're always polite and have helped me in my indecisiveness of choosing one of their zillion coffees.

3) Environment: Fine. It's obviously a Hipster hangout over there on 24th back behind the Mission. Congratulations on pulling people past Valencia. I'd like to think it's the perfect location to fool you into thinking it's the ghetto, but really, nothing is going to happen. An occasional cop car drives by, then everything goes back to normal.

For Philz employees, I know you guys read this, the only thing I recommend is getting glass mugs. That's it. That will make it worlds better.
author: Dustin D.

description:
You can probably use one word to describe Philz coffee.......BOMB! They have such a friendly and helpful staff, and amazing beverages! I ran into this store when I was in a desperate search for a Starbucks around my neighborhood, found no luck so I ran into the closest Cafe to me. So I went inside, and it must have been my lucky day! Phil himself, made my coffee....he first asked if it was my first time, and when he found out that it was he guaranteed that I would be addicted, the man was right, this was the best cup of joe I ever had! It was amazing! They don't use a machine to make their coffee just lots of hot water and a filter......and they don't charge extra for soy milk! I was amazed! I also fell in love with their mint mojito (no not the kind with alcohol) it's a lovely iced mixture of coffee, chocolate (the best chocolate at that!) and mint OMG heaven! I've gotten my whole family, the boyfriend, and my co workers addicted .....it's just not the same getting coffee/ tea elsewhere once you've had the Philz experience. 
You would think friendly service, and bomb ass coffee has gotta be pricey? NOPE A large Coffee is about $4.50 definitely beats Starbucks prices that charge you extra if you want soy milk, syrup, ice, and crappy service.
author: Irene N.

description:
This is the best coffee in SF. I've tried blue bottle, four barrel, sight glass, ritual, barefoot. But Philz is what I crave. People have their preferences, so I can't say if others will like this place like I do (e.g., Mom thinks it's gross), but consider ordering what I order: a small half Jacob's and half decaf Ethiopian with cream and 1 sweet n low (or sugar or no sweetener, whatev). It is rich, chocolately and nutty, smooth. So friggin tasty. 

Mind you, decor is chaotic, parking is tough, and because they do one cup at a time, the flavor off the same-named drink might change from time to time. Nevertheless, this is the place to go. 

Now if you don't like the half-calf and want full-on, consider thinking about what *kind* of coffee you like, and ask a barrista what they think you should get. They are helpful like that. And if you're a chicken, then my suggestion is to go with the Turkish w/ cream and whatever your sweetener preference is. (sidenote: I didn't much care for the Julia's.) Or if decaf - Ethiopian all the way.
author: O. K.

description:
When I walked into Philz this morning, it smelled of cardamom and baked goods - pretty good way to start the morning right?  I never drink drip coffee (I'm a latte girl), but this coffee was amazing.  It was delicious and now I am wired!  I am still mid caffeine high as I write this!  

The food at Philz was also great.  We had a savory spinach roll and two sambosas, which were both amazing. The ambience was great and the staff was super friendly.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Alexandra K.

description:
I would simply like to add that contrary to what Katheter K. has to say, I have it on very good authority that the proprietors of Philz Coffee will not charge you a dollar fitty for a plastic lid. 

My guess is that it was a joke that simply went awry.
author: Brandon B.

description:
When I think of good coffee I think or two things:

Philz coffee

and,

My sister, Mei Ling, taking to Philz coffee.

I have to admit, it was a little daunting when I first arrived, even with my sister there (an experienced Philz coffee drinker) I still was mystified.  

I stepped up to the counter to order my sister's usual and oogled over the menu trying to determine what to order for myself.  Luckily, the staff was very friendly and helpful.  She asked what I liked about coffee and came up with an order!  It was A-MAzing. 

I have to admit, it was right then and there that I realized what good coffee truly taste like.  Apparently you really don't need a bucket of sugar to drink a cup of coffee.
author: Cassandra H.

description:
best coffe i've ever had in my life!  nothing tastes like philz and nothing ever will.  must try philtered soul.  i've gotten so many of my friends hooked on philz (sorry guys).  

disclaimer: do not drink this coffee after 6pm unless you're intent is to stay up until 4am :)
author: Stephanie M.

description:
For me, Philz is all about the fantastic low-key work environment.  Philz practically begs you to make this your living room away from home - that place you bring your laptop, plug into one of the many powerstrips, and hunker down into the garage sale chic furnishings, oh so reminiscent of the house you shared with five dudes freshman year of college, for hours upon hours upon hours.  Sometimes I bring my lunch with me, or even leave in the middle of my sess', grab some takeout, and come back.  The friendly folks who work here never seem to mind.  I always feel welcome, if not outright welcomed.  And for these things, Philz, you have my affection.

Alas, the coffee just doesn't do it for me, which is why I can't give you more than two stars.  In fact, I'm baffled by you, San Franciscans, and your obsession with your Philz brew.  Aside from being fresher than the regular old cup of joe since it's made by the cup - which, don't get me wrong, *is* worth something - it's just really not that spectacular.  I've tried many of the blends and most have not gone down well.  I can stomach "Philtered Soul" and "Canopy of Heaven" with plenty of soy milk.  And sometimes I have to when I need the caffeine.  Otherwise, I do better to grab an espresso from the Blue Bottle kiosk around the corner from my apartment and sip on Philz tea (which is quite good).
author: Lulu W.

description: I'm relatively new to drinking coffee, so I like mine sweet and creamy. With that in mind, Philz is the best I've had. I'm partial to the Jacob's Wonderbar, but Philz has so many roasts it's unlikely there isn't something for you. Be sure to let them add the cream and sugar. The coffee shop itself is a bit on the grungy side, but I usually get my coffee and leave.
author: Jeremy J.

description:
most amazing cup of coffee ever!
kind of strange though because they use paper cups even if you want iced coffee, and they're pretty small especially with the ice..
+ on the pricey side. $3 for small iced coffee.
but super delicious. very flavourful (esp considering the multiple packets of sugar i usually have to put in my coffee for me to like it..)
author: Siri W.

description:
Let me start this review off by saying that, until recently, I was not a coffee person. I had always hated the taste of black coffee, and even after I would add tons of sugar, I still didn't enjoy drinking it. And don't get me wrong, I had tried a lot of coffee. I wanted to like it, I just couldn't. Then I learned a little more about how to make the perfect cup of coffee. Make sure the beans aren't old or burnt, freshly grind the beans before making each cup, and brew a fresh pot every time you want some-- no using the brew from 12 hours ago that still looks good.

Now, meet Philz. My friend who is obsessed with coffee convinces me to go here with her to try it. I order the ecstatic iced coffee, and my whole world is changed. I have finally found the perfect cup of coffee. As is advertised, every cup is made fresh, and it is amazing how much you can taste the difference. I had some cream added with a little sugar, and it was amazing! There was no bitter after-taste that I normally experience with other coffee joints, it wasn't too sweet, and the cream didn't overpower the coffee. I tried it once without sugar and it was still amazing! Ever since I tried place, I cannot stop raving about it. And I am now an obsessive coffee drinker. I live in Daly City and go to school at SFSU, but I will travel here before classes just to get a morning brew-- it's THAT good. 

And did I mention the awesome baristas? I've had a different one every time I've gone there, and they have always been so polite and nice, even on a busy day. Add free wi-fi and plenty of sitting space, and you've got yourself a 5 star cafe.
author: Deena H.

description:
I went to Phil's this morning before my flight and holy lord I wish I had known about this place earlier. 

The one-cup-at-a-time brewing method makes all the difference in the world and the unconventional flavors melted nicely together with the coffee. 

Nothing was pre-done, making the wait a little longer than usual but well worth it. Even the sprig of mint in my coffee was picked right off the plant and placed in the cup. 

Thanks, Philz, I'm most likely going to be a regular when I move to the left coast.
author: Lindsay D.

description:
My sister walked up and asked for the smoothest blend they had, I got a sip of it and it was honestly the smoothest cup of pure coffee I'd ever had.  Unfortunately I haven't had such great luck with my own cup from Philz.  I've gotten a mocha and cappucinno and they weren't as great at the "smooth" coffee, but still good.  The butter cookie and the chocolate croissant was great too.  Samosas..okay.

Added 3/29/07:  I was asked about the Philz having samosas, they had them one day, in a basket, on the shelf, I guess I never thought about looking for them again.  Maybe it was a one time thing, trust me, you didn't miss anything.

Added 4/6/07:  Just went back today, asked for the smoothest coffee, it was pretty slow so the lady behind the counter was very helpful, gave me a nice smooth blend with honey and creme, which was great, until it got cold, then the honey gave it a weird taste.  And the samosas are actually SAMBOSAS apparently an Ethiopian pastry, had a veggie one that tasted just like a samosa, at $2 they're tastey but pricey.  Tried the apple tart too, yummy!
author: Asha H.

description:
Having worked with a few coffee snobs in my day, I'd heard so much flak against Philz concept, which basically shat on it for taking a non-purist approach to coffee.  Non-purist?  Well, maybe a revolutionary approach to coffee by adding cardamom to a french roast, rather than accepting the 'make the best black coffee' mantra.  

Anyway, after living in SF for over 3 yrs, it took a return trip to get me into Philz.  And guess what?  I loved it.  The concept, the service, and my original cup of joe.  I'm a 'best black coffee' or espresso type of guy usually, but I loved that Philz is pushing the boundaries of what coffee is supposed to taste like.  I only wished I'd figured it out when I lived in SF.  :(
author: Robby T.

description:
For this native San Diegan, this is my FAVORITE place for coffee. The service is great and the coffee is almost orgasmic. The atmosphere is pretty cool too.

I came across Philz while walking in the Mission district a few years back. My roommate was tired and I kept saying there was a coffee house down the street (eventually there was). We ordered our coffee, sat in an old leather couch and enjoyed the fresh air from all the plants inside. We felt rejuvenated (oxygen I think) and went along our way.

I miss Philz Coffee and can't wait to go back. If it means anything, this San Diegan highly recommends it!
author: Vero B.

description:
I agree, the coffee is REALLY freakin good!  I was surprised that they charged $2.75 for a small but then I had a sip and I understood, it was one hell of a drink!     

Another positive.  They have free wi-fi and three computers for their customers to use, very cool.

Also love the chess set that's out, though I'm a terrible player, it inspired me.

Only drawback.  If you're trying to work or want to read, it's a little hard.  The music is loud and this is a place where people hang out.  For a quieter space I would go to Mission Creek Cafe.  But coffee and service wise, fantastic!
author: Swetha G.

description:
Why is Philz beloved? A lot of it has to do with the coffee - it's brewed to order from a dizzying menu - not of coffee drinks, but of coffees. If you need cream and sugar, they'll add it, after they try to convince you that you don't need much of it.

A friend lives near this location, so we walked there one Sunday morning. She seemed happy to introduce me to one of her new favorite places. The peace march or stop the violence march or down with Bush march or band geeks for Obama march or whatever the parade was down 24th street seemed to make sense, even when they drowned out the live jazz playing that morning. But balance returned in the form of a mocha tesora with a sprig of mint, as the marchers moved on, and the band resumed.
author: Timothy O.

description: Nice, relax envirnoment. Coffe make at real time. Watching them to make the coffee is fun. Try #19 Tesora if it is your first time visiting. The croissants are delicious, though I hope they make them half the size and half the price so that I can try different tastes at the same time.
author: Ting S.

description:
it was actually a pretty interesting way how i found philz coffee. i was trying to go to another cafe but their line was out the freakin door and there was no way i was going to get to work on time! so i got on my handy yelp app on my iphone and found philz. got to philz i was so confused. what are all these names on the wall? where are the lattes? why are people getting out of line and getting back in line??? well, a barista called next so i went up there, she already knew i was lost haha! so, she quickly explained everything and told me to get their medium orginal coffee.

i loved how there were so many different types of coffee and the full service milk and sugar. i tried my coffee when it was ready and it was delish! glad i found this spot!
author: Anita L.

description: I hope they will soon have a Louis Vuitton shop between Philz and local mission eatery to do a little shopping between lunch and coffee. And vallet parking wouldn't change Philz margins much. Anyhow. This is the Mission and Philz makes great coffee but charging $5 in this area is not catering to the locals or at least not catering to the people who are going to stay local over the next 10 years. And that is sad. As sad as my desire to buy an appartment right next to it.
author: Bobby T.

description: I love Philz. The Ecstatic Iced is my absolute favorite! And boy am I productive once I have one of these.
author: Nicole L.

description: BEST coffee in San Francisco, period.  #fact
author: Anthony B.

description: Amazing coffee, pleasent enviorment, sets a good mood when u wake up to a cloudy SF day
author: Emerson R.

description:
When I thought I knew all of SF hidden gems along comes an invite from a friend to go to Philz for Coffee.   I thought to myself--'oh no'--- not one of those overly numerous unpersonalited coffee houses that has no passion about anything they sell and worse their main stay product is standard or sub-standard and is rarely fresh.

I have been on this part of 24th Street many times and have not really paid attention to what was on this particular corner of 24 & Folsom Street.   Upon entering this 'come as you are' coffee house was a sign board displaying 5 coffee specialties:  so far i have tried only 2 - the Turkish and Arabic.  

I wasn't sure what to expect so I ordered the Turkish coffee at the Barrista Bar.  I was asked if I wanted sugar and milk and I said "No."  The wonderous Barrista said "are you sure..."  she then said "let me make it the way I like it... you will like it."  So she immediately goes to work pours the hot water from a distance into a low tech (high flavour) individually brewed cup of coffee.  I savoured the herbaceous blend and the powerfully blissful coffee.  This I knew was going to be a treat upon my first pursed sip.  

I like the humble setting and very modest interior-- with coffee bags all carefully classified and this truly creates the coffee experience that I seek each time I go out for coffee-- this truly is a cafeteria.  I love to have service of someone taking their art form and giving me the best offering.   

We are such an individualised society that we give impossibly smug orders to a coffee maker at a branded coffee house --we cannot never truly get a full and ever reaching experience and exposure to new things.  Phil is passionate about his art and it comes across coherently and completely.

Coffee is very important and it sets the stage for the day ahead.   I am a big food and wine lover.  And what I enjoy about coffee is that it has an even more complex flavour spectrum than does wine.  I look for and am fussy about not having the best in food and wine (it doesn't always mean expensive for expensive sake).

Try Philz--simply amazing coffee and great experience-- one of my favourite coffee houses that I have found in my many travels.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Go Phil Go!  It looks like he's beginning to spread his stores around the City, there's even a "coming soon" sign near the Mission Bay Branch of the Library.  That'll be a nice homey addition to the sterile feeling of the 'hood with the Safeways/Quiznos around the corner.  This coffee is not for the weak, my mind is still racing around like a crack addict with ADD, and it's been at least 3 hours since I finished my tesora.  

Like everyone says, it's "one cup at a time", in that the bean selection to the grinding to the drip is all done right there on the spot, and it's good.  They even put sugar and cream.  Good place to grab a cup o' Philz and walk around, because it's just too damn cold to be sitting still...
author: Mark D.

description:
Phill is actually a local legend and it is quite odd that the reviews are sparse.

Each cup is brewed just for you and filled with care and love.

Fresh mint and cardoman help too.

And the shakes.  Dear god I love the shakes.

No, not milkshakes.

The shakes.  Phillz has my insides playing pinball with my heart.
author: Jen I.

description:
While I was staying at a friend's place for a conference, he recommended that I stop in and get some coffee at Philz.

I'm not really a coffee freak, but the I tried a few different blends for the week I was in town. The coffee is brewed fresh by the cup and is pretty tasty. Unfortunately the coffee cups they have leak coffee from the lid... I ended up getting coffee on my shirt on the way to the conference I was attending.
author: Nader A.

description:
One of the things I love about the city besides its wide area of terrific cafe/restaurant options, is that a lot of the best places get the attention they deserve.  Hence the lines outside of Tartine, Bi-Rite, and Mitchell's, and the buzz that surrounds Philz. Philz is awesome because it takes the ubiquitous cafe idea and makes it so much better just by taking the flavor of their coffee and tea as far as they can go.  The chai with soymilk is the best chai I've ever had and the Istanbul Treat is a wonderfully interesting combination of green and black tea, mint, and cardamom to create something that's really special.  I'm not much of a coffee drinker, but I love the Tesora mocha and understand why its been described as a masterpiece.

The place is homey and the cluttered feel of the cafe adds to the experience for me.  It feels consistent with Phil's focus on the drinks not on the ambiance.
author: Tom W.

description:
I'm torn about this review.  It's obvious Philz is an institution, and the business has received so many good reviews so it's probably warranted its reputation.  Probably.  But I wonder what they put in the water in SF that turns so many into the easily impressed.  Is Philz' coffee good?  I've been here once, so who am I do be in a position exactly to say?  But I can quibble about issues outside of its deliciousness or lack thereof.

1 - Organization:  Where the F is the line?  Oh, wait, there isn't one.  People just come in and order willy nilly.  Baristas just call out and people step up.  If you've never been, be prepared to know what you want before someone jumps in front of you.
2 - Board layout:  Sure, the coffees and prices are listed up high for all to see.  So why not put the board that lists the type of coffees up there, too?  You know, the one at knee level in front of the counters being blocked by the many patrons who walk in front of you while you try to get a grasp on what type of coffee to drink for the day?  Yeah, that one.  Put that shit at eye level or above where people won't obstruct my view (this goes back to my organization problem)
3 - Aesthetic:  I'm simply not a fan of shabby coffee house chic.  It's not chic.  I don't like places that look like they found their furniture on the street corner an hour earlier or pulled it from some apartment that's been condemned due to prostitution.
4 - Drinker's Choice:  I don't like that I can't dictate the amount of milk or half and half and sugar I put in my coffee.  At Philz, the baristas have to put it in.  What is this, Dunkin' Donuts?  If each coffee is individualized, then why would I want a barista putting the milk/sugar in my coffee?  Let me figure out how much or how little of each I want in my drink.  Just because I put a certain amount of each in one type of coffee, does not mean I'll do the same for a different roast.

That said, the coffee itself I tried (It'z the Best) wasn't the best.  It was satisfactory.  I've had better (and cheaper!!-SF really brings new meaning to the phrase "rip off" when it comes to individually dripped cups of coffee).  I also tried my brother's.  I thought the mint leaf overpowered his coffee somewhat.

Baristas were super nice.  And I loved that Phil actually works here.  So how can I not at least give three stars?  That's a real work ethic, and I don't begrudge him his success.  The next time I come back, I'll be better prepared to order quick, get my cup of coffee, and get the hell out of there.
author: Brendan Jude L.

description: Don't know what that mint does to me, but just thinking about Philz makes me happy. A definite favorite.
author: Lori T.

description: I didn't try the coffee, but i fell in love with Phil. I've never met anyone more helpful -- friend or family.
author: Ben M.

description:
Yippeee!!!  After hearing from a friend how good the mocha tesora
is at Philz, I was thrilled to find the store in the Mission District.  I don't know if it's always crowded in there, but it was really busy on the day I was there.  It may have been because there were a lot of people in the Mission attending the SF Street Food Festival. Back to the mocha tesora.....it was GOOD!  Smooth and flavorful are the best way to describe it.  

One of these days I need to stop by the Philz in Palo Alto.
author: D B.

description: I am a latte` addict........mmm too bad they don't do latte.  I am good with Rich, creamy, tasty coffee from Philz make my day brighter and energetic.  They should open around in the Sunset area!
author: Wafa R.

description:
You purists may scoff, but best coffee I've ever had.
I've worked my way through most of the menu and never had a bad brew.  I had a Philharmonic w/ cream and no sugar this morning, so I'll leave that as my recommendation.
author: Alex K.

description:
It's FRESH because it's all handmade - each cup. I'm not a coffee drinker, so I ordered a mint tea which was amazing. I saw her put in fresh mint leaves, mixed with cream and sugar and yummyness all around! 

The shop is cozy and comfortable. It's filled with artwork and the service is friendly. I'm definitely coming back!
author: Gladys C.

description:
Ritual, watch your back.

I'm one down and 25 or so to go at Philz.  This place is no nonsense, get-the-best-cup-of-coffee-around.  Period.

No matter how you like it - you'll find it at Philz - there are over 20 options to choose from and when you get overwhelmed the staff is happy to help you navigate.

It's certainly not as hip as Ritual and others, (though to their credit, they were playing the Brazilian Girls when I dropped in) but I'm hard pressed to imagine a better place to find the perfect cup of java.

Update: Two down.  Holy crap.  The person I was with was astonished when he tasted it, to the tune of "that's probably the best cup of coffee I've ever had.  That's delicious."  Take notes - Turkish Brew people.
author: Jenny S.

description:
I found this place a few months ago as I was making my way down 24th street towards the BART station one Saturday morning.  I had been up really late, and my patience was worn thin by this point.  I could've stopped at any number of other coffee places on the way, but for whatever reason I wandered into Philz in a slight daze.  There was a line of people eagerly awaiting their drinks, and the counter person asked me if I'd ever been here before.  I told her no, and she assured me that I was in for an eye opening cup of joe.

I settled into one of their tattered old living room seats five minutes later and took a long slow sip as the opening strains of Lou Reed's "Vicious" wafted down from the ceiling-mounted speakers.  This place is cool, I thought to myself.  The messy living room vibe was sinking in heavy, and it hadn't even really registered to me yet just how good the coffee itself was.  

blah blah blah blah blah...so anyways, the coffee was really good.  They specialize in these sort of proprietary drinks, which are not your ordinary latte, americano, etc.  The flavor is very delicate, and they have a velvety texture to them as you take each sip.  They serve each cup with a healthy scoop of what appears to be brown sugar, and often throw a mint leaf on top.  Its somewhat gimmicky to be sure, but you won't find another cup of coffee like this any other place in the city.  

Since I live in the Sunset, and don't usually come out to the Mission except for the nightlife, I find Philz to be a good excuse to head across town on a Sunday morning.  Its definitely one of the three or four best coffee houses in the city.
author: Gopal R.

description:
review 164, im not a unique snowflake.

Went there for the first time to see what the hype was about.  I was lucky to get there in the afternoon, so there was pretty much no line up.  I walked up said I have never been there before and went with the girl's suggestion, I think it was the Turkish blend.  It lived up to the hype.  It is the first time I had strong coffee without acidity or nasty aftertaste.  A great range of flavor in one cup, not too sweet because they added the sugar to their standard.  Not to be dramatic, but I walked out not knowing what coffee should be now.  Its almost like Philz coffee is a beverage of its own because it is so different.  I can still drink the common swill without comparing it to Philz.

The pastries arent that great.  But the coffee is well worth the trip.
author: H C.

description:
The best coffee brewed right on the spot and they know exactly how you want it, with or with out cream and sugar!!! Phil made us feel so special, he made a soy milk one for me and I fell in love!! hahaha with the coffee, but Phil's easy to fall for too! This place has it's charm and lots of charater. Great find! It's coffee, so none of that starbucks nonsense...

I work close by the Ball Park and there's a location there too! Lucky me!
author: Judi K.

description:
I mentioned before the amazingly-strong coffee. But did I mention the decor? Well, this one definitely makes for a fun afternoon. The little-lady and I made our way up here to meet a new-potential friend. We found lots to keep us entertained, including fricken scrabble! The interior is totally "rainforest-based" and the coffee and staff are just as good, if not better, than other locations.
*ding!*
author: Liz L.

description:
Coffee on another level.

I don't know how they do it, but it's a symphony in your mouth.

But stay away from their pasteries - they are as big as your head and there are flies everywhere.
author: elaine m.

description:
Holy shit, the coffee is strong!  I had a small iced coffee during the day, and I couldn't sleep at night!  The coffee is good too.  It's way better and way cheaper than Starbucks.

They have catchy names for their coffees.  I had The Ecstatic Iced Coffee.  The baristas are totally cool.  The couches, tables, and chairs are wacky.  There are different color and fabric couches, rolling chairs, leather chairs, wooden chairs, round tables, square tables, etc.  They don't match, but who cares!  There's even a piano for you to compose your next hit single on.  There's also FREE wi-fi, something all coffee shops should have!

I would definitely go back. +5 or you, Phil.
author: Kev H.

description:
Ambrosia is the coffee of the gods.

In all honesty, other than some Turkish coffee I once had on a balcony overlooking the Adriatic sea in most romantic and far-away Dubrovnik, there is no better form of caffeine than ambrosia from Philz.  While I have a hard time seeing a Zeus-like figure there, I occasionally see some young and beautiful guys that could be avatars of Apollo ordering and going out the door.

It is true, what the barista said the first time I went to Philz: "if you've ever had a better cup of coffee, I'll be a straight man."  Damned skippy he wasn't, and damned true I'd never had a better cup of brew.
author: Jana T.

description: I was wondering why a cup of tea costs $2.50, but then I got my tea and I figured it out. I had an herbal mint tea, and it was full of flora so it was pretty and it tasted wonderful. There were enough mint leaves in the cup that I may have gotten a serving of vegetables. Real mint!! Anyway, it was also cool that all the ladies behind the counter were constantly checking to make sure that no customer was ignored. I will be back.
author: Merrilee T.

description:
True, this place is legendary. Much of the mission can be divided into "oh, that's close to Philz!" and everywhere else. That said however, I don't think that it really lives up to its hype. 

Okay, the coffee is awesome. In fact, I tend to agree that it's the best in town. The Tesora is the veteran coffee drinker's best friend and the Soo Good, lives up to its namesake. Also, unsurprisingly, the tea (green with mint and honey) is also fantastic. Overall, whatever liquid just filled your little brown cup is going to be great. 

Besides the coffee though, Philz leaves much to be desired. The layout is terrible; both getting your coffee and trying to find a place to sit feel more like a trek into the Temple of Doom, than a pleasant way to spend the morning. It's constantly packed, it's pretty expensive, and finding a place to plug in your computer is usually a fruitless endeavor. 

I still love Philz, however, if they ditched the wifi, got rid of some of their decaying couches and chairs, and streamlined the ordering process, I would no longer have a reason to walk past it in favor of the numerous other cafes on 24th.
author: Evan S.

description:
Best Coffee Ever. So good it gives me chills. 
The staff is helpful and enthusiastic, the treats are scrumptious. 
It's usually packed, but always worth the wait. 

My favorites: Sooo Good, Canopy of Heaven.
author: Megan G.

description: Currently addicted to the mocha tesora.  I probably don't want to know how much fat is in the cream and sugar (and everything else) that goes in there, but I'll keep feigning ignorance as I order another large coffee.
author: Melinda C.

description: Well, this place is fine. They make some good coffee. However, I can't help but feel its popularity (and it is popular) is mostly sizzle and not much steak. First, what the fuck is with all the different flavors but no info on what's actually *in* them? Frankly, most of them taste the same to me. And, do you know what cream they use? "Manufacturing cream." This shit has over 40% fat content (more than heavy whipping cream). Hell, you could put manufacturing cream in Sanka and it would make the coffee taste fucking amazing. So, it's a fine cup of coffee; a little over-hyped in my opinion. Oh, and I'm no neat freak but those fabric seating options = petri dish.
author: Chris M.

description:
I like all things coffee and this is by far the way coffee *should* taste. 

Forget Starbucks, Peet's, or Tully's...Philz is the way to go! 

Philz is a great way to start off any day..oh yeah and it's quite addictive...crack coffee...so hot right now.
author: Natalie C.

description:
Wow!

I can't believe I'm the first to rate this place!!
(Now the paranoia sets in-- did I just not find the exsiting reviews??)

Anyhow... I went to Phillz for the first time a few weeks back and had a transcendent experience.

The coffee is simply amazing. AMAZING.  And juding by the rush in there... its worth the wait. . 

I say wait, becuase they make each cup individually.... each cup is lovingly and carefully prepared... these people REALLY love their 
coffee.

It's also the very strongest coffee I've ever tasted-- without it tasting too acidic or bitter-- the coffee is rich and thick and I think is the secret to flight

There's a few pastries available, and a few places to sit for those obligatory chess games...

The greatest thing ever is Phil himself.
(Yes, there's a Phil!)

He's one of those older gentlemen with an amazing lust for life, that he gives off that "crazy like a fox" vibes -- in a good way. He was very warm, very matter of fact in explaining his coffees and how he does business... he obviously loves his coffee very very much.

Pity I don't live in the city-- or I'd make this part of my regular routine.

Oh, and if I could give extra stars for the fact that they carry organic, vegan donuts, I would.
author: Roachie D.

description:
One word... Mocha Tesora coffee. with mint 
It's a kinda of minty, chocolaty Turkish drip coffee... so thick you can put a spoon in it upright... And after you drink the coffee, you can read your fortune in the remaining coffee grains..  Only bad part... the special drip process takes a while... and lines can get long...

I'm not a coffee drinker.... but when I need a caffeine fix, there's only one place I head to... Philz... Plus I remember I gave my old leather couch to Phil when I was moving out of the hood... He actually came with a guy to get it... I think it's in one of the shops now...what a guy!
author: Doris M.

description:
They say Philz Coffee is like crack. I got "its the best" and about 10 minutes later my arms were tingly. HA.

I do like the kind service and local feel to the place.
author: Anita C.

description:
As a recent transplant from Seattle (supposedly the coffee capital), I have been continuously impressed with the quality of the locally owned coffee bars in San Francisco. They surpass most of what Seattle has to offer.

I drink coffee pretty rarely, being more of a tea person, but when I do I am picky. I like my coffee rich and full bodied. Even a hint of sourness and it goes down the drain. Philz more than met my needs. 

Be warned - this is not the place to go for your double latte or white chocolate mocha. Each cup is made separately - that's right, one cup at a time - fresh brewed drip with your choice of beans. They even sugar and cream it for you. I  worried they'd over sweeten, but they added just the right amount. I ordered #1, a Turkish brew, hoping for strength and body. It delivered. Everyone else seemed equally pleased with their individual choices. It's all just a matter of deciding which of the more than 20 roasts is right for you. There are a few non-coffee selections, as well. One friend ordered an Istanbul tea, which was aromatic and strong. The menu also boasts iced tea, hot chocolate, and iced coffee.

As an additional bonus, a gentleman lounged on a bench rockin' the blues on a harmonica. My toe was tapping even before the caffeine hit my system. It added to the quirky, earthy feel of the joint. 

Overall: excellent atmosphere, excellent service, excellent coffee. The only thing missing is a description of each roast to help with the selection process.
author: Veronica L.

description:
I grew up loving coffee in the pacific northwest and now am stranded in the midwest with mediocre coffee in good vibe shops ... but this place blew my mind.  I was ready to move next door just for the amazing coffee ... I can only think of one or two cups of coffee that have been at this level my entire life ...

Do not leave San Fran without trying a cup ... even if you arent a coffee lover this place will make you think twice about your morning beverage.
author: Sara P.

description:
The first time I walked in, I had no idea what this place was about (nor did I pay much attention) and ordered a large coffee...DOH!!!

Philz stands alone in the world of coffee (be gone evil starbucks!) Quality coffee for those who are particular, or for those of us who still enjoy the flavor of our coffee...if you like to taste your coffee, only Philz will do.

You pick out what type of beans you want from an incredibly long list, what spices you want to add (if any) and then they grind it and press it for you. AMAZING....
author: Beth M.

description:
I drink a lot of coffee, but this place is where I turn on the big days. 
You know the days, you have your morning coffee to wake you up but you need that booster shot- these are the days you need philz!
When I I'm in SUPER need of that good ole coffee high that so often eludes, I'm here. But trust me, it's a serious, strong cup of coffee. Phil is a flirt, but it's in a fun way. he loves when you love his coffee.
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
Just got home with a small cup of house blend.
I didn't know they don't serve espresso drinks until I got there, but the guy at the cafe was nice and patient.  Since I ordered a latte not knowing what they actually serve, he offered to foam milk.  I got sweet house blend with 1% milk.  GOOD!

Never knew I enjoy dripped coffee until today!
author: Yoko S.

description: So yummy! My hubby and I end up here at least once a week, and it never disappoints. Amazing coffee AND they have mini cupcakes!
author: Kathryn M.

description: Nice place to hang out and kill the afternoon.
author: Shirley W.

description: We came to this place unplanned, just wanting to get a coffee. What we experienced was probably the best coffee since long time ( and nothing what we had expected in the US :-)).  Can highly recommend this place and will go there again if an opportunity comes up.
author: Michael S.

description:
If you're a coffee fiend like I am, you'll put your caffeine twitches to rest with a tall cup of Turkish from Philz. Just as in any other case, "the blacker the berry, the sweeter the juice," and the Turkish will deliver the goods. Dark, Rich, Herbaliciously tasty. But make no mistake, this is no 'limp-wristed sissy-boy' coffee - each cup of hand crafted coffee delivers at least a pots worth of caffeine and a proportionally sized grin to go with it. And not to worry, if you're a newbie or just a hipster, they have many medium and lighter roasts for you too! I recommend letting the Philz staff pimp-out your cup of joe with the quite essential - cream, sugar, and fresh mint. 

Enjoy!

p.s.  take your own mug/thermos - you'll save some waste and they'll cut you a small discount. =)
author: Pejman M.

description:
Hands down the best coffee in the city and I am obsessed.  I was lucky enough to have Phil make me my first cup of Philz.  Now I love the Philharmonic blend.

In an attempt to cut calories, I have recently opted for non-fat milk instead of cream, and it tastes good too!
author: Rachel F.

description:
From the comments here, it should be clear that Philz is not for everyone. And honestly, the first two cups I had, they were good, but I didn't get it.

My mistake was getting the coffee black (how I normally drink it). Let them do the whole cream and sugar thing, and you are getting the intended flavors and experience. World of difference.

And, I guess, if it doesn't work for you, move along. You can't please everyone, and you only have to watch one cup get made to realize that Philz is not a product produced for the masses. For those of us who like it, we like it a lot.
author: Michael A.

description:
I was a coffee snob before trying my first cup of Philz. I knew where all the small batch roastery cafes were and preferred Peets to Starbucks. Now I'm totally screwed. I live in Hayes Valley, within easy walking distance of Blue Bottle, but I gladly drive across town to get my Ambrosia. The cycle of addiction usually starts with the Turkish blend...or Arabic and then one ventures out further down the list until they settle on their all time favorite. Veterans get really particular about which barista prepares their coffee and subtle differences in cups from day to day, but when they get it all right, nothing compares. 

I am highly suspicious of anyone that bothers to write anything but a 5 star review of Philz Coffee. This may be a good place for homeland security to start searching for insurgents.
author: Darren K.

description:
I am converted forever... just when I thought gourmet coffee couldn't get any better - I found Philz!

I often go out of my way, illegally park, run late to appointments just to get a cup of my Philz coffee.  My favorite blend is their Philtered Soul.  Each cup is dripped individually, hand crafted so to speak, made just for you.  The aroma is tantalizing.  At a comparable $3 a cup, why would anyone still patron Starbucks...?
author: Judy C.

description:
I gave up coffee five months ago, but today, I couldn't walk past Philz without grabbing a small Turkish. It was just as good as I remembered it.

The 24th St. Philz is one of the most eclectic coffee shops I've ever been in. It's such a dizzying array of signs and stuff everywhere that it can be mistaken for a haphazard establishment. That said, the coffee is amazing. Made one cup at a time, this is the anti-Starbucks of all coffees. The whole ordering process and queue situation is a little crowded and backwards at times, but that's fine. Just go with the flow and try not to come in with any expectations. You'll be presently surprised.
author: Tim B.

description:
Hangover CURE.

Turkish coffee. Strong, spicy, bold and easy on a queasy stomach.

Live jazz music? Creepy guy on the bench outside watching me makeout? Mis-matched comfy furniture? Crazy dude trying to bum a cigarette?? Fashion plates lazily waiting in line? This is an authentic coffee house as diverse as SF itself.

I am a convert to the church of Philz.
author: Patrice S.

description:
This sounds like I'm boasting but when Philz first opened it was a health foods store. I was happy cause we could use one in the neighborhood and i did my best to give him my business. He was always nice, the place was always empty and he'd often have me taste coffee "blends" he was testing (chocolate and coffee, mint and coffee, etc). I moved a few blocks away and kinda forgot about him. Well, no less than a year later, he remade the place and built and incredible niche for himself. 

Philz is part of the "one cup at a time" movement which means every cup is brewed fresh--including grinding the beans. It makes a difference. Their coffee is amazing--it's the only coffee I buy. I've also had their green tea and it was fabulous though their Chai left me wanting. Philz is the bomb and I love it!
author: Mario T.

description: This is the original Philz. It's filled with mismatched couches, random tables and hipsters on their Macs. The floor is a little sticky, but all of these qualities make this place vintage. Stopped in for a chai after my acupuncture appointment and it totally hit the spot. I love the mint sprigs in there. Gives the chai a refreshing flavor you can only find at Philz. And I must apologize to Blue Bottle, because I think I've found my new spot. I like that I can order my drinks the way I want. Not like at some places where I cant get a Gibraltar to go ahem. And free wifi here woohoo!
author: Trina A.

description:
This place helped me get through many papers, projects and night classes during my first semester of grad school.Was it the coffee, the Mission or the company I liked so much?
 I don't come here much anymore because I no longer do any work in the area but I remember the iced coffee, chai tea, free wireless, big kitchen table, friendly service and study buddy very fondly.
author: deb C.

description:
This is a great coffee shop, with horrible coffee.  It's a good place to meet up with people and have a sit, and get a pastry.  I love the atomsphere, despite the horde of fixie-riding hipsters surrounding the place,  but the coffee is simply bad. 

I've bought beans three times to use in either a filter or my espresso machine, mainly because I live right around the corner and was too hung over to get to Peets.  

Each time i have sought the advice of the people who work there and told them what i like.    And each time i am reminded of safeway select coffee.   This last time I read the description of the coffee and nowhere did it say anything about being flavored,  but now as I sit here choking it down, i'm left with an awful chemical "french vanilla non-dairy creamer" sort of after taste.   I smelled it the second I poured water on the beans.  Bleah!

Head down to the corporate-esque organic coffee shop at 24th and harrison instead,  the prices are a bit better and it tastes good.
author: Max B.
